choices.text: Administer H₂ blocker in all ventilated ICU patients
Avoid prophylaxis unless GI bleed occurs

questions.text: A 66-year-old man in the ICU with septic shock is on mechanical ventilation for 3 days and receiving vasopressors for hemodynamic support. He has no history of gastrointestinal bleeding. Current labs show platelets 48,000/μL, INR 1.7, and creatinine 2.1 mg/dL. He is being fed via a nasogastric tube but is unable to tolerate oral medications. A junior resident suggests continuing only fluids and lactulose due to infection concerns with acid-suppressive agents. What is the most appropriate approach for stress ulcer prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administer PPI or H₂ blocker

 

  • This patient meets multiple high-risk criteria for clinically significant upper GI bleeding:
    • Mechanical ventilation >48 hours,
    • Bleeding diathesis (platelets <50,000/µL, INR >1.5),
    • Shock requiring vasopressors.
  • For critically ill high-risk patients, guidelines strongly recommend SUP with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) or histamine-2 receptor blocker (H₂ blocker) (Grade 1B).
  • PPI is preferred due to superior acid suppression and evidence from meta-analyses supporting its efficacy in preventing UGIB, especially in those at highest risk.
  • In patients unable to take enteral medications, an IV PPI is preferred; IV H₂ blockers are an acceptable alternative if cost or availability is an issue.
  • Though acid suppression is associated with increased VAP and Clostridioides difficile risk, these risks are outweighed by the benefits in high-risk ICU patients.
  • Sucralfate is no longer considered effective as monotherapy for SUP in high-risk patients.
  • Avoiding prophylaxis until bleeding occurs contradicts the preventive intent of SUP.

 

Indications for Stress Ulcer Prophylaxis in ICU:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start sucralfate regardless of risk: Not evidence-based for high-risk ICU patients and less effective than PPIs or H₂ blockers.

 

Option C. Administer H₂ blocker in all ventilated patients: Blanket approach is outdated. SUP is recommended only in those with bleeding risk.

 

Option D. Avoid prophylaxis unless GI bleed occurs: SUP is preventive, not therapeutic — waiting for bleeding defeats its purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In critically ill ICU patients with bleeding diathesis or mechanical ventilation >48 hours, stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI (preferred) or H₂ blocker is recommended. The benefits of prophylaxis outweigh infection risks in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the paediatrician for a routine examination. On physical examination, the right side of the scrotum is empty, and the testis is palpated in the inguinal canal. The parents are concerned and ask about possible complications their child may face in the future if this condition is left untreated. Which of the following is the least likely complication associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal hydrocele

 

  • A vaginal hydrocele occurs when there is fluid accumulation around the testis only in the scrotum (tunica vaginalis). 
  • However, in the case of an undescended testis, a patent processus vaginalis will lead to a “congenital” hydrocele which will extend from the scrotum up to the deep ring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indirect inguinal hernia: Highly likely. About 90% of undescended testes are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, predisposing to indirect inguinal hernias.

 

Option B. Infertility: Common in undescended testes due to impaired spermatogenesis from higher intra-abdominal temperature. Even after orchidopexy, fertility may still be affected, particularly in bilateral cases.

 

Option C. Testicular torsion: More likely to occur in undescended testes due to inadequate fixation and abnormal mesentery, making them prone to rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Undescended testis (cryptorchidism) is associated with several complications if not surgically corrected early, including infertility, malignancy risk (seminoma), inguinal hernia, congenital hydrocele, and testicular torsion. 
  • However, a vaginal hydrocele is less likely in this condition since it typically involves the scrotal testis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with acute onset of profuse watery diarrhea described as resembling “rice water” or rice gruel. He recently returned from a coastal region in South Asia. He appears dehydrated, and stool cultures are pending. The physician suspects a bacterial toxin that increases intestinal permeability. Which of the following cellular structures is most likely impaired, leading to the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zona occludens


Zona occludens, also known as tight junctions, are crucial components of the intestinal epithelial barrier. They are located at the apical portion of epithelial cells and regulate paracellular permeability. In infections such as cholera, bacterial enterotoxins (like cholera toxin) disrupt these tight junctions, leading to massive water and electrolyte secretion into the intestinal lumen, producing watery diarrhea that resembles rice water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gap junction: Allow for intercellular communication via ions and small molecules but do not regulate epithelial barrier function.


Option C. Adherent junction: Provide mechanical adhesion between adjacent cells but do not primarily regulate permeability.


Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Anchor epithelial cells to the basement membrane and are not involved in regulating intestinal lumen permeability.

 

Educational Objective:


Damage to tight junctions (zona occludens) increases paracellular permeability in the gut, leading to leakage of fluids and electrolytes, a mechanism often exploited by pathogens causing secretory diarrhea.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with secondary infertility visits the clinic with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles and inability to conceive for 2 years. After ruling out anatomical and endocrinological causes, you decide to start ovulation induction with Clomiphene citrate 50 mg/day for 5 days. On which days of her menstrual cycle should she begin the medication for optimal follicular recruitment and ovulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Day 2 to Day 6

 

Clomiphene citrate is used for ovulation induction in women with anovulatory infertility. It is typically initiated at a dose of 50 mg/day for 5 days, starting from Day 2 to Day 6 of the menstrual cycle. This timing ensures adequate FSH stimulation for follicular development, leading to ovulation around Day 14 in a regular 28-day cycle.

 

  • If ovulation does not occur, the dose can be increased up to 100 mg/day.
  • If ovulation induction fails after 6–8 cycles, gonadotropin therapy may be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clomiphene citrate is started from Day 2 to Day 6 of the menstrual cycle for ovulation induction in anovulatory infertility. It acts by increasing FSH secretion and promoting follicular maturation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with multiple pruritic, erythematous papules distributed over his forehead, neck, and the V-area of his chest. He reports that the rash has recurred every summer for the past four years and tends to resolve spontaneously during the winter. He denies any systemic symptoms. He works outdoors and frequently uses various sunscreen and cosmetic products. Examination reveals discrete lichenified papules with mild scaling in the affected areas. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to identify the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patch test

 

  • The clinical picture is suggestive of chronic photoallergic contact dermatitis, often caused by a delayed-type (Type IV) hypersensitivity to photo-exposed allergens such as cosmetic ingredients or sunscreens. 
  • The patch test is the gold standard for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis due to delayed-type hypersensitivity. 
  • It involves applying allergens under occlusion for 48 hours and interpreting results at 48 and 96 hours. 48 hours is reading 1 and 96 hours is reading 2.
  • Reading 2 is best for patch test.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prick test: Used to evaluate immediate-type (Type I) hypersensitivity, typically for urticaria or food/drug allergies—not for delayed hypersensitivity.

 

Option C. Serum IgE levels: Elevated in atopic dermatitis or systemic allergic conditions but not helpful in diagnosing contact dermatitis.

 

Option D. Skin biopsy: May help exclude other dermatologic conditions but is not diagnostic for allergic contact dermatitis or its allergen.


Educational Objective:


Patch testing is the investigation of choice for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis caused by delayed-type hypersensitivity. It is particularly useful in chronic, relapsing, photo-distributed rashes exacerbated by topical exposures.

questions.text: A child presents with anemia, seizures, intellectual disability, and hair texture as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Menkes disease

 

Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to defective copper transport. This results in copper deficiency in various tissues.


Key clinical features:

 

  • Kinky, sparse, brittle hair (pili torti)
  • Neurodegeneration (seizures, hypotonia, developmental delay)
  • Anemia
  • Failure to thrive
  • Skeletal abnormalities
  • Death typically occurs in early childhood if untreated.

     

The characteristic hair abnormalities (seen in the image) are a hallmark of Menkes disease and help in clinical diagnosis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Down syndrome: Characterized by hypotonia, intellectual disability, flat facies, and congenital anomalies — not associated with kinky hair.


Option C. Iron deficiency anemia: Can cause pallor, pica, and hair thinning but not the kinky hair pattern seen here.


Option D. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Presents with self-mutilation, hyperuricemia, and neurologic features — hair changes are not typical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menkes disease is a copper transport disorder marked by kinky hair (pili torti), neurodevelopmental delay, seizures, and failure to thrive. It is confirmed by low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels and characteristic hair microscopy findings.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the nutritional composition of human milk is/are correct? 

 

  1. Human milk contains higher concentrations of whey and lactalbumin compared to casein.
  2. The calcium to phosphorus ratio in human milk is less than 1.
  3. Human milk is richer in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) and has lower protein content than cow’s milk.
  4. The osmolality of human milk is approximately 290 mOsm/L.
  5. Iron content in human milk ranges between 1.5–2.0 mg/100 mL.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, and 4

 

Statement 1. Human milk contains higher concentrations of whey and lactalbumin compared to casein: Correct, Human milk contains high levels of lactalbumin and whey protein, with whey: casein ratio of 60:40, making it easier to digest.

 

Statement 3. Human milk is richer in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) and has lower protein content than cow’s milk: Correct, Human milk is richer in PUFAs (important for brain and retinal development) and contains lower protein content (1.1 g/100 mL) compared to cow’s milk.

 

Statement 4. The osmolality of human milk is approximately 290 mOsm/L: Correct, the osmolality of human milk is approximately 280-300 mOsm/L, which is ideal for infant kidneys.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. The calcium to phosphorus ratio in human milk is less than 1: Incorrect, the calcium to phosphorus ratio in human milk is 2:1, which enhances calcium absorption—unlike cow's milk, where the ratio is lower.

 

Statement 5. Iron content in human milk ranges between 1.5–2.0 mg/100 mL: Incorrect, Iron content in human milk is 0.29–0.45 mg/100 mL, not 1.5–2.0 mg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human milk provides optimal nutrition tailored to infants, with a high whey-to-casein ratio, low protein content, essential fatty acids, ideal osmolality, and enhanced mineral bioavailability despite low absolute concentrations.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a history of neurosyphilis presents with difficulty in vision, especially in dim light. On examination, his pupils are small, irregular, and do not constrict in response to light, but do constrict during accommodation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Argyll Robertson pupil

 

Argyll Robertson pupil is classically associated with neurosyphilis. These pupils:

 

  • Are small and irregular
  • Exhibit light-near dissociation (they do not constrict to light, but do constrict during accommodation)
  • Are often bilateral
  • Known as "prostitute’s pupils" — they accommodate but do not react

 

 

This presentation is highly specific to tertiary syphilis (neurosyphilis).


Other Options:

 

Option A. Marcus Gunn pupil:  Seen in optic nerve disease, typically unilateral, presenting as a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). Light response is affected in both direct and consensual pathways, unlike the light-near dissociation in this case.

 

Option B. Tonic pupil (Adie’s pupil):  Usually unilateral, with a dilated pupil that reacts poorly to light and slowly to accommodation. It is typically seen in young women, not linked to neurosyphilis.

 

Option C. Oculomotor nerve (CN III) paralysis:  Results in a dilated pupil, often with ptosis and extraocular muscle involvement. The pupil may not respond to light or near stimulus depending on parasympathetic involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupils are classically seen in neurosyphilis and are characterized by small, irregular pupils that accommodate but do not react to light — a key example of light-near dissociation.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child presents with failure to thrive and laboratory findings reveal metabolic acidosis with an elevated anion gap. Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal tubular acidosis

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) occurs when there is an accumulation of unmeasured anions (such as lactate, ketones, or organic acids). Common causes include:

 

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (A) → ↑ ketone bodies
  • Chronic renal failure (B) → retention of acids like sulfates and phosphates
  • Inborn errors of metabolism (D) → organic acidemias (e.g., methylmalonic acidemia)

 

Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA), on the other hand, is a cause of normal (non-anion gap) metabolic acidosis. It results from defects in acid excretion or bicarbonate reabsorption without accumulation of unmeasured anions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal tubular acidosis presents with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, unlike conditions such as Methanol exposure, Uremia, DKA, Propylene glycol exposure, Infection/Isoniazid, Lactic acidosis, Ethylene glycol exposure, Salicylates (Mnemonic - MUDPILES) which present with a high anion gap.

questions.text: Which of the following amoebae is least likely to be associated with neuropathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dientamoeba fragilis

 

Dientamoeba fragilis is a protozoan parasite primarily associated with gastrointestinal symptoms, including abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and flatulence. It has no established neuropathogenic potential and is not known to invade the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balamuthia mandrillaris: This free-living amoeba causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE), a rare but often fatal CNS infection. It typically affects immunocompromised patients but can also affect immunocompetent individuals.

 

Option B. Naegleria fowleri: Known as the “brain-eating amoeba,” Naegleria fowleri causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), a rapidly progressive and nearly universally fatal CNS disease following exposure to warm freshwater.

 

Option D. Acanthamoeba species: Acanthamoeba can lead to granulomatous amoebic encephalitis in immunocompromised individuals. It can also cause keratitis, particularly in contact lens users.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dientamoeba fragilis is a gastrointestinal parasite and is not associated with CNS disease, unlike other free-living amoebae such as Naegleria, Acanthamoeba, and Balamuthia which are neuropathogenic.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic during flu season with high-grade fever, dry cough, myalgia, and nasal congestion. The symptoms began abruptly two days ago. A rapid antigen test confirms infection with a virus that has a negative-sense RNA genome and neuraminidase activity as part of its envelope glycoproteins. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Influenza virus

 

  • The influenza virus is a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Orthomyxoviridae family.
  • It is unique among human viruses in possessing two key surface glycoproteins:
    • Hemagglutinin (HA) – for binding to host cell receptors
    • Neuraminidase (NA) – for viral release by cleaving sialic acid
  • The presence of neuraminidase activity and negative-sense RNA genome identifies the virus as Influenza.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Newcastle disease virus: A paramyxovirus affecting birds, rarely infects humans, but does contain neuraminidase. However, it is not a common cause of human respiratory disease in children.

 

Option B. Parainfluenza virus: Also a paramyxovirus and negative-sense RNA virus, it lacks significant neuraminidase activity and primarily causes croup (laryngotracheobronchitis).

 

Option D. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV): Negative-sense RNA virus from Paramyxoviridae, causes bronchiolitis and pneumonia in infants, but does not possess neuraminidase. It uses fusion (F) protein for entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Influenza virus is a negative-sense RNA virus that uniquely expresses both hemagglutinin and neuraminidase on its surface—key for viral entry and release—distinguishing it from other respiratory viruses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who recently returned from a conflict zone presents with fever and generalized rash. On examination, he is febrile and found to have body lice in his clothing. The rash is widespread but notably spares the palms and soles. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

  • Rickettsia prowazekii causes epidemic typhus, which classically presents with fever, rash, and history of louse infestation.
  • The rash typically starts centrally and spreads peripherally, sparing the palms and soles.
  • It occurs in crowded, unsanitary conditions, such as in military camps, prisons, or among displaced populations—matching the history of a militant in this case.
  • Transmission occurs via body lice (Pediculus humanus corporis), which defecate on skin; scratching introduces the organism into circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia conorii: Causes Mediterranean spotted fever; presents with fever, and rash that includes palms and soles—not consistent with this vignette.

 

Option B. Rickettsia typhi: Causes endemic (murine) typhus, transmitted by fleas, not lice. Rash is less common and nonspecific; not typically associated with epidemic outbreaks.

 

Option D. Rickettsia akari: Agent of rickettsialpox, transmitted by mites; causes vesicular rash and eschar, often confused with chickenpox, and lacks lice association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickettsia prowazekii causes epidemic typhus, transmitted by body lice, and presents with fever and a rash that spares the palms and soles—commonly seen in overcrowded or military settings.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding hematological changes in normal pregnancy are true? 

 

  1. Pregnancy is considered a hypercoagulable state.
  2. Plasma fibrinogen levels decrease due to increased consumption.
  3. Platelet count may slightly decrease due to hemodilution and increased consumption, typically without adverse pregnancy outcomes.
  4. There is an increase in plasma levels of clotting factors I, II, VII, VIII, IX, and X.
  5. Clotting time is significantly prolonged in the third trimester.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, and 4 only

 

Statement 1 is true: Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state, an adaptive change to reduce bleeding during delivery.

 

Statement 3 is true: Mild thrombocytopenia (gestational thrombocytopenia) can occur due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption, usually seen in the third trimester and does not adversely affect pregnancy.

 

Statement 4 is true: There is an increase in plasma levels of clotting factors I, II, VII, VIII, IX, and X.

 

Note – Factor XI and XIII actually decrease during pregnancy. 

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2 is false: Fibrinogen levels actually increase by about 50% (from 200–400 mg/dL to 300–600 mg/dL).

 

Statement 5 is false: Clotting time remains unaffected during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state, marked by increased fibrinogen and several clotting factors, with mild thrombocytopenia in late pregnancy due to hemodilution and platelet consumption. Clotting time remains unchanged.

questions.text: Match the following types of delusions with their definitions:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-C

 

  1. Delusion of persecution – D. Belief that one is being conspired against: This is the most common type of delusion in paranoid schizophrenia, where the person believes that others are plotting harm against them.
  2. Delusion of grandeur – B. Belief that one has special powers: The person believes they are famous, powerful, or possess extraordinary abilities, commonly seen in manic episodes.
  3. Delusion of reference – A. Belief that external events are referring to oneself: The individual believes that newspapers, TV shows, or random comments are specifically about them.
  4. Nihilistic delusion – C. Belief that oneself or the world does not exist: A delusion often associated with severe depression or psychosis, particularly Cotard syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delusion of persecution: The belief that one is being harmed, harassed, or conspired against — classic in paranoid schizophrenia.
  • Delusion of grandeur: The belief that one possesses extraordinary powers, wealth, or fame — commonly seen in mania.
  • Delusion of reference: Believing that neutral events (like TV shows or newspaper articles) have a special and personal meaning — often observed in schizophrenia.
  • Nihilistic delusion: The false belief that oneself, others, or the world does not exist — seen in severe depressive states or Cotard syndrome.

choices.text: If she belongs to a tribal area where education criteria are relaxed
If she completes a special government-sponsored bridge training course
If she has previous experience working as an Anganwadi worker
If she is nominated by the Panchayat based on community support

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman from a rural community is interested in becoming an ASHA worker. She has completed formal education up to 8th grade and is fluent in the local language. However, she does not meet the standard eligibility criteria. Under which of the following conditions can she still be selected as an ASHA worker?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If she belongs to a tribal area where education criteria are relaxed

 

According to ASHA worker selection criteria, the minimum education requirement is a 10th-grade education, but this requirement is relaxed for tribal/ remote/ underserved areas, allowing selection based on community need rather than formal education.


Other Options:

 

Option B. If she completes a special government-sponsored bridge training course: Incorrect, no bridge training exists to waive formal education criteria. Training is only provided post-selection.

 

Option C. If she has previous experience working as an Anganwadi worker: Incorrect, Previous Anganwadi work does not waive educational requirements.

 

Option D. If she is nominated by the Panchayat based on community support: Incorrect, Panchayat approval is essential, but it cannot override national eligibility guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASHA worker selection requires a minimum 10th-grade education, but this is relaxed for tribal areas where literacy levels are lower.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with longstanding seropositive rheumatoid arthritis presents with progressive dyspnea and mild pleuritic chest pain. He denies fever or cough. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral pleural effusions. Thoracentesis yields a cloudy, milky-appearing fluid. Pleural fluid analysis shows  protein 4.5 g/dL, cholesterol 280 mg/dL, triglycerides 35 mg/dL, and presence of cholesterol crystals. Gram stain and culture are negative, and there is no neutrophilic predominance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pseudochylothorax

 

  • This patient has pseudochylothorax, a rare chronic exudative pleural effusion seen in longstanding inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and tuberculosis.
  • The milky appearance of fluid is due to high cholesterol content, not triglycerides.
  • Cholesterol crystals are diagnostic.
  • Pseudochylothorax occurs due to chronic pleural inflammation and fibrosis, leading to degeneration of cellular lipids over time.
  • Triglyceride levels are usually <110 mg/dL, helping to differentiate from chylothorax.
  • Unlike empyema, fluid is not purulent, and cultures are negative.
  • TB can also cause pseudochylothorax, but typically with unilateral effusion and more constitutional symptoms.

 

Comparison of Milky Pleural Effusions:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Empyema: Purulent, foul-smelling fluid with high neutrophils and often positive cultures; not seen here.

 

Option C. Chylothorax: Triglyceride-rich effusion (>110 mg/dL), commonly due to thoracic duct injury or malignancy.

 

Option D. Tuberculous pleuritis: May cause chronic effusion or pseudochyle but usually lymphocytic, not milky initially.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudochylothorax is a chronic cholesterol-rich exudative pleural effusion, typically seen in rheumatoid arthritis or tuberculosis, characterized by high cholesterol, low triglycerides, and cholesterol crystals in pleural fluid.

choices.text: Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the small intestine
Inhibition of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein
Activation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α)

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of ezetimibe in the treatment of hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the small intestine

 

  • Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor. It acts on the Niemann-Pick C1-like 1 (NPC1L1) transporter located in the brush border of the small intestine, blocking the absorption of dietary and biliary cholesterol.
    • This leads to reduced delivery of cholesterol to the liver, upregulation of hepatic LDL receptors, and increased clearance of LDL cholesterol from the blood.
    • It is often used as adjunct therapy with statins to further lower LDL levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase: This is the mechanism of statins, not ezetimibe. Statins inhibit cholesterol synthesis, whereas ezetimibe inhibits absorption.

 

Option C. Inhibition of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP): This describes the action of lomitapide, used in familial hypercholesterolemia, not ezetimibe.

 

Option D. Activation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α): This is the mechanism of fibrates, which are used to treat hypertriglyceridemia, not primarily for LDL lowering like ezetimibe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ezetimibe lowers LDL cholesterol by inhibiting cholesterol absorption in the small intestine via NPC1L1 transporters. It is often used in combination with statins for enhanced lipid-lowering efficacy.

choices.text: Stop leprosy drugs and add steroids
Continue anti-leprosy drugs and add steroids

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant lady on leprosy treatment has type 2 Lepra reaction. Next line of management is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue anti-leprosy drugs and add steroids

 

Type 2 Lepra reaction (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum or ENL) is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction characterized by immune complex deposition. It occurs in lepromatous or borderline lepromatous leprosy.

 

  • In pregnancy, thalidomide is absolutely contraindicated due to its well-known teratogenic effects.
  • The treatment involves continuing the anti-leprosy multidrug therapy (MDT) (Rifampicin, Dapsone, Clofazimine) as stopping it may worsen disease control.
  • Systemic corticosteroids (like prednisolone) are the drug of choice for controlling inflammation and systemic symptoms of ENL in pregnant patients.

     

Other Options:


Option A. Stop leprosy drugs and add steroids: Incorrect, Stopping MDT is not recommended even during lepra reactions, unless there's a specific contraindication. Continuation is essential to prevent resistance and relapse.


Option B. Thalidomide: Contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenicity (phocomelia and other severe birth defects). Although thalidomide is highly effective for ENL, it is only used in non-pregnant patients.


Option C. Thalidomide + steroids: Also contraindicated in pregnancy because thalidomide should not be used under any circumstance in pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with Type 2 Lepra reaction, the correct approach is to continue anti-leprosy treatment and add corticosteroids. Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy, and anti-leprosy therapy should never be stopped during a lepra reaction.

 

  • Treatment of Type 1 Lepra reaction: Prednisolone 
  • Treatment for type 2 lepra reaction: 
    • For Mild cases – Antipyretic analgesics (Aspirin) 
    • For Severe cases – Prednisolone 
    • For steroid withdrawal symptoms - Clofazimine

questions.text: A 74-year-old man from Coimbatore is admitted for community-acquired pneumonia and has been receiving intravenous ceftriaxone for 6 days. He now develops watery, foul-smelling diarrhea associated with mild cramping and generalized fatigue. Vitals: T 99.8°F, HR 94/min, BP 116/72 mmHg. He is not hypotensive and has no abdominal distension. Labs reveal WBC 13,800/mm³ and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.0). Colonoscopy shows the following lesions. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral vancomycin

 

  • Colonoscopy and clinical picture is very much suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis caused by C. difficile infection (CDI). 
  • This patient has nonfulminant CDI (mild-moderate), as there is no shock, ileus, or megacolon, and his WBC <15,000 and creatinine <1.5 mg/dL rise from baseline.
  • Oral vancomycin (125 mg QID for 10 days) is the first-line treatment for initial CDI episodes across all severities as per current guidelines.
  • While fidaxomicin is preferred when available due to lower recurrence rates, oral vancomycin remains the most widely used and guideline-approved option in many settings.
  • IV vancomycin has no therapeutic role in CDI since it does not penetrate the colonic lumen.
  • Oral metronidazole is now considered inferior and is not recommended as first-line, particularly in elderly or hospitalized patients.
  • For fulminant CDI (hypotension, ileus, or megacolon), high-dose oral vancomycin plus IV metronidazole is used, and rectal vancomycin may be added in ileus.

 

Assessment of CDI Severity:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. IV metronidazole: Used in fulminant CDI, especially when ileus is present; not monotherapy in nonsevere cases.

 

Option C. Oral metronidazole: Previously first-line; now inferior efficacy, especially in elderly or hospitalized patients.

 

Option D. IV vancomycin: Ineffective in CDI as it does not reach the colonic lumen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nonfulminant Clostridioides difficile infection, oral vancomycin is the current first-line treatment over metronidazole, especially in elderly or hospitalized patients. Route and severity stratification guide therapy; IV vancomycin has no role in treating CDI.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male with treatment-resistant focal seizures is prescribed a newer-generation antiepileptic drug. The chosen medication exerts its anticonvulsant effect by antagonizing AMPA receptors. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  Perampanel

 

  • Perampanel is a newer-generation antiepileptic drug that acts as a selective, non-competitive antagonist of the AMPA receptor, a subtype of the ionotropic glutamate receptor.
  • By inhibiting AMPA receptors, Perampanel dampens excitatory neurotransmission, which helps reduce seizure activity in focal and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.
  • AMPA receptor antagonism represents a unique mechanism of action compared to many older antiepileptic drugs, and this glutamatergic inhibition helps suppress neuronal hyperexcitability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregabalin:  Pregabalin binds to the alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, not AMPA receptors. It reduces neurotransmitter release, particularly glutamate, norepinephrine, and substance P, but through a presynaptic calcium modulation mechanism.

 

Option C. Lacosamide: Lacosamide enhances the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, stabilizing hyperexcitable neuronal membranes. It does not interact with AMPA receptors.

 

Option D. Valproate: Valproate has multiple mechanisms, including increasing GABA levels, blocking sodium channels, and modulating T-type calcium channels, but it does not inhibit AMPA receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perampanel is an antiepileptic drug that acts by antagonizing AMPA receptors, thereby reducing excitatory glutamatergic transmission in seizure disorders.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue and early satiety. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory findings show pancytopenia. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, and electron microscopy of one of the abnormal cells is shown in the image. Which of the following best identifies the cell shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

The image depicts a "hairy cell", which is a neoplastic B cell characterized by:

 

  • Irregular cytoplasmic projections seen best on electron microscopy
  • Associated with Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL)
  • Clinical features include:
    • Pancytopenia
    • Splenomegaly (due to red pulp infiltration)
    • "Dry tap" on bone marrow aspiration (due to marrow fibrosis)
    • Honey comb appearance and Fried egg appearance on bone marrow biopsy (due to perinuclear halo)
    • High risk of development of atypical mycobacterial infections
    • Involvement of red pulp of spleen
  • Stains positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)

 

Hairy cells classically show “hair-like” cytoplasmic extensions, as seen in this EM image, distinguishing them from other abnormal blood cells.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Neutrophil with toxic granulations: Toxic granulations are coarse, dark granules in neutrophils seen during severe infections or inflammation. They do not appear as cytoplasmic projections and would not explain the splenomegaly or pancytopenia.

 

Option C. Target cell: Target cells are erythrocytes with a central area of staining surrounded by a ring of pallor, giving a bullseye appearance. These are seen in liver disease, thalassemia, and postsplenectomy—not in leukemias. They are identified on peripheral smear, not electron microscopy.

 

Option D. Lipid-laden macrophage: This describes Gaucher cells, seen in Gaucher disease, a lysosomal storage disorder. These cells have a “crumpled tissue paper” cytoplasm and are not seen with hairy projections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cell leukemia is a B-cell neoplasm characterized by cytoplasmic projections visible on electron microscopy. It presents with splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and a “dry tap” on bone marrow aspiration due to marrow fibrosis.

choices.text: Increase the magnesium sulfate infusion rate
Intubate and start mechanical ventilation immediately

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida woman at 34 weeks gestation with preeclampsia with severe features is receiving intravenous magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. After 8 hours of infusion, the nurse reports that the patient appears drowsy, has a respiratory rate of 10/min, and no elicitable patellar reflexes. Her urine output is 20 mL/hour. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer intravenous calcium gluconate

 

The patient is exhibiting signs of magnesium sulfate toxicity, which include:

 

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs): First clinical sign, typically at serum magnesium levels of 7–10 mEq/L
  • Respiratory depression: Occurs at levels 10–12 mEq/L
  • Respiratory arrest or cardiac arrest: Occurs at levels >12 mEq/L and >25 mEq/L, respectively

 

Toxicity is more likely when urine output is decreased, as magnesium is excreted renally.

 

Management includes:

 

  • First step should be to confirm magnesium toxicity through serum magnesium level
  • Immediate discontinuation of magnesium sulfate
  • Administration of calcium gluconate (1 g IV), which antagonizes magnesium’s effects and reverses neuromuscular and respiratory depression

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the magnesium sulfate infusion rate:  Increasing the MgSO₄ dose would worsen the toxicity.

 

Option C. Administer intravenous furosemide: Furosemide is not the first-line treatment; it may be used in cases of fluid overload, not MgSO₄ toxicity.

 

Option D. D. Intubate and start mechanical ventilation immediately: Intubation is considered if the patient is in respiratory arrest; however, this patient still has respiratory effort and should first receive calcium gluconate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of deep tendon reflexes is the earliest clinical sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity. Calcium gluconate is the antidote and should be administered immediately in symptomatic cases, along with stopping MgSO₄ infusion.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Muscles of Mastication and Their Actions:

 

Column A (Muscles)

 

  1. Temporalis
  2. Masseter
  3. Lateral pterygoid
  4. Medial pterygoid

 

Column B (Action on Mandible)

 

  1. Elevation and Retraction (posterior fibers)
  2. Depression and Unilateral Jaw Swinging
  3. Elevation and Protrusion (superficial fibers)
  4. Elevation and Protrusion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-A, 2-C, 3-B, 4-D

 

  • Temporalis (1-A): Elevates the mandible; posterior fibers retract the mandible.
  • Masseter (2-C): Elevates the mandible and the superficial fibers assist in protrusion.
  • Lateral Pterygoid (3-B): Only muscle of mastication that causes depression of the mandible and swings the jaw side-to-side unilaterally.
  • Medial Pterygoid (4-D): Helps elevate the mandible and also contributes to protrusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • All muscles of mastication are supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3). 
  • Their coordinated actions help in complex jaw movements like chewing, biting, and grinding.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

Column A (Oxygen Delivery Devices)

 

  1. Nasal Cannula
  2. Simple Face Mask
  3. Venturi Mask
  4. Non-Rebreather Mask
  5. High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC)


Column B (Maximum FiO₂ Delivered)

 

  1. Up to 40%
  2. Up to 50-60%
  3. Up to 80%
  4. Up to 100%
  5. Up to 60%
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-A, 2-B, 3-E, 4-C, 5-D

 

1 – A: Nasal cannulae deliver FiO₂ ranging from 24-40%, with a maximum FiO₂ of up to 40% at a flow rate of 1-5 L/min, making them suitable for patients requiring low-flow oxygen therapy. 

 

2 – B: Simple face masks provide an FiO₂ of 40-60%, with a maximum FiO₂ of up to 50-60% at 6-10 L/min, commonly used in moderate hypoxia. 

 

3 – E: Venturi masks allow for precise FiO₂ titration, ranging from 24-60%, with a maximum FiO₂ of up to 60%, making them ideal for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who require controlled oxygenation. 

 

4 – C: Non-rebreather masks (NRBMs) provide high FiO₂ levels (60-100%), with a maximum FiO₂ of up to 80%, using a reservoir bag and high-flow oxygen, making them useful in severe hypoxia and critical care settings. 

 

5 – D: High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can deliver humidified and heated oxygen at 30-60 L/min, achieving a maximum FiO₂ of up to 100%, making it an effective alternative to non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in respiratory distress.

 

Educational objective:

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 1-month history of chronic cough, progressive shortness of breath, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral upper lobe infiltrates with cavitary lesions. Sputum culture grown on Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium yields colonies that test positive for MPT64 antigen. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

This patient presents with classic signs of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB), including:

 

  • Chronic cough
  • Weight loss
  • Night sweats
  • Cavitary lesions in the upper lobes on imaging

 

The culture result grown on Lowenstein-Jensen medium and testing positive for MPT64 antigen confirms that the causative organism belongs to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex (MTBC).

 

  • MPT64 is a specific protein antigen secreted by MTBC organisms, including M. tuberculosis and M. bovis.
  • It is commonly used in rapid diagnostic tests to distinguish MTBC from non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

 

Among the MTBC group, Mycobacterium tuberculosis is by far the most common cause of pulmonary TB, especially in immunocompetent individuals with typical clinical and radiographic features as seen in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium kansasii: A non-tuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) that can mimic TB in the lungs, but it does not produce MPT64 antigen. Therefore, it can be ruled out by the antigen result.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium leprae: Causes leprosy, a chronic disease affecting the skin and peripheral nerves, not the lungs. It is not cultured on LJ medium and does not produce MPT64 antigen.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC): A group of NTMs more commonly seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS). MAC does not express MPT64 antigen and usually does not produce cavitary lesions in the upper lobes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Detection of MPT64 antigen confirms infection with the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex. Among its members, Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the most common cause of pulmonary TB, particularly in immunocompetent patients with typical cavitary lung lesions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis and signs of hypovolemic shock, including hypotension and tachycardia. Immediate stabilization with IV fluids, Terlipressin, and blood transfusion is initiated. What is the next immediate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Variceal banding

 

  • Acute variceal bleeding is a life-threatening complication of portal hypertension, often seen in cirrhotic patients. 
  • The immediate priority in management is hemodynamic stabilization (IV fluids, blood transfusion, correction of coagulopathy) followed by definitive control of bleeding.
    • Endoscopic variceal band ligation (EVL) is the first-line treatment for active esophageal variceal bleeding. It involves placing elastic bands around the varices to induce thrombosis and prevent further hemorrhage.
    • Pharmacologic therapy with vasoactive drugs (e.g., octreotide, terlipressin) is also initiated to reduce portal pressure and decrease variceal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TIPSS (Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt): This is a second-line therapy for patients with refractory variceal bleeding despite band ligation and vasoactive therapy. It is not an immediate first-step intervention in acute bleeding.

 

Option C. Transabdominal gastroesophageal devascularization: This is a surgical option used for refractory variceal bleeding in patients who are not candidates for TIPSS. It is not a first-line treatment in acute management.

 

Option D. Balloon tamponade (e.g., Sengstaken-Blakemore tube): This is a temporary measure used only in massive bleeding when endoscopic therapy is not immediately available. However, it carries risks of complications like esophageal rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with massive hematemesis due to esophageal varices, the next immediate step in management is endoscopic variceal banding to control active bleeding. 
  • Pharmacologic therapy with vasoactive agents (e.g., octreotide) should be started simultaneously. 
  • TIPSS and surgical options are reserved for refractory cases, while balloon tamponade is used only as a bridge in uncontrolled bleeding.

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing acetylcholine release

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe generalized muscle spasms and opisthotonos (arching of the back), several days after sustaining a puncture wound to the foot while working outdoors. He had not received tetanus immunization in over 15 years. The person shows a classic hyperextended posture consistent with tetanic spasms. The toxin responsible for this condition acts through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

 

  • The clinical picture is consistent with tetanus, caused by Clostridium tetani.
  • The responsible neurotoxin, tetanospasmin, reaches the central nervous system through retrograde axonal transport.
  • It cleaves synaptobrevin, a SNARE protein required for neurotransmitter release from inhibitory interneurons, leading to presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine.
  • This disinhibition of motor neurons causes the hallmark muscle rigidity and spasms (e.g., lockjaw, opisthotonos).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postsynaptic blockade of acetylcholine receptors: This describes the mechanism of botulinum toxin at the neuromuscular junction, but tetanus affects inhibitory neurons in the CNS, not postsynaptic Ach receptors.

 

Option C. Inhibition of glycine receptor expression: This is not the mechanism of tetanospasmin. The toxin prevents glycine release, not receptor expression.

 

Option D. Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing acetylcholine release: This is the mechanism of botulinum toxin, which blocks Ach release at the neuromuscular junction, causing flaccid paralysis—not the spastic paralysis seen in tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanospasmin inhibits the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA and glycine) by cleaving SNARE proteins in interneurons, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and spastic paralysis.

choices.text: Review at 12 weeks for early anomaly scan
Detailed counseling about potential fetal risks and management options

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, currently 9 weeks pregnant, presents with a 4-day history of low-grade fever and a maculopapular rash that began on her face and has spread downward to her trunk and extremities. She also complains of mild arthralgias. She has no documented history of MMR vaccination or prior rubella infection. On examination, she is febrile (38.3°C), and there is postauricular lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests confirm a positive rubella-specific IgM. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Detailed counseling about potential fetal risks and management options

 

Rubella infection during the first trimester poses a significant risk for the fetus, particularly for congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) in 90% of cases. CRS commonly includes:

 

  • Congenital cataracts
  • Congenital heart defects (especially PDA)
  • Sensorineural hearing loss

 

There is no antiviral treatment or curative intervention for rubella in pregnancy. Therefore, the primary management includes:

 

  • Thorough counseling about the high risk of fetal infection and associated complications
  • Discussing the option of continuing vs terminating the pregnancy based on the patient’s values and preferences
  • Optionally, rubella avidity testing can help determine whether infection is recent or remote, but it does not change the need for counseling

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administration of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG): IVIG is not effective in reducing fetal transmission or preventing CRS.

 

Option B. Isolation and symptomatic treatment only: Maternal isolation may help prevent spread to others but is not a management strategy for the fetal risk or clinical decision-making.

 

Option C. Review at 12 weeks for early anomaly scan: While an early anomaly scan is important and part of follow-up, waiting without immediate counseling is inappropriate. The first and immediate next step should be counseling about fetal risks based on the confirmed rubella infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rubella infection in early pregnancy requires comprehensive counseling regarding the high risk of congenital rubella syndrome, rather than immediate treatment or termination. The management is centered on informed decision-making rather than interventions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old healthcare worker presents for follow-up after a documented needle-stick injury involving a patient later found to be positive for hepatitis B virus (HBV). His serological results are being monitored over time to assess for acute infection, resolution, or chronicity. Which of the following markers is expected to be detectable regardless of whether the patient completely recovers or progresses to chronic HBV infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-HBc

 

  • Anti-HBc (antibody to hepatitis B core antigen) is produced in both acute and chronic HBV infections and also remains detectable after recovery.
  • It reflects exposure to the actual virus, as it is not present in vaccinated individuals (since the vaccine contains only HBsAg).
  • IgM anti-HBc indicates acute infection, while IgG anti-HBc persists for life and is seen in both chronic and resolved infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HBV DNA: Indicates active viral replication and is present only during active infection, whether acute or chronic. It disappears after recovery.

 

Option C. Anti-HBs: Appears only after recovery or vaccination. It is absent in chronic infection where the virus persists.

 

Option D. Core antigen (HBcAg): Not detectable in serum; it is found only within infected hepatocytes and is not used as a serum marker in clinical practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBc antibodies are present in all individuals with past or current HBV infection, regardless of recovery or progression to chronic hepatitis B.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding cardiovascular examination findings in pregnancy are correct? 

 

  1. The apex beat is displaced to the 4th intercostal space and lies 2.5 cm medial to the midclavicular line.
  2. A physiological systolic murmur may be heard at the apical or pulmonary area due to increased blood volume.
  3. A mammary murmur can be heard in the 2nd and 3rd left intercostal spaces due to increased internal mammary blood flow.
  4. An S3 heart sound may be present due to rapid diastolic ventricular filling.
  5. ECG may show left axis deviation but is otherwise typically normal.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Statements 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

 

Statement 2: Correct – A systolic murmur at the apical or pulmonary area is common due to increased blood flow and cardiac output.

 

Statement 3: Correct – A mammary murmur may be auscultated in the left 2nd and 3rd intercostal spaces due to increased flow through internal mammary arteries.

 

Statement 4: Correct – An S3 may be heard due to rapid ventricular filling during diastole, which is a normal physiological change.

 

Statement 5: Correct – ECG is usually normal but left axis deviation may be seen due to anatomical displacement of the heart.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 1: Incorrect – The apex beat shifts outwards (laterally) and upwards during pregnancy due to diaphragm elevation; it is located 2.5 cm lateral to the midclavicular line, not medial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During pregnancy, cardiovascular adaptations include lateral displacement of the heart, increased cardiac output, and blood volume, often manifesting as benign auscultatory findings like systolic murmurs, mammary murmurs, and S3. ECG changes such as left axis deviation may be observed but are generally benign.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man from Surat with a history of diabetes and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden severe diffuse abdominal pain, multiple episodes of vomiting, and mild generalized abdominal tenderness. BP is 110/70 mmHg, HR is 36/min, and SpO₂ is 97% on room air. Serum lactate is markedly elevated at 6.1 mmol/L. ECG is shown. On examination, his abdomen is soft without guarding or rebound tenderness. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT Angiography

 

  • This is a classic presentation of acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI), particularly of embolic origin given the history of atrial fibrillation and sudden-onset abdominal pain.
  • The hallmark of AMI is pain out of proportion to physical examination findings; despite severe pain, the abdomen remains soft early in the disease course.
  • Elevated lactate indicates tissue ischemia and metabolic acidosis, further supporting the diagnosis.
  • CT angiography is the diagnostic test of choice to visualize arterial occlusion, guide revascularization decisions, and assess for bowel viability.
  • Immediate imaging is crucial as early identification, and intervention can prevent progression to bowel necrosis and death.
  • Surgery is reserved for patients with clinical signs of peritonitis or bowel gangrene.

 

Acute Mesenteric Ischemia vs Other Acute Abdomen

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency laparotomy: Reserved for patients with signs of peritonitis such as guarding, rigidity, or rebound tenderness.

 

Option B. IV broad-spectrum antibiotics: Important adjunctive therapy but not the initial diagnostic step; diagnosis must first be confirmed.

 

Option D. Colonoscopy: Contraindicated due to the high risk of perforation in ischemic and necrotic bowel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with atrial fibrillation and sudden severe abdominal pain disproportionate to examination findings, acute mesenteric ischemia must be suspected, and CT angiography is the essential first diagnostic step to confirm vascular occlusion and guide management.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress, audible wheezing, and use of accessory muscles. She is unable to speak in full sentences. Vital signs show tachypnea, tachycardia, and an oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. She is diagnosed with status asthmaticus. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for initial administration via nebulization?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Formoterol plus budesonide

 

  • Status asthmaticus is a severe, life-threatening asthma exacerbation that requires immediate treatment to reverse airway obstruction. The initial management includes:
    • Rapid-acting bronchodilators (inhaled β₂-agonists)
    • Systemic corticosteroids
    • Oxygen supplementation
  • Formoterol is a long-acting β₂-agonist (LABA) with a rapid onset of action, unlike other LABAs (e.g., salmeterol). When combined with budesonide, an inhaled corticosteroid, the combination provides both immediate bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects.
  • This combination is now approved for as-needed and reliever therapy, especially in severe asthma, and can be administered via nebulization or metered-dose inhaler in acute settings. 
  • It allows for rapid relief with added anti-inflammatory action.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Montelukast:  A leukotriene receptor antagonist, used for maintenance therapy, not in acute or emergency settings. It is not administered via nebulization and has delayed onset of action.

 

Option C. Theophylline: A methylxanthine bronchodilator with a narrow therapeutic index and significant side effects. It is not used in acute asthma management due to limited efficacy and toxicity concerns, also this cannot be given trough inhalational route.

 

Option D. Hydrocortisone: While systemic corticosteroids are essential in status asthmaticus, they are not administered via nebulization. Hydrocortisone is given intravenously, and although important, bronchodilators are prioritized for immediate nebulized therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Formoterol (a fast-acting LABA) combined with budesonide (an inhaled corticosteroid) can be nebulized for rapid relief in status asthmaticus, offering both bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman undergoes renal function testing as part of a clinical research study. Her urine sample shows a high concentration of a test substance, and the goal is to determine the rate at which her kidneys clear this substance from plasma. Which of the following is the correct formula for calculating the renal clearance rate (Cₛ) of a substance?

 

  • Us​ = Urine concentration of the substance
  • V = Urine flow rate
  • Ps​ = Plasma concentration of the substance
questions.solution:
Ans. B)   

 

 

The renal clearance rate (Cₛ) is defined as the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time.

 

The correct formula is:

 

 

This equation allows the estimation of how effectively the kidneys are clearing a specific substance from the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:



The renal clearance of a substance is calculated using the formula

 

 

reflecting the efficiency of renal elimination and forming the basis of key renal function tests.

choices.text: Continue warfarin until the onset of labor
Switch to unfractionated heparin at 36 weeks gestation
Administer low-dose aspirin instead of warfarin

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman with a history of mechanical mitral valve replacement is being managed with anticoagulation therapy. She is currently 35 weeks pregnant and has been on warfarin since the end of the first trimester. She presents for a routine prenatal follow-up. Her INR is within the therapeutic range, and she has no signs of bleeding or thromboembolism. What is the most appropriate next step in her anticoagulation management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Switch to unfractionated heparin at 36 weeks gestation

 

In pregnant women on warfarin for mechanical valves or thromboembolic conditions:

 

  • Warfarin is teratogenic, particularly between 6–12 weeks gestation.
  • It is discontinued once pregnancy is confirmed (especially if dose >5 mg/day) and replaced with heparin (UFH or LMWH) until 12 weeks.
  • Warfarin may be resumed after 12 weeks and continued until 36 weeks.
  • At 36 weeks, warfarin is switched back to heparin due to its shorter half-life and ease of reversal at the time of delivery.
  • Heparin is then stopped just before delivery to reduce the risk of peripartum bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin until the onset of labor: Incorrect. Warfarin crosses the placenta and increases the risk of fetal bleeding, particularly intracranial hemorrhage during labor. Continuing warfarin beyond 36 weeks is not recommended because spontaneous labor can occur anytime near term.

 

Option C. Discontinue anticoagulation until delivery: Incorrect. This would leave the patient with a mechanical heart valve unprotected, leading to a high risk of valve thrombosis and maternal mortality. Anticoagulation must be maintained throughout pregnancy, including the peripartum period (with careful timing).

 

Option D. Administer low-dose aspirin instead of warfarin: Incorrect. Aspirin alone is insufficient for preventing thromboembolic events in patients with mechanical heart valves. It may be used adjunctively in certain high-risk cases, but never as a substitute for heparin or warfarin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women requiring long-term anticoagulation (e.g., for mechanical heart valves), warfarin should be stopped at 36 weeks gestation and replaced by heparin to allow safer peripartum management and minimize bleeding complications during delivery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. A coronal section of the brain is shown. Which of the following regions, when affected, is responsible for the observed neurotransmitter deficiency in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The area labelled B is the Substantia Nigra, located in the midbrain. It is responsible for the synthesis of dopamine, a key neurotransmitter involved in movement control. 

 

In Parkinson's disease, the neurons in the Substantia Nigra degenerate, leading to a deficiency in dopamine production, which causes the characteristic motor symptoms of the disease, such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This is the corpus callosum, involved in motor control but not directly linked to dopamine synthesis in Parkinson's disease.

 

Option C: This area is likely part of the pons, which has no direct connection to Parkinson's disease or dopamine synthesis.

 

Option D: This area points to the medulla oblongata, which is involved in autonomic functions, not the synthesis of dopamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Degeneration of the Substantia Nigra results in a dopamine deficit, which is the primary cause of the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason correctly explains the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason does not correctly explain the Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Assertion is false, but Reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): During head and neck surgeries, accidental injury to the internal jugular vein can result in venous air embolism, leading to a sudden drop in end-tidal CO₂ (etCO₂), hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias.
 

Reason (R): Venous air embolism occurs because positive intrathoracic pressure during inspiration forces air into the venous system, particularly in a head-up surgical position.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true, but Reason is false.

 

  • Assertion (True): Venous air embolism (VAE) is a well-known complication of neck surgeries, particularly when large veins like the internal jugular vein are injured. It can cause a sudden drop in etCO₂, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias due to air entering the venous system and traveling to the right heart and pulmonary circulation.

     
  • Reason (False): The mechanism described in the reason is incorrect. Air entry into the venous system does not occur due to positive intrathoracic pressure during inspiration. Instead, negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration creates a suction effect, pulling air into open veins. The head-up position lowers venous pressure, further increasing this risk.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is participating in a controlled metabolic study. Her oxygen consumption is measured at 300 mL/min, and her carbon dioxide output is recorded as 270 mL/min. What is the estimated respiratory quotient (RQ) in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.9
 

  • The Respiratory Quotient (RQ) is calculated using the formula:
  • RQ = CO₂ eliminated / O₂ consumed
  • Substituting the given values: RQ = 270 / 300 = 0.9

     
  • This RQ value suggests a mixed substrate metabolism, commonly seen with a balanced diet of carbohydrates and fats.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.7: Corresponds to fat metabolism; not applicable here as the CO₂/O₂ ratio is higher.


Option B. 0.8: Suggests protein metabolism, which would result from a lower CO₂ output relative to O₂.


Option D. 1.0: Represents pure carbohydrate metabolism, where CO₂ output equals O₂ consumption.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The respiratory quotient (RQ) is the ratio of carbon dioxide produced to oxygen consumed and helps identify the predominant metabolic fuel being utilized: 

 

  • carbohydrates (RQ = 1.0), fats (RQ = 0.7), proteins (RQ = 0.8). A value of 0.9 indicates a mixed fuel utilization.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding supine vena cava syndrome are correct? 

 

  1. The condition is caused by compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus, especially in the supine position.
  2. The aorta is more commonly compressed than the inferior vena cava in late pregnancy.
  3. Collateral venous circulation via the azygous and paravertebral veins usually compensates for vena cava compression.
  4. Symptoms may include hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope when collateral circulation fails.
  5. Supine vena cava syndrome is managed by placing the patient in a Trendelenburg position.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct

 

Statement 1: Correct – The inferior vena cava is compressed by the gravid uterus in the supine position, leading to reduced venous return.

 

Statement 3: Correct – Collateral circulation via azygous and paravertebral veins helps compensate for the reduced IVC flow.

 

Statement 4: Correct – Failure of collateral flow results in symptoms like hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2:  Incorrect – The aorta is relatively resistant to compression due to its muscular structure; the vena cava is more susceptible.

 

Statement 5:  Incorrect – Management involves left lateral positioning, not the Trendelenburg position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine vena cava syndrome is caused by gravid uterine compression of the inferior vena cava, especially in the supine position, leading to reduced venous return and symptoms such as hypotension and syncope. Management includes placing the patient in the lateral decubitus position to relieve compression.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding typical HRCT findings in fungal pneumonia are correct? 

 

  1. Cavitary lung lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities (halo sign) are commonly seen.
  2. The presence of Kerley B lines is a classic feature of fungal pneumonia.
  3. Hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark feature of invasive aspergillosis.
  4. The “air crescent sign” may appear in the healing phase of fungal pneumonia.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 4 only

 

Fungal pneumonia, particularly invasive aspergillosis, shows characteristic findings on high-resolution CT (HRCT):

 

Statement 1: Correct.


Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities, known as the halo sign, are a classic early finding in invasive fungal infections. The ground-glass halo represents hemorrhage around a fungal lesion.

 

Statement 4: Correct.


The air crescent sign, which represents retraction of necrotic lung tissue, is typically seen during the recovery phase of invasive aspergillosis. It appears as a crescent-shaped air collection in a pre-existing nodule or consolidation.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect.

 

Kerley B lines are linear opacities seen on imaging due to interlobular septal thickening, most often associated with pulmonary edema, lymphangitic carcinomatosis, or interstitial lung disease — not fungal pneumonia.

 

Statement 3: Incorrect.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy is not a hallmark of invasive aspergillosis or most fungal pneumonias. It is more commonly seen in tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, or lymphoproliferative disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The halo sign and air crescent sign are key high-resolution CT findings in fungal pneumonia, particularly invasive aspergillosis, while Kerley B lines and hilar lymphadenopathy are not characteristic.

questions.text: Injury of which of the following nerves causes drooping of the shoulder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

  • Drooping of the shoulder is caused by paralysis of the trapezius muscle, which is supplied by the spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI). 
  • The trapezius muscle originates from the external occipital protuberance and inserts into the lateral third of the clavicle. 
  • The spinal root of the accessory nerve (nerve B in the image) is responsible for innervating this muscle, and damage to this nerve leads to weakness or paralysis of the trapezius, causing the characteristic drooping of the shoulder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lesser occipital nerve: This nerve supplies the skin of the posterior scalp and has no role in innervating the trapezius muscle or affecting shoulder movement. It is not responsible for shoulder drooping.

 

Option C. Mastoid process: The mastoid process is a bony landmark on the temporal bone and does not innervate any muscles or have a role in shoulder movement.

 

Option D. Transverse cutaneous nerve of the neck: This nerve supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral neck. It is unrelated to the innervation of the trapezius muscle and does not contribute to shoulder movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Injury to the spinal accessory nerve, which innervates the trapezius muscle, leads to shoulder drooping. The nerve responsible is identified as B in the image.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is false, but R is true
A is true, but R is false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In Bruton’s disease, there is normal opsonization.

 

Reason (R): Bruton’s disease is an inherited immunodeficiency characterized by a deficiency of B lymphocytes.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is false, but R is true

 

  • Assertion: "In Bruton’s disease, there is normal opsonization" → False. Opsonization is impaired in Bruton’s disease because it requires antibodies, especially IgG, which coat pathogens and enhance phagocytosis. Since Bruton’s patients have absent or severely reduced B cells, they lack immunoglobulins, resulting in defective opsonization.
  • Reason: "Bruton’s disease is an inherited immunodeficiency characterized by a deficiency of B lymphocytes." → True. Bruton’s disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene. This blocks B cell maturation, leading to very low or absent peripheral B cells and immunoglobulins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bruton’s disease (X-linked agammaglobulinemia) leads to defective humoral immunity due to absent B cells and immunoglobulins, resulting in impaired opsonization and susceptibility to encapsulated bacterial infections.

choices.text: It cannot be used for complex, multidimensional problems requiring dynamic decision-making
It fails to eliminate personal bias among participating experts
It allows uncontrolled discussions, leading to dominance by strong personalities
It forces consensus, eliminating diverse perspectives from consideration

questions.text: Which of the following is the most significant limitation of the Delphi Method in clinical decision-making?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It cannot be used for complex, multidimensional problems requiring dynamic decision-making

 

  • The Delphi method is best suited for answering a single-dimension, well-defined question (e.g., determining best guidelines for a particular clinical practice).
  • It is not suitable for complex, multifactorial problems that require real-time dynamic decision-making, such as emergent surgical procedures.


Other Options:


Option B. It fails to eliminate personal bias among participating experts: Incorrect, While Delphi reduces bias, no method can eliminate it completely.


Option C. It allows uncontrolled discussions, leading to dominance by strong personalities: Incorrect, Delphi controls discussions through structured questionnaires, preventing dominance by individuals.


Option D. It forces consensus, eliminating diverse perspectives from consideration: Incorrect, it seeks consensus but does not necessarily eliminate diversity of thought.


Educational Objective:

 

The Delphi method is effective for structured, single-dimension decision-making but is limited in addressing complex, real-time, multidimensional problems.

questions.text:
A patient with suspected brucellosis has repeatedly negative results on the Standard Agglutination Test (SAT), despite high clinical suspicion. Which of the following statements regarding possible causes of false-negative SAT results is incorrect? 

 

  1. The prozone phenomenon occurs due to an excess of antigens in the patient's serum.
  2. Blocking antibodies like IgG or IgA can interfere with visible agglutination.
  3. Non-agglutinating antibodies may prevent detection of a true positive case.
  4. Prozone phenomenon can lead to underestimation of antibody levels.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1

 

1. The prozone phenomenon occurs due to an excess of antigens in the patient's serum: This statement is incorrect. The prozone phenomenon results from an excess of antibodies, not antigens, in the patient's serum. When there is a high concentration of antibodies, they may interfere with lattice formation needed for visible agglutination, leading to a false-negative result in tests like SAT. Thus, the claim that the prozone effect is due to excess antigen is false.

 

Correct Statements:

 

2. Blocking antibodies like IgG or IgA can interfere with visible agglutination: Correct. Non-agglutinating antibodies such as IgG or IgA can bind antigens without causing the cross-linking necessary for visible clumping. These are sometimes referred to as blocking antibodies and can mask a true positive result, producing a false-negative SAT.

 

3. Non-agglutinating antibodies may prevent detection of a true positive case: Correct. Non-agglutinating antibodies like certain forms of IgG or IgA bind without causing agglutination, thus preventing the appearance of a positive reaction in the SAT, despite the presence of infection.

 

4. Prozone phenomenon can lead to underestimation of antibody levels: Correct. In the prozone effect, the excess antibodies interfere with agglutination, and the test may falsely appear negative or indicate low titers, leading to underestimation of antibody levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

False-negative Standard Agglutination Tests (SAT) may occur due to the prozone phenomenon caused by excess antibodies or the presence of non-agglutinating/blocking IgG or IgA antibodies.

questions.text: A 10-day-old neonate is brought in with persistent vomiting, jaundice, and poor feeding. The parents mention that the symptoms began shortly after introducing breast milk. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly and bilateral lens opacities. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated liver transaminases, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and hypoglycemia. Urinalysis is positive for reducing substances, but glucose is not detected. Based on the likely diagnosis, which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

  • The clinical presentation is classic for classic galactosemia, a life-threatening metabolic disorder presenting in the neonatal period with vomiting, jaundice, hepatomegaly, cataracts, and hypoglycemia, often shortly after the ingestion of breast milk or formula (which contains lactose).
  • The underlying cause is a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT), which impairs the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to UDP-galactose in the Leloir pathway. As a result, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates, leading to liver dysfunction, renal damage, and neurotoxicity.
  • The finding of urinary reducing substances in the absence of glucosuria is key to diagnosing a disorder of galactose metabolism. Prompt diagnosis and removal of galactose/lactose from the diet can prevent irreversible damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldolase B: Deficiency of aldolase B causes hereditary fructose intolerance, which presents after ingestion of fructose-containing foods. It is associated with hypoglycemia, vomiting, and hepatomegaly, but not cataracts or positive reducing substances in the urine from birth.

 

Option C. Galactokinase: Deficiency causes a milder form of galactosemia, usually limited to the development of cataracts due to accumulation of galactitol, but without hepatomegaly, vomiting, or hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Fructokinase: Deficiency results in essential fructosuria, a benign condition causing fructose to spill into the urine. It is asymptomatic and unrelated to the neonatal presentation seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to accumulation of toxic galactose metabolites. Early signs include vomiting, jaundice, hepatomegaly, cataracts, and positive urinary reducing substances.

choices.text: The toxicology expert’s testimony is inadmissible because they did not have first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition at the time of death.
The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.
The forensic expert’s testimony is admissible only if it can be corroborated by a common witness who had first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition.

questions.text: In a case of death due to alleged poisoning, the prosecution presents a toxicology expert who testifies that the victim’s body had toxic substance based on the analysis of the stomach contents. The defence argues that the expert’s testimony should be inadmissible as toxicology expert neither examined the victim while he was alive, nor he conducted the autopsy himself. Which of the below is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.

 

  • Under the Indian Evidence Act (Section 45) and general legal principles applicable in most jurisdictions, expert opinions are admissible in court when the matter involves scientific, technical, or specialized knowledge. 
  • The law specifically allows for expert testimony even if the expert did not directly examine the victim, as long as their opinion is based on valid scientific analysis, such as laboratory examination of bodily specimens (in this case, stomach contents).
