  • In expert evidence witness can be of 3 types: Expert evidence (technical expertise), Common witness (first hand knowledge) and Hostile witness.
  • The expert's role is not to testify on direct facts but to interpret findings based on scientific knowledge. Hence, the toxicologist’s report and opinion about the presence of toxic substances are legally admissible despite the absence of direct involvement in the autopsy or victim’s treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The toxicology expert’s testimony is inadmissible because they did not have first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition at the time of death: Incorrect, The law does not require first-hand knowledge for an expert’s opinion to be admissible. The expert's admissibility hinges on their technical expertise and the scientific basis of their conclusion, not on personal observation of the victim.

 

Option C. The forensic expert’s testimony is admissible only if it can be corroborated by a common witness who had first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition: Incorrect, Expert evidence stands on its own and does not require corroboration by a non-expert or common witness. While corroborative evidence may strengthen the case, it is not a legal requirement for admissibility.

 

Option D. Both A and C: Incorrect, for the reasons above. Neither A nor C is correct individually, so both cannot be correct together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Expert testimony is admissible in court even if the expert did not have first-hand knowledge of the victim, as long as it is based on scientific analysis within their expertise.

questions.text: The genetic code is degenerate, meaning that most amino acids are encoded by more than one codon. This degeneracy often allows silent mutations (point mutations that do not change the amino acid) to occur without affecting the protein function. However some amino acids are coded by a single unique codon, and any mutation in that codon is more likely to result in a change in protein synthesis. Which of the following amino acids is coded by only one codon and thus does not exhibit degeneracy in the genetic code?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Methionine

 

  • Methionine (AUG) is the only amino acid (besides tryptophan) that is coded by a single codon—AUG—which also serves as the start codon in mRNA translation. Therefore, methionine does not show degeneracy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serine, B. Valine and C. Alanine: Are each encoded by multiple codons, illustrating the degeneracy of the genetic code, which provides a buffer against some mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methionine is coded exclusively by a single codon (AUG), which also serves as the universal start codon in protein synthesis. 
  • Unlike most amino acids that have multiple codons (degeneracy), methionine’s lack of codon redundancy means mutations affecting AUG are more likely to disrupt protein initiation or alter protein function.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a known history of depression and recent upper respiratory tract infection is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed syncopal episode at home. She had been started on oral azithromycin three days ago and has been on long-term amitriptyline therapy. On arrival, her BP is 86/58 mmHg, HR is irregular at 130/min, and she appears confused. Shortly after, she loses consciousness Bedside ECG is taken and shown below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defibrillation

 

  • This patient is experiencing torsades de pointes (TdP), a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QT prolongation, secondary to combined azithromycin and tricyclic antidepressant use.
  • The clinical presentation of syncope and hypotension with polymorphic VT (irregular wide complex tachycardia) on ECG mandates immediate unsynchronized defibrillation according to ACLS protocols.
  • Magnesium sulfate is the first-line treatment in stable TdP (conscious, perfusing patients) but not appropriate when the patient is unstable.
  • The presence of prolonged QT and polymorphic VT further supports the diagnosis rather than ischemic monomorphic VT.
  • Administering sodium bicarbonate is beneficial in TCA overdose with wide QRS complexes but is not a primary emergency step in pulseless TdP unless wide QRS with acidosis is prominent.
  • Lidocaine is ineffective in torsades and is primarily used in ischemic, monomorphic VT.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer IV magnesium sulfate: Correct for stable torsades but insufficient in pulseless TdP.

 

Option C. Administer IV sodium bicarbonate: Reserved for TCA-induced cardiotoxicity with wide QRS; not first intervention here.

 

Option D. Administer lidocaine: Indicated for monomorphic VT post-MI; ineffective for polymorphic VT due to QT prolongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulseless polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (torsades de pointes) mandates immediate unsynchronized defibrillation rather than magnesium sulfate administration, as per ACLS guidelines for cardiac arrest due to ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with a 20 pack-year smoking history presents with shortness of breath and chest discomfort. Imaging reveals a mass in the central region of the lung. Biopsy is performed, and immunohistochemical staining is positive for chromogranin. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Small cell carcinoma

 

This patient presents with a centrally located lung tumor in the context of a heavy smoking history, along with chromogranin positivity on biopsy. These findings are characteristic of small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC).

 

  • SCLC is a high-grade neuroendocrine tumor most commonly seen in smokers.
  • It arises in the central airways (hilar region).
  • Cells stain positive for neuroendocrine markers such as:
  • Chromogranin 
  • Synaptophysin
  • Neuron-specific enolase (NSE)

 

 

  • SCLC is often aggressive, with early metastasis and paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., SIADH, Cushing's).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: Although carcinoid tumors also stain positive for chromogranin, they are typically low-grade, often present in younger, non-smoking individuals, and usually have less aggressive behavior than SCLC.

 

Option B. Large cell carcinoma: Large cell carcinoma is undifferentiated, and though it may express some neuroendocrine markers, it typically lacks chromogranin expression. It is not strongly linked to neuroendocrine features like SCLC.

 

Option D. Pulmonary hamartoma: Hamartomas are benign lung tumors composed of disorganized but mature tissue, such as cartilage and fat. They do not stain positive for chromogranin, nor are they linked to smoking or central lung masses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small cell carcinoma of the lung is a central, high-grade neuroendocrine tumor strongly associated with smoking and characterized by chromogranin positivity on immunohistochemistry.

questions.text: A 36-year-old pre-menopausal woman is diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. She undergoes a core needle biopsy, and immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining is performed. The report shows the estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2-neu are all negative. Which of the following best describes the prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Poor prognosis

 

  • The immunohistochemistry details provided reveal that the tumor is triple negative—i.e., it lacks expression of estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2-neu. 
  • This subtype is referred to as Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC).
    • TNBC is more common in BRCA + women.
    • It is more aggressive with higher rates of recurrence and shorter disease-free intervals.
    • Lacks targeted therapy options like hormonal therapy (e.g., tamoxifen) or HER2-targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab).
    • While it may initially respond well to chemotherapy, long-term prognosis is generally poorer compared to receptor-positive cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Good prognosis: Incorrect. TNBC is associated with worse prognosis due to aggressive nature and lack of targeted therapies.

 

Option C. Good outcome with trastuzumab: Incorrect. Trastuzumab is only effective in HER2-positive cancers, but this case is HER2-negative.

 

Option D. Good outcome without trastuzumab: Incorrect. While some TNBCs may be chemosensitive, they still carry a worse long-term prognosis, and lack of HER2 overexpression makes trastuzumab ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC), characterized by the absence of ER, PR, and HER2 expression on immunohistochemistry, is associated with a poor prognosis due to its aggressive nature, lack of response to targeted hormonal or HER2-directed therapy, and higher recurrence risk despite chemosensitivity.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Fosaprepitant is incorrect?

 

  1. Fosaprepitant is a prodrug that is rapidly converted to aprepitant in the body.
  2. It is used primarily for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced diarrhea.
  3. Fosaprepitant acts as a neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptor antagonist.
  4. It is often administered as part of a multi-drug antiemetic regimen with a 5-HT₃ antagonist and dexamethasone.
  5. It helps prevent delayed-phase nausea and vomiting in patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only statement 2 is incorrect

 

2. Fosaprepitant is used for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), not diarrhea. Fosaprepitant is used for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), not diarrhea. Its mechanism does not affect bowel motility or fluid secretion. Its mechanism does not affect bowel motility or fluid secretion.

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1 – Correct: Fosaprepitant is a prodrug of aprepitant, administered intravenously. It is rapidly converted to aprepitant, the active NK1 receptor antagonist.

 

Statement 3 – Correct: It blocks neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptors, which bind substance P, a key mediator in vomiting pathways.

 

Statement 4 – Correct: It is frequently combined with ondansetron (a 5-HT₃ antagonist) and dexamethasone for complete antiemetic coverage, especially in highly emetogenic regimens like cisplatin.

 

Statement 5 – Correct: It is particularly effective at preventing delayed-phase nausea and vomiting, which occurs 24–72 hours post-chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fosaprepitant is an IV prodrug of aprepitant, used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting by antagonizing NK1 receptors. 
  • It is not used for diarrhea and is typically part of combination antiemetic regimens.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man from Patna with known tuberculous meningitis presents with progressive confusion, worsening drowsiness, and generalized weakness. BP is 90/60 mmHg. Serum sodium is 118 mEq/L, urine sodium is 64 mEq/L, and urine osmolality is 500 mOsm/kg. Other electrolytes are normal. Clinical examination reveals signs of dehydration with poor skin turgor. What is the most likely cause of his hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebral salt wasting

 

  • Cerebral salt wasting (CSW) is a common cause of hyponatremia in patients with CNS infections such as tuberculous meningitis.
  • It is characterized by hypovolemia with high urine sodium (>40 mEq/L) and high urine osmolality, as seen in this patient.
  • The key distinguishing factor from SIADH is volume status: CSW presents with clinical dehydration, while SIADH is euvolemic.
  • Pathophysiology involves excessive natriuresis mediated by increased brain natriuretic peptide leading to salt and water loss.
  • Correct management requires volume repletion with isotonic or hypertonic saline and salt supplementation, not fluid restriction.
  • Failure to recognize CSW can worsen hypovolemia and hyponatremia, leading to seizures or death.

 

CSW vs SIADH

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SIADH: Presents with euvolemia, not hypovolemia; fluid restriction is the treatment, not saline replacement.

 

Option C. Adrenal insufficiency: Would present with hyperkalemia, hypotension, and sometimes eosinophilia, which are absent here.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Rarely causes severe hyponatremia and would be associated with bradycardia, constipation, and dry skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with CNS infections like tuberculous meningitis, hyponatremia with clinical hypovolemia, high urine sodium, and high urine osmolality is characteristic of cerebral salt wasting, requiring volume and sodium repletion rather than fluid restriction.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male presents with chronic, progressive abdominal discomfort over the past year. Cross-sectional imaging reveals a 10 cm pancreatic mass. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen confirms pancreatic adenocarcinoma, and molecular analysis identifies inactivation of the SMAD4 gene. Alteration in which of the following regulatory pathways is most likely responsible for the pathogenesis of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TGF-beta

 

  • SMAD4 is a tumor suppressor gene that functions within the TGF-beta (Transforming Growth Factor-beta) signaling pathway. 
  • In normal cells, TGF-beta binds to its receptor and triggers phosphorylation of SMAD2 and SMAD3, which then form a complex with SMAD4. 
  • This complex translocates to the nucleus to regulate genes involved in cell cycle arrest, differentiation, and apoptosis.
  • In pancreatic adenocarcinoma, inactivation of SMAD4 results in disruption of this tumor-suppressive signaling, allowing unchecked proliferation and progression of malignancy. 
  • Therefore, the regulatory pathway most commonly altered by SMAD4 loss is the TGF-beta pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MYC: Is a proto-oncogene involved in cell cycle progression and proliferation, but it is not regulated by the SMAD4 pathway or directly linked to TGF-beta signaling. MYC is associated with nuclear transcription factor and other type of malignancy.

 

Option B. BCL2: Regulates apoptosis and is often involved in lymphoid malignancies, particularly follicular lymphoma. It is not associated with the TGF-beta pathway or SMAD4 mutations.

 

Option D. Beta-catenin: Is part of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is important in other malignancies like colorectal cancer (as Beta catenin has the close association with APC gene), but not directly affected by SMAD4 inactivation. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMAD4 is an essential mediator of the TGF-beta signaling pathway. Inactivation of SMAD4 leads to disruption of growth-inhibitory signals and contributes to pancreatic adenocarcinoma development.

choices.text: Bezold-Jarisch Reflex – Bradycardia and hypotension due to stimulation of ventricular chemoreceptors; afferent and efferent limbs via vagus nerve.
Bainbridge Reflex – Bradycardia due to increased venous return, mediated by stretch receptors in the right atrium.
Cushing Reflex – Protective response to cerebral ischemia involving systemic hypertension and reflex bradycardia.
J Reflex – Bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea due to stimulation of juxta-pulmonary capillary (J) receptors.

questions.text: Regarding various cardiovascular reflexes, which of the following is incorrectly matched with its description?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bainbridge Reflex – Bradycardia due to increased venous return, mediated by stretch receptors in the right atrium.

 

The Bainbridge reflex is a cardioacceleratory reflex triggered by increased venous return, which stimulates stretch receptors in the right atrium, leading to inhibition of the vasodilator area, reduction in vagal tone, and a reflex tachycardia. 

 

The option incorrectly associates it with bradycardia, which makes it the wrong match.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Correctly described. It involves chemoreceptors in the left ventricle, activated by chemical substances (e.g., alkaloids), leading to bradycardia and hypotension via vagal pathways.


Option C. Cushing Reflex: Correct. It is a protective reflex during raised intracranial pressure, leading to systemic hypertension, reflex bradycardia, and respiratory irregularities.


Option D. J Reflex: Correct. Triggered by stimulation of juxta-pulmonary capillary (J) receptors, leading to apnea, bradycardia, and hypotension—seen in pulmonary edema or congestion.

 

Educational Objective:


The Bainbridge reflex causes tachycardia in response to increased venous return via right atrial stretch receptors. 

 

Confusing it with bradycardia reflexes like Bezold-Jarisch or Cushing reflex is a common error and must be clearly distinguished in physiology-based

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of catatonia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pressured speech

 

  • Catatonia is a psychomotor syndrome characterized by a range of motor, behavioral, and speech abnormalities. 
  • Core features include mutism, echolalia (repeating others' words), echopraxia (mimicking others' movements), waxy flexibility (maintaining imposed postures), stupor, and posturing. 
  • These symptoms reflect motor and behavioral inhibition or repetition, not hyperactivity.
  • Pressured speech is a feature of mania, not catatonia. 
  • It refers to rapid, excessive, and hard-to-interrupt speech, which is the opposite of the speech disturbances seen in catatonia (like mutism).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Echolalia: A classic feature of catatonia involving repetitive echoing of another’s speech.

 

Option B. Waxy flexibility: A hallmark sign, where patients maintain positions into which they are placed.

 

Option D. Mutism: A common symptom, indicating absence or near-absence of verbal response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clinical features of catatonia includes-

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is being treated for dyslipidemia with rosuvastatin. At a follow-up visit, he reports symptoms of muscle pain and weakness. Which of the following drugs should be avoided due to a known interaction that increases the risk of statin-induced myopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clarithromycin

 

  • Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic and a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor. While rosuvastatin is primarily cleared by non-CYP3A4 pathways, concomitant use of strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (like clarithromycin, erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, ketoconazole) can still increase plasma levels of statins, especially with statins that are CYP-metabolized.
  • This interaction can raise the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis, particularly when statins are used in higher doses or combined with other interacting agents.
  • Even though rosuvastatin is less dependent on CYP3A4 than simvastatin or atorvastatin, caution is still advised with strong inhibitors like clarithromycin, especially in patients with other risk factors for myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pregabalin: Used for neuropathic pain. It does not interact with statins and does not increase the risk of myopathy.

 

Option C. Rivaroxaban:  An oral factor Xa inhibitor. Though metabolized by CYP3A4, it has no clinically significant interaction with statins in terms of increasing myopathy risk.

 

Option D. Teriparatide: A recombinant PTH analog used for osteoporosis. It does not interact with statins and is not associated with statin-related muscle toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clarithromycin, a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor, can increase statin plasma concentrations and raise the risk of myopathy. It should be avoided or used with caution in patients taking statins like rosuvastatin.

questions.text: Under Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, "T3 Camps" include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tell



Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) strategy, “T3 Camps” stand for:

 

  • Test – Screening individuals for anemia using appropriate tools like hemoglobin testing.
  • Treat – Providing the necessary treatment to those who are anemic (e.g., iron, folic acid, deworming).
  • Talk – Counseling individuals and families on nutrition, hygiene, and compliance with iron-folic acid supplementation.

 

There is no component called "Tell" in the official T3 framework. “Tell” is a distractor not aligned with the structured communication or intervention methods under AMB.


Educational Objective:


To identify the components of the T3 strategy under the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, which focuses on screening, treating, and counseling to reduce the burden of anemia across target populations, especially in children, adolescents, and pregnant women.

 

Note – Now, its expanded to include one additional “T” as “Track” i.e. follow up through AMB T4 app.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with increased urinary frequency, nocturia, and difficulty initiating urination. His blood pressure is within normal limits. After evaluation, he is diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The physician chooses a drug that relieves urinary obstruction without causing significant systemic hypotension. Which of the following agents is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tamsulosin

 

  • Tamsulosin is a selective α1A-adrenergic receptor antagonist, primarily acting on smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck. 
  • Because it has minimal action on vascular α1B receptors, it improves urinary flow in patients with BPH without significantly affecting blood pressure, making it particularly suitable for normotensive or elderly patients at risk of postural hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Doxazosin: Though effective for both BPH and hypertension, Doxazosin is a non-selective α1-blocker that acts on both vascular and prostate α1 receptors, often leading to orthostatic hypotension, especially in older adults.

 

Option C. Phentolamine:  A non-selective α-adrenergic antagonist used primarily in the diagnosis and management of pheochromocytoma and for catecholamine-induced hypertensive crises. It is not used in BPH, and it causes profound vasodilation and hypotension.

 

Option D. Alfuzosin: Alfuzosin is used in BPH, but it is less uroselective compared to tamsulosin, and while better tolerated than doxazosin, it still carries greater risk of hypotension than tamsulosin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tamsulosin is a selective α1A-adrenergic blocker that relieves lower urinary tract symptoms in BPH without significantly affecting blood pressure, due to its specificity for receptors in the prostate and bladder neck.

 

Note - Tamsulosin and Silodosin (new drug) used for the BPH treatment, which do not cause postural hypotension

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant presents with vomiting and failure to thrive. The child improves with IV glucose, but symptoms recur after one month. On investigation, elevated glutamine and uracil levels are noted.Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC)

 

This clinical picture is suggestive of a urea cycle disorder with hyperammonemia.

 

  • Urea cycle defects lead to accumulation of ammonia, which manifests as vomiting, lethargy, failure to thrive, and encephalopathy.
  • The fact that IV glucose improves the condition supports a metabolic disorder where catabolism (e.g., fasting) increases ammonia load.
  • Elevated glutamine is a marker of hyperammonemia, as glutamine acts as a temporary ammonia sink.
  • Elevated uracil and orotic acid are markers specifically associated with OTC deficiency.

 

Most common urea cycle disorder (X-linked recessive). Hyperammonemia with elevated glutamine. Increased orotic acid/uracil in urine due to excess carbamoyl phosphate shunted into pyrimidine synthesis. Classic presentation: vomiting, encephalopathy, failure to thrive.

 

Other Options: 
 

Option A. CPS1 deficiency:

 

  • Hyperammonemia present.
  • But no orotic aciduria, because CPS1 acts before carbamoyl phosphate enters the cytosolic pyrimidine synthesis pathway.
  • No uracil accumulation.


Option C. Arginase deficiency:

 

  • Usually presents later in childhood.
  • Spastic diplegia and developmental delay.
  • No orotic acid elevation; ammonia levels only mildly elevated.


Option D. Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency:

 

  • Hyperammonemia with accumulation of argininosuccinic acid.
  • No uracil elevation.
  • May present with brittle hair (trichorrhexis nodosa).

 

Educational Objective:
 

Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency is the most common urea cycle defect, often presenting in infancy with hyperammonemia, vomiting, failure to thrive, and elevated glutamine and orotic acid (uracil) due to diversion of excess carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis.

choices.text: Flexes, abducts, and laterally rotates the thigh at the hip joint; extends the knee
Extends, adducts, and medially rotates the thigh at the hip joint; flexes the knee
Flexes, abducts, and laterally rotates the thigh at the hip joint; flexes the knee
Extends, abducts, and laterally rotates the thigh at the hip joint; extends the knee

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the action of the sartorius muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flexes, abducts, and laterally rotates the thigh at the hip joint; flexes the knee

 

 

  • The sartorius is the longest muscle in the human body. It originates from the ASIS (anterior superior iliac spine) and inserts into the tibia behind the knee joint. 
  • The muscle is also known as the tailor’s muscle or honeymoon muscle, responsible for helping people sit in the cross-legged position (palati position). 
  • The sartorius causes flexion at the hip, flexion at the knee, abduction of the hip, and lateral rotation of the thigh.
  • It is not responsible for extension at the knee, which rules out some of the incorrect options. 
  • The correct option reflects the actions of flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation at the hip and flexion at the knee.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexes, abducts, and laterally rotates the thigh at the hip joint; extends the knee: This is incorrect because the sartorius flexes the knee, it does not extend the knee.

 

Option B. Extends, adducts, and medially rotates the thigh at the hip joint; flexes the knee: This is incorrect because the sartorius flexes the thigh, not extends it. It also abducts and laterally rotates the thigh rather than adducting and medially rotating it.

 

Option D. Extends, abducts, and laterally rotates the thigh at the hip joint; extends the knee: This is incorrect because the sartorius muscle does not extend the knee; it is involved in knee flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sartorius muscle is responsible for flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh at the hip joint and flexion at the knee. 
  • It helps in the cross-legged position and is referred to as the tailor’s muscle.

choices.text: It can be associated with heparin flushes
Risk is higher in medical vs surgical patients and occurs more in males
Arterial and venous thrombosis occur at equal rates

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with sepsis and is started on unfractionated heparin for DVT prophylaxis. On day 5, he develops swelling in the left leg, and Doppler confirms proximal deep vein thrombosis. Repeat labs show a drop in platelet count from 145,000/µL on admission to 60,000/µL today. He is afebrile, and there are no signs of active bleeding. A peripheral smear shows thrombocytopenia without schistocytes. What is true regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It can be associated with heparin flushes

 

  • This patient likely has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) — a prothrombotic immune-mediated disorder caused by antibodies against platelet factor 4 (PF4)-heparin complexes.
  • HIT can occur even after low-dose exposure, including heparin flushes used for catheter patency.
  • Thrombocytopenia typically begins 5–10 days after heparin exposure, and is usually moderate (platelets fall >50% but rarely below 20,000/μL).
  • Venous thromboses (DVT, PE) are more common than arterial events (stroke, limb ischemia).
  • The diagnosis is clinical, supported by the 4 Ts score (Thrombocytopenia, Timing, Thrombosis, alternative causes). A presumptive diagnosis is sufficient to initiate treatment while confirmatory tests are pending.
  • Immediate steps include stopping all heparin, avoiding warfarin initially, and starting non-heparin anticoagulation (e.g., argatroban, fondaparinux, or DOACs).

 

HIT – Diagnostic and Management Framework:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelet counts often fall below 20,000/µL: This is uncommon in HIT; counts typically stay above 30,000/µL.

 

Option C. Risk is higher in medical vs surgical patients and occurs more in males: Incorrect. Surgical patients and females are at higher risk.

 

Option D. Arterial and venous thrombosis occur at equal rates: Venous thrombosis predominates (DVT > PE > arterial events).

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIT is an immune-mediated prothrombotic condition that can occur even after minimal heparin exposure. It should be suspected when thrombocytopenia and thrombosis co-occur within 5–10 days of heparin use. Management requires immediate cessation of all heparin and initiation of non-heparin anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a bulge in the left groin that has progressively enlarged over the past year. On examination, the bulge becomes more prominent when the patient coughs and decreases in size when lying down. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). On further inspection, a part of the bowel appears to be forming a wall of the hernia sac as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sliding hernia

 

  • Inguinal hernias are sometimes referred to as ‘sliding’ in type. These are acquired indirect hernias arising at the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. 
  • Retroperitoneal fatty tissue is pushed downwards along the inguinal canal. As more tissue enters the hernia, peritoneum is pulled with it, thus creating a sac. However, the sac has formed secondarily, distinguishing it from a classic indirect hernia. 
  • On the left side, the sigmoid colon may descend into a sliding hernia (the caecum may do so on the right). 
  • Surgeons need extra caution during repair because the bowel may form part of the sac itself and can be damaged during the dissection. 
  • This is the correct term for a hernia in which part of the hernia sac wall is formed by an organ that "slides" into it. 
  • In this case, the image and the history suggest that part of the bowel (possibly the sigmoid colon) has become part of the hernia sac, which is characteristic of a sliding hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Richter’s hernia: Where a knuckle of bowel wall/circumference of bowel forms the content.

 

Option B. Maydl’s hernia: Where two loops of bowel form the content.

 

Option C. Pantaloon Hernia: This term describes a situation where both an indirect and a direct inguinal hernia are present simultaneously, creating a "pantaloon" shape as the hernia sacs straddle the inferior epigastric vessels. This is not what is being shown in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • A sliding hernia is one in which an organ, such as the sigmoid colon or bladder, forms part of the hernia sac wall and can "slide" into the sac. 
  • This condition is particularly risky during surgical repair due to the potential for organ injury.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is evaluated after experiencing sudden muscle fatigue and cramps following high-intensity interval training in a poorly ventilated environment. He reports that his legs feel “heavy” and “burning” shortly after starting his workouts. Laboratory studies show a transient drop in blood pH and increased anion gap. Given the likely metabolic shift in skeletal muscle during intense physical exertion under low oxygen availability, which of the following substances is expected to accumulate as the primary end product of glucose metabolism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lactate

 

  • During intense physical exertion, especially in conditions of limited oxygen availability, skeletal muscle cells rely on anaerobic glycolysis for energy production. Under these hypoxic conditions, pyruvate formed from glycolysis cannot proceed through the aerobic pathway (i.e., conversion to Acetyl-CoA and entry into the citric acid cycle). Instead, it is converted to lactate by the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase, which simultaneously regenerates NAD⁺ needed for continued glycolytic flux.
  • As a result, lactate accumulates as the major end product of glucose metabolism in tissues undergoing anaerobic respiration. This accumulation can lead to a transient metabolic acidosis during intense exertion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyruvate: Although pyruvate is the immediate product of glycolysis, it does not accumulate under anaerobic conditions. It is instead converted to lactate, making it an intermediate rather than a major end product.

 

Option B. Acetyl-CoA: Formation of Acetyl-CoA from pyruvate via the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex requires oxygen and occurs in the mitochondria. Under hypoxic conditions, this aerobic pathway is suppressed, so Acetyl-CoA is not the major product.

 

Option D. Urea: Urea is a nitrogen-containing waste product formed from amino acid catabolism in the urea cycle, unrelated to glucose metabolism. It does not accumulate in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactate is the primary end product of glucose metabolism in hypoxic or anaerobic conditions, such as during vigorous exercise with limited oxygen availability.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents with progressive fatigue and lower limb edema. On physical examination, he has an elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) with prominent "v waves" visible during the cardiac cycle. Auscultation reveals a pansystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tricuspid regurgitation

 

  • Large v waves on the jugular venous pressure waveform are characteristic of tricuspid regurgitation. 
  • In this condition, during right ventricular systole, blood abnormally flows back into the right atrium due to incompetent tricuspid valve closure. 
  • This retrograde flow leads to a sharp rise in atrial pressure and a prominent v wave in the JVP waveform.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial fibrillation: Associated with absent a waves due to lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

 

Option B. Pulmonary stenosis: Leads to large a waves due to increased resistance against which the right atrium contracts.

 

Option D. Constrictive pericarditis: Characterized by a rise in JVP during inspiration (Kussmaul’s sign), not prominent v waves.

 

Educational Objective:


Prominent or large v waves on the JVP waveform are a hallmark of tricuspid regurgitation, resulting from systolic backflow of blood into the right atrium.

choices.text: Use a bronchodilator at the same time
Add a short course of oral antifungal therapy
Reduce inhaler use to once daily
Rinse the mouth and throat with water after each use

questions.text: A male patient is started on an inhaled corticosteroid using a metered-dose inhaler (MDI), prescribed at two actuations twice daily for asthma control. To reduce the risk of developing oropharyngeal candidiasis, which of the following is the most appropriate preventive measure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinse the mouth and throat with water after each use

 

  • Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are commonly used in the management of persistent asthma to reduce airway inflammation. 
  • However, they can deposit in the oropharynx, where local immunosuppression can lead to oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush).

 

The best way to prevent this complication is to:

 

  • Rinse the mouth and gargle with water after using the inhaler
  • Spit out the water rather than swallowing
  • Use a spacer with MDI to decrease oropharyngeal deposition

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Use a bronchodilator at the same time: Bronchodilators do not prevent fungal overgrowth and are not a substitute for rinsing.

 

Option B. Add a short course of oral antifungal therapy:  Prophylactic antifungals are not routinely indicated and may promote resistance.

 

Option C. Reduce inhaler use to once daily: Reducing the prescribed dose may compromise asthma control and is not appropriate without physician approval.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients using inhaled corticosteroids should rinse their mouth and gargle with water after each use to prevent oropharyngeal candidiasis due to local immunosuppressive effects.

choices.text: Generation of action potential → Neuromuscular junction activation → Calcium release → T-tubule activation → Contraction
Neuromuscular junction activation → Action potential in muscle fiber → T-tubule propagation → Calcium release from cisternae → Contraction
Calcium binds to actin → Action potential spreads → Calcium released → Neuromuscular stimulation → Muscle contracts
Action potential in T-tubule → Muscle contraction → Calcium movement → Action potential in cisternae → Relaxation

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is participating in a study on skeletal muscle physiology. During muscle fiber stimulation, which of the following represents the correct sequence of events involved in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuromuscular junction activation → Action potential in muscle fiber → T-tubule propagation → Calcium release from cisternae → Contraction

 

The correct order of events in skeletal muscle excitation-contraction coupling is:
 

  1. Excitation of muscle fibers by motor nerve impulses at the neuromuscular junction
  2. Generation of action potential in the muscle fiber membrane
  3. Spread of action potential along T-tubules
  4. Entry of the action potential into terminal cisternae
  5. Release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum cisternae
  6. Calcium binds to actin filaments (specifically to troponin), initiating interaction with myosin
  7. Contraction of the muscle fibers

 

Other options:
 

Option A. Generation of action potential → Neuromuscular junction activation → Calcium release → T-tubule activation → Contraction:  Incorrect order — action potential cannot precede neuromuscular junction activation.


Option C. Calcium binds to actin → Action potential spreads → Calcium released → Neuromuscular stimulation → Muscle contracts: Incorrect — calcium does not bind to actin before the action potential spreads or is generated.


Option D. Action potential in T-tubule → Muscle contraction → Calcium movement → Action potential in cisternae → Relaxation: Incorrect — contraction does not precede the movement of calcium or action potential initiation.

 

Educational Objective:


Excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle begins with stimulation at the neuromuscular junction and proceeds through a well-ordered sequence: action potential generation, T-tubule propagation, calcium release, and finally muscle fiber contraction.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with symptoms of urinary urgency, increased frequency, and nocturia. She is diagnosed with overactive bladder syndrome. Which of the following newly approved agents acts as a β₃-adrenergic receptor agonist and is appropriate for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibegron

 

  • Vibegron is a newly approved β₃-adrenergic receptor agonist used in the management of overactive bladder syndrome.
  • It works by relaxing the detrusor smooth muscle during the storage phase of the micturition cycle, thereby increasing bladder capacity and reducing urgency, frequency, and nocturia.

 

Unlike antimuscarinic agents, β₃-agonists like vibegron:

 

  • Have fewer anticholinergic side effects (e.g., dry mouth, constipation)
  • Are well tolerated in elderly patients
  • Do not impair cognition, making them suitable for older adults
  • Vibegron is similar in function to mirabegron, another β₃-agonist, but vibegron has a more recent approval and a favorable side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Solifenacin:  A muscarinic receptor antagonist (anticholinergic). Commonly used for OAB, but can cause dry mouth and constipation.

 

Option C. Oxybutynin: A non-selective antimuscarinic. Effective but associated with significant anticholinergic side effects.

 

Option D. Darifenacin: Another M3-selective antimuscarinic. Though more selective, it still poses anticholinergic risks, especially in older adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mirabegron is a β₃-adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of overactive bladder, especially in patients who cannot tolerate the anticholinergic side effects of traditional therapies.

choices.text: The most common cause is vocal cord trauma
Histologically, it is a malignant lesion of the vocal cords
The edema fluid accumulates in the Reinke's space (subepithelial space)
The treatment of choice is tracheostomy and radiotherapy

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive hoarseness of voice. Laryngoscopic examination is as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The edema fluid accumulates in the Reinke's space (subepithelial space)

 

  • The condition shown is Reinke’s edema (polypoid corditis), characterized by diffuse collection of fluid in the Reinke’s space, which is the subepithelial space of the vocal cords.
  • It is strongly associated with chronic smoking, with up to 97% of cases seen in smokers.
  • Laryngoscopy reveals the classical “saddle-bag” appearance of the vocal cords.
  • It is a benign lesion and not a malignancy.
  • The treatment of choice is micro laryngeal surgery, not tracheostomy or radiotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The most common cause is vocal cord trauma: False, the main cause is chronic smoking (also voice abuse, but not trauma alone)

 

Option B. Histologically, it is a malignant lesion of the vocal cords: False, Reinke's edema is a benign lesion, not malignant.

 

Option D. The treatment of choice is tracheostomy and radiotherapy: False, treatment is microlaryngoscopic surgery and voice therapy, not tracheostomy or radiotherapy (those are for cancers)

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The crus commune is a part of the cochlea responsible for high-frequency sound detection.
It is a shared bony canal connecting the posterior and superior semicircular canals.
The crus commune contains the utricle, a structure involved in detecting linear acceleration.
It is an extension of the auditory tube and plays a role in equalizing ear pressure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents with a long-standing history of recurrent vertigo and imbalance, especially with rapid head movements. Neurologic examination is unremarkable. Audio vestibular testing reveals signs suggestive of a structural abnormality within the inner ear, specifically affecting the semicircular canals. Which of the following statements regarding the crus commune in the inner ear is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a shared bony canal connecting the posterior and superior semicircular canals.

 

The crus commune, correctly stated here, is a shared canal that connects the posterior and superior semicircular canals in the inner ear. This structure is part of the vestibular system, which plays a crucial role in balance and spatial orientation.

 

Semicircular canals are three in number, the lateral, posterior and superior, and lie in planes at right angles to one another. Each canal has an ampullated end which opens independently into the vestibule and a non-ampullated end. The non-ampullatedends of posterior and superior canals unite to form a common channel called crus commune. Thus, the three canals open into the vestibule by five openings.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The crus commune is a part of the cochlea responsible for high-frequency sound detection: This statement is incorrect. The cochlea, not the crus commune, is involved in sound detection, with different parts responsible for detecting different frequencies of sound.

 

Option C. The crus commune contains the utricle, a structure involved in detecting linear acceleration: This statement is incorrect. The utricle, along with the saccule, is indeed involved in detecting linear acceleration, but it is not contained within the crus commune. These structures are located in the vestibule, not the semicircular canals.

 

Option D. It is an extension of the auditory tube and plays a role in equalizing ear pressure: This statement is incorrect. The auditory tube (Eustachian tube) is responsible for equalizing pressure between the middle ear and the atmosphere. The crus commune is part of the bony labyrinth of the inner ear and is unrelated to the auditory tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify the crus commune as a shared bony canal in the inner ear that connects the posterior and superior semicircular canals and is involved in the vestibular system, not in hearing or pressure equalization.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought in for evaluation of short stature. Which of the following statements regarding constitutional growth delay are correct? 

 

  1. He had normal length and weight at birth
  2. Catch-up growth typically occurs at 6–12 months of age
  3. His bone age is greater than chronological age
  4. His height velocity assumes a normal rate during middle childhood
  5. Final adult height is typically normal
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A, E

 

The scenario describes Constitutional Growth Delay (CGD), a common cause of short stature in children with delayed skeletal maturation and late onset of puberty, but eventual attainment of normal adult height.

 

A. He had normal length and weight at birth: Correct, Children with CGD are born with normal length and weight.

 

E. Final adult height is typically normal: Correct, Final adult height is usually normal, though delayed in attainment.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

B. Catch-up growth typically occurs at 6–12 months of age: Incorrect, Catch-up growth does not typically occur at 6–12 months; rather, these children continue to grow slowly in early years and catch-up during adolescence.

 

C. His bone age is greater than chronological age: Incorrect, Bone age in CGD is delayed, i.e., less than chronological age.

 

D. His height velocity assumes a normal rate during middle childhood: Incorrect, Height velocity is slower than normal during early years but normalizes later.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In constitutional growth delay, children have normal birth parameters, delayed bone age, and delayed puberty, but they ultimately reach normal adult height.
  • The key distinguishing feature is the bone age lag behind chronological age with no pathological findings.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding early pregnancy signs is/are correct? 

 

  1. Chadwick’s sign is characterized by a bluish discoloration of the anterior vaginal wall observed around the 8th week of pregnancy.
  2. Osiander’s sign involves increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices and typically appears before the 4th week.
  3. Goodell’s sign refers to cervical softening and is evident as early as the 6th week of gestation.
  4. Palmer’s sign involves rhythmic uterine contractions and is elicited on bimanual examination between the 4th and 8th weeks.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 1, 3, and 4 are correct

 

Statement 1. Chadwick’s sign is characterized by a bluish discoloration of the anterior vaginal wall observed around the 8th week of pregnancy: Correct. Chadwick’s sign (also called Jacquemier’s sign) is the bluish discoloration of the anterior vaginal wall, seen by the 8th week.

 

Statement 3. Goodell’s sign refers to cervical softening and is evident as early as the 6th week of gestation: Correct. Goodell’s sign refers to a soft cervix, seen by the 6th week.

 

Statement 4. Palmer’s sign involves rhythmic uterine contractions and is elicited on bimanual examination between the 4th and 8th weeks: Correct. Palmer’s sign is characterized by rhythmic uterine contractions elicited on bimanual examination, typically between 4–8 weeks.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Osiander’s sign involves increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices and typically appears before the 4th week.: Incorrect. Osiander’s sign appears at 6–8 weeks, not before the 4th week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Several clinical signs aid in the early diagnosis of pregnancy. These signs are classified based on their anatomical location (vaginal, cervical, uterine) and the time at which they typically appear. Recognizing these signs can support clinical diagnosis before imaging confirmation.

questions.text:
Match the following HPV vaccines with the HPV types they protect against: 

 

Column A: HPV Vaccine

 

  1. Cervarix
  2. Gardasil
  3. Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent)
  4. Cervavac (India)

 

Column B: HPV Types Covered

 

  1. 6, 11, 16, 18
  2. 16, 18
  3. 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58
  4. 6, 11, 16, 18 (Indian quadrivalent)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

 

Cervarix (Bivalent): Covers high-risk types 16, 18 → B

 

Gardasil (Quadrivalent): Covers types 6, 11, 16, 18 → A

 

Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent): Covers types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58 → C

 

Cervavac (India's vaccine): A quadrivalent vaccine covering 6, 11, 16, 18 → D

 


Educational Objective:

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18,31,33,45,52,58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18

choices.text: Increased rainfall leading to cleaner water sources
Higher temperatures and humidity promoting flea reproduction
Improved urban hygiene reducing flea populations
Global mosquito control efforts eliminating vector competition

questions.text: Which of the following environmental factors is most likely to contribute to increased Xenopsylla cheopis-mediated Yersinia pestis outbreaks?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Higher temperatures and humidity promoting flea reproduction

 

  • Warm, humid environments favor flea reproduction, increasing transmission risk.
  • Rodent population booms due to climate change further amplify transmission cycles.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased rainfall leading to cleaner water sources: Incorrect, Plague thrives in dry, overcrowded conditions, not clean environments.

 

Option C. Improved urban hygiene reducing flea populations: Incorrect, Better hygiene reduces, rather than increases, flea populations.

 

Option D. Global mosquito control efforts eliminating vector competition: Incorrect, Mosquitoes do not compete with Xenopsylla cheopis for transmission niches.


Educational Objective:

 

Rising temperatures and humidity due to climate change favor Xenopsylla cheopis proliferation, increasing the risk of plague outbreaks.

 

Xenopsylla cheopis and Plague

choices.text: Webbed neck with widely spaced nipples

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is most likely expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gynecomastia with long thin limbs


The 47, XXY karyotype indicates Klinefelter syndrome, a chromosomal disorder affecting males. It is characterized by:

 

  • Tall stature with long limbs (eunuchoid body habitus)
  • Gynecomastia (increased estrogen-to-testosterone ratio)
  • Small testes with infertility (due to primary testicular failure)
  • Learning difficulties or mild intellectual disability

 

These features arise due to an extra X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism and altered androgen-estrogen balance.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Short stature with polydactyly – Suggestive of Ellis–van Creveld syndrome or Trisomy 13.


Option C. Webbed neck with widely spaced nipples – Characteristic of Turner syndrome (45, X).


Option D. Rocker bottom feet – Seen in Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is characterized by tall stature, long limbs, gynecomastia, hypogonadism, and infertility. It results from an additional X chromosome in males and is a common cause of male infertility.

questions.text:
Match the columns in A (Types of Shock) with B (classical presentation): 

 

Column A (Types of Shock)

 

  1. Anaphylactic shock
  2. Hemorrhagic shock
  3. Cardiogenic shock
  4. Neurogenic shock

 

Column B (Classical Presentation):

 

  1. Bradycardia with warm, dry skin and hypotension 
  2. Elevated jugular venous pressure, pulmonary edema
  3. Hypotension with cold, clammy extremities 
  4. Hypotension, bronchospasm, and urticaria
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A

 

  • (1-D) Anaphylactic shock: Presents with vasodilation, bronchospasm, and urticaria due to IgE-mediated hypersensitivity.
  • (2-C) Hemorrhagic shock: Typically results from acute blood loss with signs of hypovolemia like cold, clammy skin and hypotension.
  • (3-B) Cardiogenic shock: Results from pump failure (e.g., MI), leading to pulmonary edema, raised JVP, and hypotension.
  • (4-A) Neurogenic shock: Often seen after spinal cord injury with autonomic disruption causing bradycardia and hypotension, unlike other forms of shock.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Atherosclerotic aneurysm of the abdominal aorta

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with a pulsatile abdominal mass and complaints of vague lower back pain. The patient undergoes the procedure shown in the image. What is the most likely underlying pathology being treated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atherosclerotic aneurysm of the abdominal aorta

 

  • The image shows an Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR), a minimally invasive procedure used for treating abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). 
  • This condition occurs due to degenerative changes and weakening of the aortic wall, primarily caused by atherosclerosis. 
  • Risk factors include hypertension, smoking, male gender, and advanced age. 
  • The classic presentation includes a pulsatile abdominal mass and possible lower back or flank pain. 
  • If left untreated, it can rupture, leading to catastrophic hemorrhage.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Aortic dissection: Aortic dissection results from a tear in the intimal layer, leading to the formation of a false lumen. It usually occurs in the thoracic aorta. It is commonly managed using open surgery or stenting in selected cases, but EVAR is not the standard treatment.

 

Option C. Psoas abscess after Pott’s spine: Psoas abscess is treated by drainage and anti-TB therapy.

 

Option D. Acute mesenteric ischemia: This is a vascular emergency caused by occlusion or reduced blood flow to the intestines, commonly involving the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). It is managed with embolectomy, revascularization, or bowel resection, but not EVAR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • EVAR (Endovascular Aneurysm Repair) is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), which is most commonly caused by atherosclerosis.
  • AAA typically presents as a pulsatile abdominal mass and can be asymptomatic until rupture occurs. 
  • Screening is recommended for high-risk individuals, and timely intervention prevents life-threatening complications.

questions.text:
Autopsy of a bombing victim reveals:

 

  • Intestinal perforation
  • Skull base fracture with underlying brain contusions
  • Absence of external lacerations
  • Carboxyhemoglobin level of 38%

 

What is the least likely blast injury type present?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secondary

 

  • The correct answer is Secondary, because no evidence of external lacerations was found during autopsy, which are typically hallmark features of secondary blast injuries. 
  • Secondary blast injuries are caused by projectiles or fragments propelled by the explosion, and they typically cause penetrating injuries or lacerations to the body. They lead to abrasions, contusions and lacerations. However, in this case, the absence of external lacerations makes it least likely that secondary blast injuries are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary: Primary blast injuries are due to the shock waves. Direct effect of blast overpressure waves, and commonly affect hollow internal organs/air-filled organs like lungs, intestines, and ears. The intestinal perforation seen here is classic for primary blast injuries.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Tertiary blast injuries result from the body being thrown by the high velocity blast wind and hitting a hard surface, leading to blunt trauma. The skull base fracture and brain contusions fit well within this category.

 

Option D. Quaternary: Quaternary injuries include any other injury like burns, inhalational injuries, and toxic effects from the explosion environment. The carboxyhemoglobin level of 38% is a strong indicator of carbon monoxide poisoning, hence clearly a quaternary injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absence of external lacerations makes secondary blast injury the least likely; these injuries typically result from penetrating fragments or shrapnel.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is recovering from a recently treated ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). She received appropriate acute therapy and is now discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy, atorvastatin, and a beta-blocker. Which of the following beta-blockers should be avoided in this patient due to its partial agonist activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pindolol

 

  • Beta-blockers are standard post-MI therapy because they:
    • Reduce myocardial oxygen demand
    • Lower risk of arrhythmias
    • Improve survival after myocardial infarction
  • However, not all beta-blockers are appropriate in this context. Pindolol has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA) — meaning it has partial agonist effects at β-adrenergic receptors, especially β1-receptors.
  • Because of this partial agonist activity:
    • Pindolol does not fully suppress heart rate and contractility, which are essential goals post-MI
    • It may reduce the protective effects of beta-blockade in myocardial infarction recovery
    • Therefore, pindolol is contraindicated or should be avoided in patients with ischemic heart disease or post-MI

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Propranolol:  A non-selective beta-blocker with no intrinsic sympathomimetic activity. Although not cardioselective, it is used in some cardiovascular conditions and is acceptable post-MI if needed.

 

Option C. Nebivolol: A cardioselective β1-blocker with vasodilatory properties due to nitric oxide release. It has no partial agonist activity and may be appropriate in patients with cardiovascular disease.

 

Option D. Metoprolol: A β1-selective blocker (cardioselective) with no ISA. It is one of the most commonly used beta-blockers post-MI, supported by strong clinical evidence for improving survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beta-blockers with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, such as pindolol, celiprolol, alprenolol, acebutolol should be avoided in patients recovering from myocardial infarction due to their partial agonist effect, which may blunt the cardioprotective benefits of beta-blockade.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging, painless thyroid nodule. She denies any symptoms of thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism. Fine-needle aspiration reveals cells with neuroendocrine features, and the biopsy specimen shows amyloid deposition in the stroma, as highlighted in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely type of amyloid protein associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ACal

 

The patient presents with a thyroid mass that on histology shows amyloid deposition—a key finding in medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC arises from parafollicular C-cells, which secrete calcitonin. This calcitonin is abnormally folded and deposited as amyloid in the tumor stroma.

 

  • The amyloid found in MTC is derived from calcitonin, and the amyloid protein subtype is known as ACal (amyloid derived from calcitonin).
  • This explains the presence of amyloid on biopsy in this setting.

 

Thus, based on the diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma, amyloid derived from calcitonin (ACal) is the most appropriate answer.

 

Note:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is associated with development of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2A and Type 2B (MEN2A and MEN2B) Syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aβ2: Aβ2 is associated with hemodialysis-related amyloidosis, derived from β2-microglobulin, and does not relate to thyroid tumors or medullary carcinoma.

 

Option C. AA: AA amyloid is derived from serum amyloid A, seen in chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., TB, RA). It is not related to neuroendocrine tumors or the thyroid.

 

Option D. Aβ: Aβ (amyloid-beta) is found in the central nervous system, especially in Alzheimer disease plaques. It is unrelated to medullary thyroid carcinoma or calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In medullary thyroid carcinoma, amyloid deposits are composed of ACal, which is derived from calcitonin secreted by neoplastic C cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past 4 months. Imaging reveals a cavitatory lesion in the right lower lobe of the lung. She undergoes a lobectomy, and the histopathological section from the lesion is shown. Based on this, what is the most likely diagnosis and characteristic cyst wall structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Echinococcal cyst; 3-layered cyst

 

  • The classic histological appearance shown is of a hydatid cyst caused by Echinococcus granulosus and shows:
  • Three layers:
    • Inner germinal layer (produces scolices and daughter cysts)
    • Middle laminated membrane (acellular, refractile)
    • Outer fibrous host-derived capsule (pericyst)
  • These features match the image and the description provided in the vignette (progressive dyspnea, cavitary lesion, histopathology).
  • Lung involvement is a common extrapulmonary site for hydatid cysts.
  • The laminated membrane gives a distinctive appearance with multiple daughter cysts.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides infection; 2-layered cyst: Strongyloides stercoralis is a nematode that primarily causes intestinal and pulmonary symptoms but does not form multilayered cysts in the lungs. No laminated or germinal layers are seen.

 

Option B. Paragonimus infection; 3-layered cyst: Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke) may form cavitary lesions but produces non-laminated cysts, usually with inflammatory granulomas, not the organized 3-layered hydatid cyst seen here.

 

Option D. Cysticercosis; 2-layered cyst: Taenia solium larval form can infect many tissues, including brain and muscle. Cysticercus lesions have a thin wall with only 2 layers and a central scolex, not the trilaminar structure seen in Echinococcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid cysts characterized histologically by three layers: an inner germinal layer, a laminated membrane, and an outer fibrous capsule. 
  • This appearance is pathognomonic and helps differentiate it from other parasitic infections.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with Child C Cirrhosis and Hepatitis C is undergoing a liver transplant. Which anatomical structure should the surgeon prepare to anastomose first in the recipient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IVC

 

  • The IVC, both supra-hepatic and infra-hepatic, is usually the first part to be anastomosed during liver transplantation to establish venous outflow from the liver, which is critical to providing immediate blood drainage from the graft.
  • The order of anastomosis is: IVC > Portal Vein > Hepatic Artery > Bile Duct 

 

Other Options:



Option A. Hepatic artery: 



Anastomosis of the hepatic artery is performed later during the transplant.

 

  • Although it is critical for oxygenated blood supply to the graft, establishing venous drainage (IVC) takes priority.
  • Arterial anastomosis typically follows portal vein anastomosis.


Option B. Portal Vein:


The portal vein is anastomosed after the IVC.

 

  • Portal vein anastomosis establishes portal venous inflow to the graft.
  • Although important for liver function (providing nutrients and partial oxygenation), it is not the first connection made.


 

Option C. Bile duct:



Bile duct anastomosis is done last.

 

  • It restores the biliary drainage system after vascular anastomoses are completed.
  • A choledochocholedochostomy (duct-to-duct) or Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is performed depending on circumstances.


 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The first structure to be anastomosed in the recipient of a liver transplant is the IVC, specifically starting with the supra-hepatic IVC, followed by the infra-hepatic IVC, to establish adequate venous outflow from the liver.
  • The order of anastomosis in the recipient of a liver transplant is: 

 

  1. Supra-hepatic IVC
  2. Infra-hepatic IVC 
  3. Portal Vein
  4. Hepatic Artery 
  5. Bile duct

questions.text: An 80-year-old man from Pune with a history of cervical spondylosis is brought to the emergency department after falling backwards in his bathroom. Since the fall, he reports clumsiness in his hands and difficulty feeding himself and buttoning his shirt. On examination, there is marked weakness of grip and reduced strength in shoulder abduction and elbow flexion. Lower limb strength is relatively preserved, and no sensory level is identified. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk in all four limbs, and there is no bladder involvement at this time. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Central cord syndrome

 

  • This patient presents with disproportionate weakness in the upper limbs, particularly in the distal fine motor functions like buttoning a shirt, with relative sparing of lower limbs.
  • The clinical context of cervical hyperextension trauma in an elderly individual with cervical spondylosis is classic for central cord syndrome (CCS).
  • Pathophysiologically, CCS involves damage to the central fibers of the corticospinal tract, which control upper limb function more medially.
  • Lower limb fibers (located laterally in the cord) remain relatively preserved.
  • Bladder dysfunction may occur but often develops later.
  • Other spinal syndromes typically show different patterns of motor, sensory, or sphincter involvement.

 

Spinal Cord Syndromes:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brown-Séquard syndrome: Produces asymmetrical findings with a distinct sensory split; not seen here.

 

Option B. Conus medullaris syndrome: Affects lower limbs symmetrically with early sphincter dysfunction — not present in this case.

 

Option C. Anterior spinal cord syndrome: Causes complete bilateral motor and pain/temp loss with sparing of posterior column — no such findings here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central cord syndrome typically presents in elderly patients after cervical hyperextension injury, leading to disproportionately greater upper limb weakness due to central corticospinal tract involvement. Lower limbs are relatively spared, and MRI often reveals cervical cord edema.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man hospitalized for sepsis develops sudden thrombocytopenia after several days of unfractionated heparin therapy. His platelet count drops by more than 50%, and he is diagnosed with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The treating team discontinues heparin and initiates an alternative anticoagulant that directly inhibits thrombin without requiring antithrombin III and is not neutralized by platelet factor. Which of the following is the most appropriate anticoagulant in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

  • Lepirudin is a recombinant direct thrombin inhibitor derived from hirudin, originally found in leech saliva. It directly inhibits both free and clot-bound thrombin, making it particularly useful in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) because:
    • It does not require antithrombin III for activity
    • It is not affected by platelet factor 4, which is central to the pathophysiology of HIT
    • It provides predictable anticoagulation and is monitored using aPTT

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enoxaparin: A low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), which still cross-reacts with heparin antibodies in HIT. Not safe in this scenario.

 

Option C. Warfarin: Should not be started in acute HIT as it can worsen thrombosis risk and cause warfarin-induced skin necrosis when protein C levels drop rapidly.

 

Option D. Clopidogrel: An antiplatelet agent (ADP receptor blocker), not an anticoagulant. It plays no role in treating HIT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor used as an alternative anticoagulant in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. It acts independently of antithrombin III and is not affected by platelet factor 4.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor like Lepirudin, Argatroban are injectable and Dabigatran is oral.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old male presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue for the past 6 months. He denies cough, wheezing, or orthopnea. On examination, breath sounds are diminished bilaterally, and there is paradoxical abdominal movement during inspiration. Pulmonary function tests reveal:

 

  • FEV1: Decreased
  • FEV1/FVC: Normal
  • TLC: Decreased
  • DLCO: Normal
  • Maximal Inspiratory Pressure (Pimax): Markedly Decreased

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on this pulmonary function profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory muscle weakness


The key to solving this tough question lies in identifying the pattern of restriction with preserved DLCO and significantly reduced inspiratory strength (Pimax):

 

  • FEV1 ↓, TLC ↓ = restrictive pattern
  • FEV1/FVC normal = rules out obstructive disease
  • DLCO normal = suggests the alveolar-capillary membrane is intact
  • Pimax ↓↓ = indicates reduced respiratory muscle strength

 

These findings strongly point toward respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., due to neuromuscular disorders like ALS, myasthenia gravis, or Guillain-Barré syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (ILD): Would present with ↓FEV1, ↓TLC, and ↓DLCO, but Pimax is typically normal.

 

Option B. Severe asthma: Would show an obstructive pattern (↓FEV1, ↓FEV1/FVC, ↑TLC, ↑DLCO), which is not consistent with this case.

 

Option D. COPD: Characterized by ↓FEV1, ↓FEV1/FVC, ↑TLC (due to air trapping), and ↓DLCO. Pimax may be slightly reduced but not as severely as in neuromuscular conditions.

 

Educational Objective:


A restrictive PFT pattern with normal DLCO and significantly decreased inspiratory pressure (Pimax) is highly suggestive of respiratory muscle weakness, distinguishing it from interstitial lung diseases or chest wall abnormalities.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about pleomorphic adenoma is incorrect? 

 

  1. The tumor commonly shows the presence of myoepithelial cells, contributing to its biphasic nature.
  2. Areas of chondroid (cartilage-like) differentiation are frequently observed on microscopy.
  3. Keratin pearls are a classic histological hallmark of pleomorphic adenoma.
  4. Although benign, pleomorphic adenomas can sometimes show perineural invasion or recur if incompletely excised.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only statement 3 is incorrect

 

Statement 3 - Keratin pearls are not a feature of pleomorphic adenoma. They are characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma, where concentric layers of keratin are produced by malignant squamous cells. This feature is not seen in pleomorphic adenoma, which is a benign mixed tumor.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1 - Myoepithelial cells: True. Pleomorphic adenoma is called a mixed tumor because it contains both epithelial and myoepithelial components, contributing to its histologic diversity.

 

Statement 2 - Chondroid differentiation: True. The tumor often displays mesenchymal-like stroma, including chondroid (cartilage-like), myxoid, or osseous elements. This is a classic and diagnostic feature.

 

Statement 4 - Perineural invasion: True. Though rare and typically associated with malignant tumors, benign pleomorphic adenomas can show perineural involvement, especially when large or recurrent. This can complicate surgical resection and contribute to recurrence if margins are inadequate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign salivary gland tumor characterized by both epithelial and myoepithelial cells, often displaying chondroid or myxoid stroma. It does not show keratin pearls, which are specific to squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 36-year-old HIV-positive man with a CD4 count of 170 cells/mm³ presents for routine follow-up. He is asymptomatic and currently not on any prophylactic medications. The physician initiates therapy with a combination drug that inhibits sequential steps in folate metabolism. Which of the following infections is this medication most likely prescribed to prevent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP)

 

  • Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim–Sulfamethoxazole) is the first-line prophylactic and treatment agent for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP), particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS.
    • The drug combines two agents that block folate synthesis at different steps:
      • Sulfamethoxazole inhibits dihydropteroate synthase
      • Trimethoprim inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • Prophylaxis is indicated in HIV-positive patients with a CD4 count <200 cells/mm³, or in others who are immunosuppressed (e.g., transplant patients, chemotherapy).

 

Note:

 

Cotrimoxazole is drug of choice for:

 

  1. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
  2. Nocardia
  3. Burkholderia cepacia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis: Prophylaxis usually involves fluconazole. Cotrimoxazole is not used for this fungal infection.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC): Prevented with azithromycin or clarithromycin in patients with CD4 <50 cells/mm³. Cotrimoxazole is ineffective.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii encephalitis: Prophylaxis is typically needed at CD4 <100 and is done with cotrimoxazole, but only if IgG seropositive. However, PJP prophylaxis is the first indication once CD4 <200.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim–Sulfamethoxazole) is the drug of choice for prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in HIV patients with CD4 <200 cells/mm³. It inhibits folate synthesis at two distinct steps.

questions.text: You are evaluating the developmental progress of an infant during a routine well-child visit. You are shown a set of images that represent different developmental milestones achieved at different ages. Arrange the milestones in the correct order based on their typical age of appearance, starting from the earliest to the latest.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) D-A-C-B

 

  • Image D: Rounded back on sitting (3 months): This is an early gross motor milestone; infants at this age cannot sit erect and show a rounded back when supported in a sitting position.
  • Image A: Mouthing (5 months): Mouthing is a part of early exploration through oral means, typically occurring around 5 months.
  • Image C: Pivoting (9 months): Pivoting is part of gross motor development that typically appears around 9-10 months as the infant starts to move on the floor.
  • Image B: Scribbling (15 months): Scribbling is a fine motor milestone, developing around 15 months when a child begins to explore drawing/writing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Developmental milestones follow a sequential and predictable pattern. Recognizing the typical age of acquisition of motor and fine motor skills is essential for early identification of developmental delay.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with lower back pain radiating down the left leg, worse on coughing. On exam, he has a positive straight leg raise at 30°, and weakness of dorsiflexion of the big toe. Which nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L5

 

  • Motor involvement:
    • Big toe dorsiflexion (extensor hallucis longus) → L5
    • Also supplies foot dorsiflexors and invertors (tibialis anterior partially), gluteus medius (hip abduction)
  • Sensory loss:
    • Lateral leg and dorsum of the foot, especially 1st web space
  • Reflexes:
    • Usually, no deep tendon reflex is associated directly with L5, but there may be a subtle decrease in medial hamstring reflex.
    • Big toe dorsiflexion = hallmark motor function of L5 root


Other Options:

 

Option A. L3 nerve root:

 

  • Motor involvement:
    • Quadriceps (knee extension)
    • Hip flexors (iliopsoas) — L2-L3
  • Sensory:
    • Anterior thigh
  • Reflex affected:
    • Patellar reflex (L3-L4)
    • L3 lesion causes anterior thigh symptoms, not sciatic distribution or dorsiflexion weakness.

 

Option B. L4 nerve root:

 

  • Motor involvement:
    • Quadriceps (knee extension)
    • Ankle dorsiflexion (tibialis anterior)
  • Sensory:
    • Medial leg and medial foot
  • Reflex affected:
    • Patellar reflex
    • L4 may cause mild dorsiflexion issues but not isolated big toe dorsiflexion weakness. Pain distribution is also more anterior/medial, not down the lateral leg.

 

Option D. S1 nerve root:

 

  • Motor involvement:
    • Plantarflexion (gastrocnemius, soleus)
    • Gluteus maximus (hip extension)
  • Sensory:
    • Lateral foot and sole
  • Reflex affected:
    • Achilles reflex
    • S1 would cause difficulty standing on tiptoes, not lifting the big toe.



Educational Objective:

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the angle of the mandible on the left side
Inability to close the right eye
Loss of taste from the posterior third of the tongue

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with progressive swelling in her right cheek over the past 6 months, accompanied by mild facial asymmetry. She has a history of smoking and reports occasional difficulty moving the right side of her face. On examination, there is a firm, non-tender mass anterior to the ear at the angle of the mandible. Fine needle aspiration confirms a diagnosis of mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the parotid gland. A right-sided total parotidectomy is planned. Following surgery, which of the following is the patient most likely to experience?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inability to close the right eye

 

  • The facial nerve (CN VII) passes through the parotid gland but does not innervate it. During a total parotidectomy, especially when excising malignant tumors such as mucoepidermoid carcinoma, the facial nerve is at significant risk of injury.
