  • Damage to this nerve, particularly its temporal and zygomatic branches, may lead to inability to close the eye, loss of forehead wrinkling, deviation of angle of mouth, loss of power in lower lip, and flattening of the nasolabial fold on the affected side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of sensation over the angle of the mandible on the left side:  It is mediated by the great auricular nerve, not CN VII. While it runs close to the surgical site, it is not the primary concern post-parotidectomy. Injury to the great auricular nerve can lead to Frey’s Syndrome on the ipsilateral side 

 

Option B. Difficulty protruding the tongue: It is seen in hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) injury, not facial nerve injury.

 

Option D. Loss of taste from the posterior third of the tongue: It is supplied by CN IX (glossopharyngeal nerve). Facial nerve supplies taste from the anterior 2/3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Injury to the facial nerve (CN VII) is the most feared complication of parotid gland surgery, leading to ipsilateral facial muscle weakness, especially inability to close the eye and wrinkle the forehead.

choices.text: Instruct the patient to skip the next 3 doses of warfarin and discharge home
Hold warfarin and administer fresh frozen plasma
Hold warfarin and administer subcutaneous vitamin K
Hold warfarin and administer oral vitamin K

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman from Nagpur with atrial fibrillation on chronic warfarin therapy presents for routine anticoagulation monitoring. She reports feeling well, with no history of recent trauma, bleeding gums, hematuria, or melena. She has a known past history of peptic ulcer disease but no active gastrointestinal symptoms currently. She is hemodynamically stable. Her rest of the laboratory results are as follow:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hold warfarin and administer oral vitamin K

 

  • Patients with INR >10 without active bleeding are at high risk for spontaneous hemorrhage and require active reversal of warfarin effect.
  • Oral vitamin K (2.5–5 mg) is the preferred route for safe and effective correction in such asymptomatic cases.
  • Oral administration leads to predictable absorption, avoids complications of intravenous (e.g., anaphylaxis), and is faster acting than subcutaneous injection.
  • Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) or prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) are reserved for patients with major bleeding or those requiring urgent invasive procedures.
  • Simply withholding warfarin without administering vitamin K is inadequate when the INR exceeds 10, given the bleeding risk.
  • Subcutaneous vitamin K absorption is unpredictable and variable, making it unsuitable for reliable reversal.

 

Management Strategy Based on INR and Bleeding Status:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Instruct the patient to skip the next 3 doses of warfarin and discharge home: Insufficient for INR >10; requires active reversal with vitamin K.

 

Option B. Hold warfarin and administer fresh frozen plasma: Used only when active major bleeding is present or immediate reversal is necessary.

 

Option C. Hold warfarin and administer subcutaneous vitamin K: Poor, unpredictable absorption; inferior to oral administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with an INR >10 without active bleeding, warfarin should be withheld and oral vitamin K administered to safely and effectively reduce the risk of spontaneous hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient came to the OPD after a fall on his hand. He is now experiencing pain in the hand region. The X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the type of joint marked in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ellipsoid joint

 

  • In the provided X-ray, the joint displayed is the radiocarpal joint (wrist joint), which is an ellipsoid joint. 
  • This joint is located between the radius and the proximal carpal bones (mainly the scaphoid and lunate).
  • Ellipsoid joints are characterized by their oval-shaped articular surfaces, which allow movement in two planes—flexion/extension and abduction/adduction. 
  • This structure is ideal for the wrist, enabling a wide range of motion but limiting rotational movements, which are instead handled by the distal radioulnar joint.

 

Key points from the X-ray:

 

  • The radius can be seen articulating with the scaphoid and lunate bones of the wrist.
  • This type of joint is classically referred to as an ellipsoid joint because of its shape and movement.

 

Mnemonic for Carpal Bones:

 

 

  • To remember the carpal bones seen on the X-ray, you can use the mnemonic: "Shyam Lal Tinde Pakao Tumhare Tinde Kacche Hai". These bones, in order, are:
    • Scaphoid
    • Lunate
    • Triquetrum
    • Pisiform
    • Trapezium
    • Trapezoid
    • Capitate
    • Hamate
  • This mnemonic helps recall the carpal bones in sequence, which are crucial for understanding the anatomy of the wrist joint.
  • The radiocarpal joint allows ellipsoid joint movements like flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction, but not rotation. Therefore, it fits the criteria of an ellipsoid joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hinge joint: Hinge joints, like the elbow, permit movement in only one plane (flexion and extension). This type of joint is not seen in the wrist.

 

Option B. Ball-and-socket joint: These joints, such as the shoulder and hip, allow movement in multiple planes (flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and rotation). The wrist joint, however, does not fit this description.

 

Option D. Saddle joint: The saddle joint is found at the first carpometacarpal joint (thumb), where the first metacarpal and trapezium articulate, allowing for a greater range of motion. This joint is not visible in the provided X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The radiocarpal joint or wrist joint is an ellipsoid joint that allows movement in two planes—flexion/extension and abduction/adduction. 
  • This joint involves the articulation between the radius and the proximal carpal bones (scaphoid and lunate).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with his first generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He recently immigrated from rural Honduras. He has no history of trauma, alcohol use, or chronic medical illness. On examination, he is postictal but arousable. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurocysticercosis

 

  • The CT image shows a well-defined cystic lesion with an eccentric hyperdense nodule, known as the "dot sign" — representing the scolex of Taenia solium larva. Surrounding edema is also visible, consistent with the colloidal-vesicular stage of neurocysticercosis.
  • Neurocysticercosis is the most common parasitic infection of the CNS, especially in individuals from Latin America, Southeast Asia, and sub-Saharan Africa. It often presents with new-onset seizures in young adults from endemic areas. Imaging is diagnostic, especially when the scolex is visible, confirming the presence of the larval cyst.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Brain abscess: Often larger ring-enhancing but typically lacks a central scolex. Patients also present 



Option C. Glioblastoma multiforme: Usually appears as an irregular ring-enhancing mass with necrotic center and significant edema. It is not cystic with a scolex and usually presents in older adults.

 

Option D. Toxoplasmosis: Seen in immunocompromised patients, particularly with HIV/AIDS. Lesions are typically multiple ring-enhancing without a scolex and are more commonly located in the basal ganglia or corticomedullary junction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis should be suspected in patients from endemic regions presenting with seizures and CT findings of cystic brain lesions with a central scolex (dot sign).

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is true, but the Reason is false
Assertion is false, but the Reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Antigenic drift results in a gradual, sequential change in the antigenic structure of the influenza virus.

 

Reason (R): The new antigens formed by antigenic drift are completely unrelated to the previous viral antigens.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true, but the Reason is false

 

  • Antigenic drift is a true phenomenon involving gradual point mutations in the genes encoding hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) surface proteins of the influenza virus.
  • This leads to small, sequential antigenic changes, allowing the virus to partially escape host immune recognition, which contributes to seasonal epidemics of influenza.
  • The Reason is false because:
    • The antigens formed via drift are similar but not identical to previous strains.
    • Therefore, antibodies to previous strains may partially neutralize the new variants, although not completely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigenic drift causes small, gradual changes in viral antigens that contribute to seasonal influenza outbreaks; however, the resulting antigens remain partially related to their predecessors.

choices.text: Shifting from a defined-benefit pension system to a defined-contribution pension system
Reducing healthcare access for the elderly to lower medical costs
Implementing tax cuts to encourage higher birth rates
Increasing investment in AI and automation to replace elderly workers

questions.text: Which of the following interventions would be most effective in mitigating the economic impact of a rising Old Age Dependency Ratio (OADR) in a rapidly aging country?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shifting from a defined-benefit pension system to a defined-contribution pension system

 

A rising Old Age DR (>65 year old) puts strain on government-funded pension systems. Transitioning to a defined-contribution system (where individuals save for their own retirement) reduces the long-term financial burden on the government while still providing retirement security.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Reducing healthcare access for the elderly to lower medical costs: Incorrect, reducing healthcare for the elderly is unethical and could increase healthcare costs in the long run.


Option C. Implementing tax cuts to encourage higher birth rates: Incorrect, Higher birth rates provide long-term solutions but do not immediately mitigate rising OADR.


Option D. Increasing investment in AI and automation to replace elderly workers: Incorrect, AI and automation assist productivity but do not directly impact dependency ratios.


Educational Objective:

 

Shifting from a defined-benefit to a defined-contribution pension system is an effective strategy to reduce financial strain from a rising Old Age DR.

questions.text: A 31-year-old postpartum woman from Delhi presents to the emergency department with acute-onset confusion and bleeding gums, occurring 7 days after receiving multiple blood transfusions during labor. She is febrile, and her GCS is 12/15. Examination reveals lesions as shown in the image below. Initial labs show hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL and a platelet count of 4,000/μL. CT brain reveals an intracerebral hemorrhage without mass effect. Despite transfusion of 10 units of platelets over the last 24 hours, there has been no improvement in the platelet count. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

 

  • This clinical scenario is highly characteristic of post-transfusion purpura (PTP), an alloimmune thrombocytopenia occurring 5–10 days after transfusion, most often in multiparous women sensitized to human platelet antigen (HPA)-1a.
  • PTP is caused by the formation of alloantibodies against platelet antigens, leading to destruction of both transfused and autologous platelets.
  • It presents with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/µL), purpura, and often life-threatening bleeding, typically unresponsive to platelet transfusions.
  • IVIG is the treatment of choice and rapidly raises platelet counts by blocking Fc receptors on macrophages, thus reducing immune-mediated clearance.
  • Corticosteroids and rituximab may be used in refractory cases, but are not first-line in acute, life-threatening thrombocytopenia.
  • Exchange transfusion is not effective and reserved only for extreme or refractory cases.

 

Diagnostic Clues for Post-Transfusion Purpura:

 

 

Management Comparison:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-dose corticosteroids: May help in chronic immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), but IVIG works faster and is preferred in acute, life-threatening bleeding.

 

Option C. Exchange transfusion: Considered only in rare, refractory PTP with ongoing hemorrhage — not first-line.

 

Option D. Rituximab: Useful for long-term antibody suppression in chronic or refractory cases, not acute management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-transfusion purpura presents with severe thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage 5–10 days after transfusion, especially in multiparous women. IVIG is the first-line treatment, as platelet transfusions are typically ineffective due to ongoing alloimmune destruction.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme/diagnostic marker pairs is incorrectly matched with its associated disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta Glucocerebrosidase – Von Gierke’s disease

 

  • Beta-glucocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher's disease, a lysosomal storage disorder. 
  • Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is due to glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, not beta-glucocerebrosidase.


Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceruloplasmin – Hepatolenticular degeneration: Correct. Hepatolenticular degeneration is another name for Wilson's disease, where ceruloplasmin levels are decreased due to defective copper transport.

 

Option C. High LDH1/LDH2 – Myocardial infarction: Correct. An elevated LDH1/LDH2 ratio (called a “flipped ratio”) is a classic marker of myocardial infarction, especially in settings where troponin is unavailable.

 

Option D. Lipase – Pancreatitis: Correct. Lipase is a sensitive and specific enzyme elevated in acute pancreatitis, and more reliable than amylase for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-glucocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s. Von Gierke’s is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. Recognizing enzyme-disease pairings is key in metabolic and diagnostic pathology.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with pruritic lesions on his thigh that have progressively enlarged over several weeks. On examination, the lesions are circular with a clear center and an erythematous, raised border. The lesions are as shown in the image. How would you best describe these lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Annular 

 

  • Annular lesions are characterized by their ring-shaped appearance, with a central area that is often clear and an active erythematous or raised border.
  • This pattern is typical in conditions such as tinea corporis (ringworm), which is consistent with the presentation of this patient.
  • The activity at the edge of the lesion (scaling, inflammation) helps distinguish it from other patterns.
  • In this case, the image clearly shows annular lesions with active edges and central clearing, which is the hallmark of this description. 
  • Annular lesions differ from discoid or nummular lesions because the latter have uniform involvement without central clearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nummular: Nummular (or discoid) lesions are coin-shaped with uniform involvement throughout the lesion. They do not have central clearing and active edges as seen in this case. Nummular eczema or discoid lupus erythematosus often have this presentation.

 

Option B. Target: Target lesions (as seen in erythema multiforme) are characterized by concentric rings with three zones: a central dusky or necrotic area, an edematous middle ring, and an outer erythematous border. This pattern is distinct and not seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. Discoid: Discoid (a synonym for nummular) describes coin-shaped lesions that lack central clearing or an active border. This term is used interchangeably with nummular but does not describe the annular pattern seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annular lesions are ring-shaped with active, erythematous borders and central clearing. They are most commonly associated with dermatophyte infections such as tinea corporis. This presentation differs from nummular/discoid lesions, which are uniform without central clearing, and target lesions, which have three distinct concentric zones.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding genital tuberculosis are correct? 

 

  1. Genital tuberculosis typically begins in the fallopian tubes and later spreads to other pelvic organs.
  2. Hysterosalpingography in genital TB shows findings such as cornual block and tobacco-pouch appearance.
  3. The most common causative agent is Mycobacterium leprae.
  4. A doughy abdomen on palpation and menstrual irregularities are common clinical features.
  5. A recurrent pelvic inflammatory mass in an unmarried woman is likely to be tubercular in origin.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Statements 1, 2, 4, and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1: Correct – Genital TB commonly begins in the fallopian tubes and spreads to the endometrium and ovaries.

 

Statement 2: Correct – HSG features include lead pipe tubes, beading, cornual block, tobacco-pouch appearance, and calcification.

 

Statement 4: Correct – Menstrual irregularities and a doughy-feeling abdomen are classic findings.

 

Statement 5: Correct – In an unmarried woman, a chronic recurrent pelvic mass is strongly suggestive of TB.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3: Incorrect – The causative agent is Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not M. leprae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital tuberculosis is a common cause of infertility and chronic pelvic inflammatory disease in developing countries. It classically involves the fallopian tubes and presents with menstrual irregularities, a doughy abdomen, and specific radiological findings like cornual block and tobacco-pouch hydrosalpinx.

questions.text: A child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive loss of central vision. Fundus examination is largely normal, and systemic examination is unremarkable. An electro-oculogram (EOG) shows an Arden Index <1.50. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Best’s Vitelliform Dystrophy

 

Best’s Vitelliform Dystrophy is an inherited macular dystrophy typically presenting in childhood with loss of central vision. It is associated with a reduced Arden ratio (<1.50) on electro-oculogram (EOG), which helps differentiate it from other maculopathies.

 

Key diagnostic clues:

 

  • Normal early fundus appearance
  • Central vision affected
  • EOG abnormal (Arden Index <1.50)
  • Family history may be present

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile macular dystrophy:  This is a vague, non-specific term and does not refer to a distinct clinical entity. Best’s disease is a more precise diagnosis when EOG shows an Arden ratio <1.50.

 

Option C. Retinitis pigmentosa:  Typically presents with night blindness and peripheral vision loss, not isolated central vision loss. Also associated with bone-spicule pigmentation, not seen here.

 

Option D. Macular cone dystrophy:  Affects central vision and cone function but EOG is typically normal, and other findings like photophobia and color vision defects are usually present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Best’s Vitelliform Dystrophy is a juvenile-onset macular dystrophy characterized by central vision loss and an abnormal electro-oculogram with an Arden index <1.50. It is an important differential for macular disorders in children.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents for a routine health check-up. He is asymptomatic and his vitals are within normal limits. His lab reports show a haemoglobin level of 13 g/dL. What is the estimated oxygen-carrying capacity of his blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 17 mL/dL


The oxygen-carrying capacity of blood is directly proportional to the haemoglobin (Hb) concentration. Each gram of haemoglobin binds approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen.

 

Formula to calculate oxygen-carrying capacity:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = Hb (g/dL) × 1.34 mL/g

 

Substituting the given value:

 

  • Hb = 13 g/dL
  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 13 × 1.34 = 17.42 mL/dL

 

Thus, the estimated oxygen-carrying capacity of this 19-year-old male is approximately 17 mL/dL

 

Educational Objective:


The oxygen-carrying capacity of blood can be calculated by multiplying haemoglobin concentration (g/dL) by 1.34 mL/g, the approximate amount of oxygen that each gram of haemoglobin can bind. This calculation is crucial for understanding oxygen delivery in clinical settings.

choices.text: A student who is angry with his teacher starts breaking furniture
A person who feels anxious starts excessive hand-washing
A man with aggressive impulses becomes a professional boxer
A woman who dislikes her mother constantly forgets to call her

questions.text: In the context of defense mechanisms, which of the following is an example of sublimation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A man with aggressive impulses becomes a professional boxer

 

  • Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism in which unacceptable or socially inappropriate impulses (e.g., aggression, sexual urges) are channeled into constructive, acceptable, and often socially valued activities. 
  • In this case, the man is transforming his aggressive impulses into a socially acceptable outlet — professional boxing — making this a classic example of sublimation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A student who is angry with his teacher starts breaking furniture: This is an example of acting out, where emotions are expressed through destructive or impulsive behavior instead of being processed adaptively.

 

Option B. A person who feels anxious starts excessive hand-washing: It may reflect an attempt to reduce anxiety through ritualistic behavior, not sublimation.

 

Option D. A woman who dislikes her mother constantly forgets to call her: This is an example of repression or possibly avoidance, where the mind unconsciously forgets due to emotional conflict.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sublimation is the transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse into socially acceptable behaviour. 
  • It is a mature defence mechanism. E.g. Vincent van Gogh transformed his emotional turmoil into expressive paintings, using art as a form of sublimation to cope with his struggles.

choices.text: Epigenetic silencing due to methylation error

questions.text: A 48-year-old male reports a gradual decline in memory and increasing difficulty with coordination over the past 6 months. His partner has also noticed personality changes and episodes of involuntary limb movements. His medical history is unremarkable, but his father and grandfather developed similar progressive neurologic symptoms at ages 50 and 55, respectively. Genetic testing is planned. Which of the following best describes the underlying genetic mechanism responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Expanded trinucleotide tandem repeat

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Progressive memory loss
  • Personality changes
  • Chorea (involuntary limb movements)
  • Poor coordination
  • Family history with earlier onset in successive generations

 

These findings are highly characteristic of Huntington disease, a neurodegenerative disorder inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. The disease is caused by an:

 

  • Expansion of CAG trinucleotide repeats in the HTT gene on chromosome 4
  • Anticipation (earlier onset in successive generations) is a hallmark feature, due to expansion of repeats during paternal transmission

 

The phrase “expanded trinucleotide tandem repeat” captures this exact mechanism and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epigenetic silencing due to methylation error: This mechanism is more relevant in disorders such as fragile X syndrome or Prader-Willi/Angelman syndromes, which involve imprinting or methylation errors, not Huntington disease.

 

Option C. Nondisjunction during meiosis: Nondisjunction leads to chromosomal aneuploidy (e.g., Down syndrome), not trinucleotide repeat expansion. It results in whole chromosome gains or losses, not progressive neurodegeneration with anticipation.

 

Option D. Large deletion in one gene: Conditions like Duchenne muscular dystrophy or alpha-thalassemia involve large gene deletions, not trinucleotide repeat expansions, and they don't typically show the pattern of anticipation or the specific neuropsychiatric presentation seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Huntington disease is caused by an expanded CAG trinucleotide repeat in the HTT gene. It presents with progressive cognitive decline, personality changes, chorea, and shows genetic anticipation due to further expansion of repeats in successive generations.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man from Pune with a known history of alcohol-related cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with increasing confusion, low-grade fever, and abdominal discomfort over the last 2 days. On examination, he is drowsy, oriented only to place, has flapping tremors, and a tense, distended abdomen. There is no history of hematemesis or GI bleeding. Laboratory tests reveal serum bilirubin 6.4 mg/dL and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL. Diagnostic paracentesis is performed, and the fluid appears clear. Ascitic fluid analysis has been performed and the report is shown below:

 

 

What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cefotaxime and IV albumin

 

  • The patient meets the diagnostic criteria for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) — defined as an ascitic neutrophil count ≥250/mm³ without an evident intraabdominal source.
  • He has tense ascites, fever, hepatic encephalopathy, and biochemical indicators of liver dysfunction, with bilirubin >4 mg/dL and creatinine >1.0 mg/dL.
  • Third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., cefotaxime) are the first-line antibiotics in SBP due to their excellent gram-negative coverage and ascitic penetration.
  • IV albumin (1.5 g/kg on Day 1, 1 g/kg on Day 3) is added to prevent hepatorenal syndrome (HRS), especially when bilirubin is >4 or creatinine >1.
  • Ciprofloxacin is used for SBP prophylaxis, not for treatment.
  • Meropenem is reserved for nosocomial or resistant organisms.
  • Lactulose is used to manage hepatic encephalopathy but does not treat SBP.

 

Key Diagnostic & Management Points in SBP:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin PO: Used for secondary prophylaxis of SBP, not for treatment of active infection.

 

Option C. Meropenem: Reserved for MDR or nosocomial SBP — not first-line in community-acquired SBP.

 

Option D. Fluid resuscitation and lactulose: Treat hepatic encephalopathy but do not address the underlying infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cirrhotic patients with ascitic neutrophil count ≥250/mm³, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis should be promptly treated with third-generation cephalosporins and IV albumin to prevent renal dysfunction and reduce mortality, especially when bilirubin and creatinine are elevated.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a complaint of persistent pain in his right tibia for the past 3 weeks. He reports mild swelling but denies fever or chills. The pain is localized and worsens with activity. Physical examination reveals tenderness and mild swelling over the anterior aspect of the tibia. There is no significant medical history, and his vital signs are normal. X-ray is given below, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brodie’s abscess

 

BRODIE’S ABSCESS

 

  • It is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long standing because of strong defence mechanism of body) 
  • Seen in immunocompetent host.
  • This intraosseous abscess is related to subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis. 
  • It usually involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis); e.g., Upper end of tibia
  • Classical Brodie’s abscess looks like a small walled off (sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.

 

 

  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative)
  • Treatment: Trial of injectable antibiotics is given; if it fails, curettage of the cavity is carried out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma: 

 

  • It is commonest benign true bone tumor. 
  • The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. 
  • Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). 
  • It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
  • D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. 
  • Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Intra-cortical hemangioma:

 

  • The bone hemangioma is a benign tumor that usually involves a vertebra or the skull and commonly is found as an incidental asymptomatic lesion.  
  • They are slightly less commonly encountered in men (M:F = 0.7:1) and most commonly seen in the 5th decade of life but can occur at any age. 
  • These tumors are slow-growing and are most commonly asymptomatic unless they exert mass effect on sensitive structures, present as a swelling or a palpable mass, especially in the skull.
  • Most commonly, they are located in the thoracic spine, followed by the skull and facial bones, followed by long bones where they preferentially involve metaphysis or diaphysis.

 

 

Hemangioma of proximal femur

 

Option D. Chondromyxoid fibroma:

 

  • Chondromyxoid fibroma is a rare lesion of cartilaginous origin. Although chondromyxoid fibromas may occur at any age, most commonly occur in patients of 10-30 years old. 
  • Any bone may be involved, but the proximal tibia is the most common location. In contrast to other cartilaginous lesions, radiographic evidence of intralesional calcification usually is absent. 
  • Treatment consists of resection or extended curettage.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows Brodie’s abscess, which is a long-standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone, seen in subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of irritability, depression, and peripheral neuropathy. She reports fatigue, headaches, and difficulty concentrating. Her medical history includes poor dietary habits and frequent alcohol consumption. On physical examination, she has glossitis (inflamed tongue) and cheilosis (cracks at the corners of her mouth). Blood tests reveal microcytic anemia with a low hemoglobin level. Given the neurological symptoms, her physician orders a urine test to assess the excretion of metabolites. The results show elevated levels of xanthurenic acid in the urine. Further assessment indicates a deficiency of a specific vitamin involved in amino acid metabolism. The physician explains that this deficiency disrupts tryptophan metabolism, resulting in the accumulation of xanthurenic acid. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is associated with increased urinary excretion of xanthurenic acid?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6 deficiency

 

  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is a crucial cofactor for the enzyme kynureninase in the tryptophan metabolism pathway. It helps convert tryptophan to niacin and other metabolites.
  • In the absence of adequate vitamin B6, tryptophan metabolism is disrupted, resulting in the accumulation of xanthurenic acid, which is excreted in the urine. 
  • Elevated xanthurenic acid is a specific marker for vitamin B6 deficiency. This deficiency can also lead to peripheral neuropathy, mood disturbances, and anemia due to impaired heme synthesis. 
  • Chronic alcohol consumption further exacerbates vitamin B6 deficiency by reducing its absorption and utilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1 deficiency: Vitamin B1 (thiamine) check RBC transketolase activity. Deficiency leads to beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, but it does not result in xanthurenic aciduria.

 

Option C. Niacin deficiency: Niacin deficiency results in pellagra — characterized by the "3 D's": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While niacin is synthesized from tryptophan, a vitamin B6 deficiency disrupts this pathway, leading to reduced niacin synthesis. However, increased xanthurenic acid excretion is specifically linked to a lack of vitamin B6.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2 deficiency: For Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) check RBC glutathion reductase activity. Its deficiency causes glossitis, cheilosis, and sore throat but does not elevate xanthurenic acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B6 deficiency disrupts tryptophan metabolism by impairing kynureninase activity, leading to elevated urinary excretion of xanthurenic acid and causing symptoms like peripheral neuropathy, mood disturbances, and microcytic anemia

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was evaluated for burning sensations in his feet and clusters of small, red-purple spots on his skin. Laboratory studies revealed protein in his urine. Enzymatic analysis revealed a deficiency of α galactosidase, and enzyme replacement therapy was recommended. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fabry disease

 

Fabry disease is caused by a deficiency of α-galactosidase A, leading to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide in various tissues. It is the only X-linked sphingolipidosis.
 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Burning pain in the extremities (acroparesthesias)
  • Red-purple skin rash (angiokeratomas)
  • Renal involvement (proteinuria, progressive kidney failure)
  • Cardiac complications (hypertrophy, arrhythmias)
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms and cerebrovascular disease can also occur.

 

Early enzyme replacement therapy can help prevent irreversible damage to the kidneys, heart, and nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Farber Disease:

 

  • Caused by a deficiency of ceramidase.
  • Presents with painful swollen joints, subcutaneous nodules, and hoarseness.
  • Does not involve angiokeratomas, α-galactosidase deficiency, or burning foot pain.

 

Option C. Forbes Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III):

 

  • Caused by debranching enzyme deficiency.
  • Manifests as hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and muscle weakness.
  • It is a glycogen storage disorder, unrelated to sphingolipid metabolism.

 

Option D. Krabbe Disease:

 

  • Caused by galactocerebrosidase deficiency.
  • Features severe neurological deterioration, spasticity, and optic atrophy.
  • No angiokeratomas or renal proteinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fabry disease results from α-galactosidase deficiency, leading to systemic accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It presents with neuropathic pain, angiokeratomas, renal involvement, and cardiac complications; early enzyme replacement therapy improves outcomes and reduces organ damage

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought for evaluation of feeding difficulties and delayed developmental milestones. His presentation, Xray and ECG are as shown in the picture below. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acid maltase

 

The clinical scenario, chest X-ray, and ECG findings are classical for Pompe disease (Type II glycogen storage disease), which is caused by a deficiency of acid maltase (also called alpha-1,4-glucosidase).

 

Key findings:

 

  • Hypotonia and head lag → generalized muscle weakness
  • Frog-leg posture → due to muscle flaccidity
  • Cardiomegaly on chest X-ray → glycogen accumulation in myocardium
  • Tall QRS with short PR interval on ECG → due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • Infantile-onset Pompe disease → presents within first few months of life with progressive hypotonia, feeding difficulties, and heart failure.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphatase – Deficiency causes Von Gierke disease (Type I), characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and lactic acidosis; heart is not primarily involved.


Option B. Muscle phosphorylase – Deficiency causes McArdle disease (Type V); presents in older children/adults with exercise-induced muscle cramps and myoglobinuria.


Option D. Liver phosphorylase – Deficiency causes Hers disease (Type VI); primarily hepatomegaly and mild hypoglycemia without cardiomyopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pompe disease (Type II glycogen storage disorder) is caused by acid maltase deficiency, leading to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes. It presents in infancy with hypotonia, cardiomegaly, and heart failure, along with characteristic ECG changes (short PR, tall QRS) and is often fatal without enzyme replacement therapy.

questions.text:
Match the following cerebellar cells with their corresponding characteristics: 

 

Column A (Cerebellar Cells)

 

  1. Purkinje cell
  2. Golgi cell
  3. Basket cell
  4. Granular cell

 

Column B (Function/Location)

 

  1. Excitatory cell located in the granular layer
  2. Inhibits deep cerebellar nuclei via GABA; located in Purkinje layer
  3. Inhibits Purkinje cells; located in the molecular layer
  4. Modulates granule cells; found in the granular layer
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

  • Purkinje cell (1-B): The only efferent neuron from the cerebellar cortex; releases GABA to inhibit deep cerebellar nuclei.
  • Golgi cell (2-D): Inhibitory interneuron in the granular layer that modulates granule cell activity.
  • Basket cell (3-C): Inhibitory interneuron located in the molecular layer; inhibits Purkinje cells.
  • Granular cell (4-A): Small excitatory neuron found in the granular layer; sends axons to the molecular layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Purkinje cells are the principal output neurons of the cerebellar cortex and exert inhibitory control over the deep cerebellar nuclei through GABA, playing a key role in motor coordination.

choices.text: Normal pupillary size and absence of bradycardia

questions.text: Which of the following findings would most strongly suggest pyrethroid toxicity rather than organophosphate poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal pupillary size and absence of bradycardia

 

The correct answer is Normal pupillary size and absence of bradycardia, as this finding is more characteristic of pyrethroid toxicity and helps differentiate it from organophosphate poisoning.

 

  • Pyrethroids are synthetic insecticides that act primarily on voltage-gated sodium channels in nerves. While they can cause neurotoxic symptoms like tremors, seizures, and paraesthesia, due to excitation of CNS and PNS.  They do not cause significant cholinergic effects, so signs like miosis (pinpoint pupils), bradycardia, and secretions are generally absent.
  • Organophosphates, on the other hand, inhibit acetylcholinesterase, leading to accumulation of acetylcholine and a cholinergic crisis. This includes miosis, bradycardia, bronchorrhea, salivation, and fasciculations.

 

Hence, normal pupils and absence of bradycardia point away from organophosphate poisoning and suggest pyrethroid exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Excessive salivation and fasciculations: These are classic signs of organophosphate poisoning, due to excessive cholinergic stimulation. This option points toward organophosphates, not pyrethroids.

 

Option C. Acute respiratory distress and wheezing: While this can occur in both types of poisoning, it is non-specific. Organophosphates may cause this through bronchorrhea and bronchospasm, while pyrethroids may irritate airways, but this symptom does not clearly distinguish between the two.

 

Option D. Rapid improvement after atropine administration: Atropine specifically counters cholinergic effects, so a rapid response suggests organophosphate poisoning, where the toxic mechanism is cholinergic overstimulation. Pyrethroid poisoning does not respond significantly to atropine, as the mechanism is not cholinergic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal pupils and absence of bradycardia favor pyrethroid toxicity over organophosphate poisoning, which typically presents with cholinergic signs.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with progressive bilateral hearing loss. She reports hearing better in noisy environments, and denies any history of trauma or infections. Otoscopy reveals an intact tympanic membrane. Tuning fork tests show a Rinne negative result on the right and Weber lateralizing to the right. Which of the following statements regarding otosclerosis are true? 

 

  1. The most common site of pathology is the cochlear promontory.
  2. Paracusis Willisii is a feature seen in these patients.
  3. Schwartze’s sign is seen in active lesions and presents as a reddish hue on otoscopy.
  4. Audiometry typically shows a dip at 2000 Hz on bone conduction curve (Carhart’s notch).
  5. The preferred treatment is cochlear implant in all patients.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only statements 2, 3 and 4 are true

 

Statement 2. Correct: Paracusis Willisii is a feature of otosclerosis where patients paradoxically hear better in noisy surroundings.

 

Statement 3. Correct: Schwartze’s sign (also called Flamingo pink sign) is seen in active otosclerotic lesions, characterized by a reddish hue seen through an intact tympanic membrane due to hypervascularization.

 

Statement 4. Correct: On pure tone audiometry, a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve is seen. This is known as Carhart’s notch and is diagnostic of stapes fixation in otosclerosis.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Incorrect: The most common site of pathology in otosclerosis is the fissula ante fenestram, located just at anterior part of the oval window. This is where abnormal bone remodeling typically begins—not the cochlear promontory.

 

Statement 5. Incorrect: Cochlear implants are not the treatment of choice in all patients. The first-line treatment is surgery (Stapedotomy > Stapedectomy) in operable cases. Cochlear implants are reserved for advanced cochlear otosclerosis with severe sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 21-year-old man from Delhi is admitted to the ICU after sustaining severe traumatic brain injury following a road traffic accident. He remains unresponsive for over 48 hours despite ventilatory support. Clinical examination reveals absent brain stem reflexes with fixed dilated pupils. He has been receiving intravenous phenobarbital for seizure control, and current serum phenobarbital level is 21 mcg/mL (normal: 10–40 mcg/mL). MRI brain demonstrates diffuse cerebral edema with effacement of basal cisterns. What factor currently prevents the declaration of brain death in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum phenobarbital level

 

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all functions of the brain, including the brainstem. Diagnosis is strictly clinical but requires specific preconditions to be fulfilled before testing. The presence of CNS depressant drugs like phenobarbital can mimic brain death by suppressing neurological function. In this patient, the serum phenobarbital level remains within the therapeutic range (10–40 mcg/mL), thereby confounding the neurological assessment. Formal declaration of brain death cannot proceed until sedative effects have cleared. Diffuse cerebral edema on imaging supports catastrophic brain injury but is not sufficient alone for diagnosis.

 

Preconditions that must be fulfilled before brain death examination:

 

 

Clinical examination criteria for brain death:

 

 

If clinical testing cannot be completed, investigations are used:

 

 

Pathophysiology following brain death includes progressive systemic changes:

 

 

Brain death must also be differentiated from other conditions:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated intracranial pressure: Supports massive brain injury but does not preclude brain death declaration if other criteria are fulfilled.

 

Option B. Absence of brainstem reflexes: Required for diagnosis; not a barrier to declaration.

 

Option D. Fixed dilated pupils: An expected finding in brain death and not a contraindication.

 

Educational Objective:


Before diagnosing brain death, it is mandatory to exclude all reversible confounders such as CNS depressant drug effect, hypothermia, metabolic abnormalities, or neuromuscular blockade. The presence of therapeutic phenobarbital levels mandates delay of brain death testing until drug clearance is confirmed.

choices.text: CD 28 on MHC-1 and B7 on T lymphocytes
B7 on MHC-1 and CD 28 on T lymphocytes
B7 on MHC-1 and CTLA-4 on T lymphocytes
CTLA-4 on MHC-1 and CD 28 on T lymphocytes

questions.text: Peptide fragments are found to be presented to CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes via a major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC-I) molecule. What are the co-receptors on MHC-1 and CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes that leads to the activation of the T cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B7 on MHC-I and CD28 on T lymphocytes

 

T cell activation requires two essential signals:

 

  1. Signal 1: Recognition of the antigenic peptide presented by MHC-I on an antigen-presenting cell (APC) to the T-cell receptor (TCR) on CD8+ T lymphocytes.
  2. Signal 2 (co-stimulation): Interaction between co-stimulatory molecules — specifically, B7 (CD80/CD86) expressed on the APC and CD28 on the T cell.

 

Although MHC-I primarily presents antigen to CD8+ T cells, it is the APC that expresses B7, not the MHC molecule itself. This B7-CD28 interaction provides the second signal necessary for T cell activation.

 

Therefore, the correct co-receptors are B7 on the antigen-presenting cell (in context of MHC-I) and CD28 on the T lymphocyte.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD28 on MHC-I and B7 on T lymphocytes: CD28 is not expressed on MHC-I, and B7 is not present on T lymphocytes. The direction of expression is reversed.

 

Option C. B7 on MHC-I and CTLA-4 on T lymphocytes: While B7 is correctly on the APC, CTLA-4 is an inhibitory receptor, not a co-stimulatory one. CTLA-4 dampens T cell activation rather than promotes it.

 

Option D. CTLA-4 on MHC-I and CD28 on T lymphocytes: CTLA-4 is expressed on T cells, not on MHC-I. This pairing does not reflect the correct biology of T cell activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Co-stimulatory activation of CD8+ T lymphocytes requires B7 (CD80/86) on antigen-presenting cells and CD28 on T cells, in addition to peptide-MHC-I–TCR interaction.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD): 

 

  1. Patients recognize their obsessions as irrational
  2. Compulsions reduce anxiety caused by obsessions
  3. Insight is always absent in OCD
  4. Exposure and response prevention is a first-line therapy

 

Which of the above statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, and 4

 

Statement 1. Patients recognize their obsessions as irrational: Correct. Most individuals with OCD have good insight, meaning they recognize that their obsessions and compulsions are excessive or unreasonable, although this insight can vary.

 

Statement 2. Compulsions reduce anxiety caused by obsessions: Correct. Compulsions are repetitive behaviors or mental acts performed to neutralize or reduce the distress caused by obsessions.

 

Statement 4. Exposure and response prevention is a first-line therapy: Correct.
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), specifically Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), is a first-line treatment for OCD, along with SSRIs.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Insight is always absent in OCD: Insight is not always absent. In fact, OCD is typically associated with preserved insight, although in some cases (especially in children or severe OCD), insight may be poor or absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • OCD is characterized by obsessions (intrusive thoughts) and compulsions (ritualistic behaviors), often with preserved insight. 
  • ERP-based CBT and SSRIs are the mainstay of treatment. Insight can vary, but it is not always absent.

choices.text: Highly likely to have colorectal cancer given the test’s high sensitivity.
Confirm with additional diagnostic tests due to the potential for false positives.
Begin immediate cancer treatment based on the positive result.
Dismiss the positive result due to low cancer prevalence.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with no family history of colorectal cancer undergoes a screening colonoscopy due to his age. The test, which has a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 90%, shows a positive result. Given the general population prevalence of colorectal cancer at his age is approximately 1.5%, how should the positive result be interpreted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Confirm with additional diagnostic tests due to the potential for false positives.

 

  • Despite the high sensitivity and specificity of the screening test, the relatively low prevalence of colorectal cancer significantly impacts the positive predictive value. 
  • This means that while the test is a good initial screening tool, a positive result at this prevalence still carries a considerable chance of being a false positive. Therefore, further confirmatory tests, such as biopsies during a follow-up colonoscopy, are necessary to accurately confirm the diagnosis.


Other Options: 

 

Option A. Highly likely to have colorectal cancer given the test’s high sensitivity: Incorrect, because even a test with high sensitivity can yield false positives, particularly in the context of low disease prevalence.


Option C. Begin immediate cancer treatment based on the positive result: Incorrect, as initiating treatment solely based on a screening test without further confirmation can lead to unnecessary interventions.


Option D. Dismiss the positive result due to low cancer prevalence: Incorrect, because dismissing a positive result outright is not advisable without further investigation given the implications of a cancer diagnosis.


Educational Objective:

 

  • Even when a screening test for a condition like colorectal cancer shows high sensitivity and specificity, the prevalence of the disease significantly affects the interpretation of a positive result. 
  • Given the low prevalence, positive results should be confirmed with additional testing to ensure accuracy and prevent unnecessary treatment. This cautious approach helps in making informed and safe treatment decisions for patients.

questions.text: A clinical trial is evaluating the effectiveness of a new anticoagulant medication compared to standard therapy in preventing stroke recurrence among patients with atrial fibrillation. The study categorizes patients into two groups (new drug vs. standard therapy) and records the proportion of patients in each group who experience a stroke within one year. Which of the following statistical tests is/are appropriate for comparing these two proportions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fisher’s exact test

 

  • When comparing two proportions (categorical data), the appropriate statistical tests are the Chi-square test and Fisher’s exact test.
  • Chi-square test is used when sample sizes are large (n > 5 in each cell of the contingency table) and compares expected vs. observed frequencies.
  • Fisher’s exact test is preferred when sample sizes are small (n < 5 in any cell) since it provides an exact probability calculation.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Paired t-test:

 

  • The t-test is used for continuous numerical data, not categorical proportions.
  • The paired t-test is used for comparing means within the same group (before-and-after studies), not between two independent groups.


Option B. Unpaired t-test:

 

  • The unpaired (independent) t-test compares means between two independent groups, which is not applicable when comparing proportions.

     

Option C.  ANOVA:

 

  • ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used to compare means across three or more groups and is not applicable for categorical proportions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When comparing two proportions (categorical data), use the Chi-square test for large sample sizes and Fisher’s exact test for small sample sizes. T-tests and ANOVA are only applicable for continuous numerical data.

questions.text: A person fell off a bicycle and developed pain around the hip. On examination, the affected limb is shortened and positioned in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

 

  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury: 
    • Dashboard injury: Occur with axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction - seen as one sits in the front seat of the car.
  • The typical attitude of the lower limb would be a flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR).

 

 

  • Complications: AVN of femoral head, sciatic nerve injury, associated fractures of femoral head and acetabulum and also associated knee injuries.
  • Imaging Findings: 
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • CT scan is the best investigation to judge dislocation.
  • Treatment:
    • More the deformity is a sign that probably there is no associated fracture of acetabulum or femoral head/neck. These cases can undergo closed reduction under some sedation.
    • Reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior Dislocation of Hip:

 

  • It is less common than posterior dislocation. 
  • It is of 2 types. Type I: Pubic (femoral head lies superiorly) and Type II: Obturator (femoral head lies inferiorly). 
  • Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture (FABER) at the affected hip, with restriction of movement. 
  • Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type). Dislocation is usually seen on AP view. 
  • Treatment is reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

 

 

Option C. Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur:

 

  • The patients suffering from intertrochanteric femoral fractures are mainly of elder age group (> 60 years of age) with poor health condition & comorbidities. 
  • It is seen more commonly in males. 
  • The patient presents with severe pain, swelling & ecchymosis. There is tenderness present over the greater trochanter. 
  • The hip is externally rotated to > 45° (lateral border of foot touches the couch). There is > 1 inch of shortening in the affected limb. 
  • Broadening of greater trochanter is seen. The patient is unable to walk and SLR is also not possible. 

 

 

Option D. Fracture neck of femur:

 

  • Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. 
  • The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. They are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. 
  • In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. 
  • Risk factors include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. 
  • Displaced fractures put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. 
  • Non-operative management for these fractures is rarely the treatment course. 
  • Young patients with femoral neck fractures will require treatment with emergent open reduction internal fixation. 
  • Non-displaced fractures are treated typically with percutaneous cannulated screws or a sliding hip screw. 
  • With displaced fractures in less active elderly patients, the treatment is given by hemiarthroplasty and with more active individuals, total hip arthroplasty is done.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The limb position of flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR) is specific of posterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Hypersensitivity Reactions: 

 

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

Type I → d

 

  • Involves IgE binding to mast cells.
  • Subsequent exposure leads to degranulation → histamine release → allergic reaction.

 

Type II → c

 

  • Mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies binding directly to cellular antigens.
  • This activates complement, causing cell lysis or death.

 

Type III → b

 

  • Involves immune complex (antigen-antibody) formation.
  • Complexes deposit in tissues, triggering complement activation and inflammation.

 

Type IV → a

 

  • Cell-mediated immunity involving T helper cells (TH1).
  • These secrete cytokines that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells.
  • No antibody involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersensitivity reactions are classified into four types based on immune reactants and mechanisms: Type I (IgE, mast cells), Type II (IgG/IgM, cytotoxicity), Type III (immune complex deposition), and Type IV (T-cell mediated, delayed response).

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and neurological symptoms including wrist drop and fatigue. He works in a battery manufacturing plant. Laboratory studies show microcytic anemia and elevated blood lead levels. He is diagnosed with acute lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most appropriate chelation therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dimercaprol

 

  • Dimercaprol (British Anti-Lewisite, BAL) is a chelating agent used in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning, particularly:
    • Lead poisoning (in combination with EDTA)
    • Arsenic poisoning
    • Mercury poisoning
    • Gold poisoning
    • In severe cases of lead poisoning, particularly with neurologic involvement, Dimercaprol + EDTA is the treatment of choice. It works by binding metal ions through its sulfhydryl groups, forming stable, excretable complexes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillamine: Used primarily in copper poisoning (e.g., Wilson disease) and sometimes in mild lead poisoning, but not first-line for severe cases.

 

Option C. Deferoxamine: Chelates iron and is used in iron overdose or transfusion-related iron overload, not lead.

 

Option D. Sodium thiosulfate: Used in cyanide poisoning, not effective for heavy metal toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dimercaprol is a chelating agent used in the treatment of arsenic, mercury, and severe lead poisoning. In lead toxicity with neurologic symptoms, it is typically combined with EDTA for optimal effect.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with chronic stable angina is started on a medication that helps reduce myocardial oxygen demand without significantly affecting heart rate or blood pressure. He has already been optimized on beta-blockers and nitrates but continues to have exertional chest discomfort. The new medication works by inhibiting the late phase of the inward sodium current in ischemic cardiac myocytes. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ranolazine

 

  • Ranolazine is an antianginal agent used as add-on therapy for chronic stable angina. 
  • It works by inhibiting the late phase of the inward sodium current (late INa) in ischemic cardiac myocytes. 
  • This action indirectly reduces intracellular calcium, improving diastolic function and reducing myocardial oxygen consumption.
  • Ranolazine is unique because it:
    • Does not significantly reduce heart rate or blood pressure
    • Can be used in patients who are already on beta-blockers and nitrates
    • Is metabolized by CYP3A4, so caution is required with strong inhibitors or inducers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ivabradine: Selectively inhibits the funny current (If) in the SA node, reducing heart rate but not used primarily for angina in patients without heart failure.

 

Option C. Amlodipine:  A dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that reduces afterload and blood pressure, used in angina but affects BP, unlike ranolazine.

 

Option D. Isosorbide mononitrate: A long-acting nitrate that reduces preload and can cause reflex tachycardia; commonly used but not the correct mechanism described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ranolazine is an antianginal drug that inhibits the late inward sodium current in cardiac cells, reducing myocardial oxygen demand without affecting heart rate or blood pressure. It is useful as an add-on therapy for chronic stable angina.

choices.text: Proceed with MTP after obtaining the opinion of two medical practitioners
Inform her that MTP is mandatory for fetal anomalies beyond 20 weeks
Respect her autonomy and allow the pregnancy to continue if she wishes
Seek Medical Board approval and proceed with termination

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 22 weeks gestation is diagnosed with a fetal anomaly incompatible with life. However, she wishes to continue her pregnancy. According to the MTP Amendment Act, 2021, what is the most appropriate recommendation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respect her autonomy and allow the pregnancy to continue if she wishes

 

Under the MTP Act, 2021, while MTP is an option for substantial fetal anomalies, it is not mandatory. A pregnant woman has the right to continue her pregnancy if she wishes, and termination is only offered, not imposed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proceed with MTP after obtaining the opinion of two medical practitioners: Incorrect, MTP is not mandatory even if two doctors approve; the decision lies with the woman.


Option B. Inform her that MTP is mandatory for fetal anomalies beyond 20 weeks: Incorrect, MTP is never mandatory; informed consent is essential.


Option D. Seek Medical Board approval and proceed with termination: Incorrect, Medical Board approval is needed beyond 24 weeks, but MTP is still not mandatory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP for fetal anomalies is an option, not a mandate. A pregnant woman has the right to continue her pregnancy if she wishes, even in cases of fetal malformations.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents with painless hematuria. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender left flank mass is palpated that does not cross the midline. His blood pressure is elevated. Abdominal imaging shows a well-defined mass in the right kidney, and a nephrectomy is planned. The gross specimen from surgery is shown in the image. Based on clinical and gross findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nephroblastoma

 

Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is the most common renal malignancy in children.

 

Key clinical and gross features include:

 

  • Age under 5 years (typically 2–5 years old)
  • Painless abdominal mass that does not cross the midline
  • Hematuria, hypertension (due to renin production)
  • Grossly: Well-circumscribed, tan to gray, soft mass, often with areas of hemorrhage or necrosis
  • Microscopy: Triphasic (blastemal, stromal, epithelial components)

 

The presentation and gross appearance are classic for Wilms tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clear cell sarcoma of kidney: Though a pediatric renal tumor, it often metastasizes to bone and does not typically present with hypertension or a mass this large in such a young child. Gross appearance is also less typical.

 

Option C. Angiomyolipoma: Benign tumor composed of fat, blood vessels, and smooth muscle. More common in adults and tuberous sclerosis. Rare in infants and typically found incidentally.

 

Option D. Lymphoma involving the kidney: Uncommon as a primary kidney tumor in children. Kidney may be involved secondarily in systemic lymphoma, but mass effect is usually bilateral or diffuse, not a well-circumscribed unilateral tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) is the most common renal malignancy in children. It presents with a non-tender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline, hematuria, and hypertension.

questions.text:
Mesangial immune complex deposits are typically found in which of the following renal conditions? 

 

  1. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  2. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  3. Diabetic nephropathy
  4. Berger disease (IgA nephropathy)
  5. Minimal change disease
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4

 

1. Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) – Involves IgA immune complex deposition in the mesangium. It shares pathological features with Berger disease.

 

2. Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) – Certain types (like post-infectious and lupus-associated) involve mesangial and capillary immune complex deposition.

 

4. Berger disease (IgA nephropathy) –Classic example of mesangial IgA deposition.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

3. Diabetic nephropathy – Shows mesangial matrix expansion, but not immune complex deposits. It's a non-immune, metabolic/glomerulosclerotic condition.

 

5. Minimal change disease – Characterized by effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy. There are no immune deposits seen on immunofluorescence or light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mesangial immune complex deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy (Berger disease), Henoch-Schönlein purpura, and certain forms of immune complex–mediated rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman from a high-focus state undergoes tubectomy under the RCH program. Her health worker wants to know how much incentive an ASHA worker receives for motivating the patient. According to the Sterilization Incentive Package, how much is given to the ASHA worker for this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 200 INR

 

In 11 high-focus states, ASHA workers receive 200 INR for motivating and assisting a patient undergoing tubectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sterilization Incentive Package (RCH Program):

questions.text:
Match the Following: Congenital Hearing Disorders and Their Features:

 

Column A (Disorder)

 

  1. Michel aplasia
  2. Alexander dysplasia
  3. Mondini dysplasia
  4. Bing–Seibenmann dysplasia


 

Column B (Feature)

 

  1. Complete absence of membranous labyrinth
  2. Only 1.5 turns of cochlea formed; only basal coil present
  3. Basal turn of cochlea affected
  4. Complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinth
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A

 

1-D. Michel aplasia: Characterized by complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinth. It is the most severe form of inner ear malformation.

 

2-C. Alexander dysplasia: Involves the basal turn of the cochlea, leading to high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.

 

3-B. Mondini dysplasia: Only 1.5 turns of the cochlea are formed (normal is 2.5–2.75 turns), indicating an incomplete cochlear development.

 

4-A): Bing–Seibenmann dysplasia: There is a complete absence of the membranous labyrinth, while the bony labyrinth may still be present.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Amino acid activation by attachment to a tRNA
Correct alignment of the mRNA on the 40S ribosome

questions.text: During the process of protein synthesis, the factor eEF-2 induces the hydrolysis of GTP. The energy of this hydrolysis is coupled to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Translocation of the ribosome

 

The translation factor, eukaryotic Elongation Factor 2 (eEF-2), plays a critical role in the elongation phase of protein synthesis.

 

  • Specifically, eEF-2 catalyzes the GTP-dependent translocation of the ribosomes along the mRNA to the next codon after peptide bond formation.
  • Hydrolysis of 1 GTP by eEF-2 provides the energy required to shift the ribosome:
    • Moving the newly formed peptidyl-tRNA from the A-site to the P-site.
    • Freeing the A-site for the next aminoacyl-tRNA entry.

 

Without eEF-2-mediated translocation, the ribosome would stall, halting protein synthesis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acid activation by attachment to a tRNA:

 

  • This step is catalyzed by the family of enzymes called aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases.
  • It involves the attachment of an amino acid to its respective tRNA and uses  2 ATP, not GTP.

 

Option B. Correct alignment of the mRNA on the 40S ribosome:

 

  • Facilitated by initiation factor eIF-1 during the scanning process to locate the start codon (AUG).
  • This occurs in the initiation phase, not elongation.

 

Option C. Formation of the 80S initiation complex:

 

  • Happens after the complete assembly of the 40S preinitiation complex.
  • Requires the action of eIF-5, which helps join the 40S and 60S subunits.
  • Involves GTP but is distinct from the role of eEF-2.

 

Additional Note:

 

  • Formation of the peptide bond between amino acids is catalyzed by peptidyltransferase activity of the 60S ribosomal subunit.
  • This process does not require external energy from ATP or GTP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

eEF-2 drives the GTP-dependent translocation of the ribosome along the mRNA during peptide elongation, ensuring proper reading frame progression and continuous protein synthesis.

questions.text: A patient presents 2 years after total knee replacement with progressive knee pain and instability. ESR and CRP are normal. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aseptic loosening

 

  • Aseptic loosening is the most common long-term complication of TKR.
  • Caused by chronic micromotion, wear debris, and inflammatory response leading to osteolysis and bone resorption around the implant.
  • Seen radiologically as:
    • Radiolucent lines at implant–bone interface
    • Possible component migration or subsidence
  • Clinically:
    • Gradual onset of pain, instability, difficulty bearing weight
    • No systemic signs of infection
  • Labs: ESR/CRP are normal (helps differentiate from infection)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prosthetic joint infection (PJI):

 

  • Infection is a serious complication but less likely here due to:
    • Late onset (2 years), unless it's low-grade indolent
    • Normal ESR and CRP
  • Typical signs of infection:
    • Pain, swelling, fever, warmth
    • Elevated ESR/CRP, possibly positive joint aspirate culture
  • X-ray may show:
    • Osteolysis, periosteal reaction, joint effusion
  • Diagnosis often requires joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis
  • Not likely here: no systemic signs, and labs are normal.

 

Option C. Periprosthetic fracture:

 

  • Fractures around a prosthetic component (usually femur or tibia).
  • Presents with:
    • Acute pain, often after trauma or fall
    • Inability to bear weight
  • X-ray would show:
    • Clear fracture line around implant
    • Possible displacement

  • Risk factors: osteoporosis, loosening, trauma

     

Option D. Polyethylene liner dislocation:

 

  • Rare, but can occur in mobile bearing prostheses
  • Symptoms:
    • Sudden instability, locking, or pain
    • May feel or hear a "pop"
  • X-ray:
    • May show eccentric alignment of tibial component
    • Often needs advanced imaging to detect (CT or MRI with metal artifact reduction)
  • Not consistent: this case shows progressive, chronic symptoms — not sudden mechanical failure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A research scientist is designing an experimental vaccine in animal models to enhance the immune response. He chooses an adjuvant composed of an oil emulsion containing killed Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Which of the following best describes this adjuvant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Freund’s complete adjuvant

 

  • Freund’s complete adjuvant is composed of Freund’s incomplete adjuvant (a water-in-oil emulsion) plus killed Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli in the oil phase.
  • It is used to stimulate a strong cell-mediated immune response, particularly in research animals.
  • The inclusion of killed tubercle bacilli enhances antigen presentation and immunogenicity via activation of macrophages and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Freund’s incomplete adjuvant: Consists of a water-in-oil emulsion without mycobacterial components.

 

Option C. Alum-based adjuvant: Commonly used in human vaccines; promotes Th2-type (antibody) responses, not strong cell-mediated immunity.

 

Option D. Squalene-based adjuvant: Found in some human vaccine formulations (e.g., MF59), used for its immune-enhancing oil-in-water emulsion properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Freund’s complete adjuvant contains an oil emulsion and killed Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli, enhancing cell-mediated immunity and is primarily used in research models.

questions.text: A research team is evaluating the accuracy of a new rapid antigen test for tuberculosis (TB) compared to the existing gold-standard sputum culture test. They aim to assess the agreement between the two tests across multiple patient samples rather than measuring cause-and-effect relationships. Which of the following statistical methods is most appropriate for this type of analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Correlation analysis / Bland-Altman test
 

  • Bland-Altman analysis is a statistical method used to compare a new diagnostic test with a gold-standard test by assessing agreement between them rather than just correlation.
  • Correlation analysis alone is insufficient because it only determines the relationship between two variables, not their agreement.
  • Bland-Altman plots measure bias, agreement limits, and potential systematic differences between the two tests, making it ideal for validating new medical tests against an existing gold standard.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Regression analysis / Likelihood test: Incorrect,

 

  • Regression analysis is used to assess relationships between dependent and independent variables, not agreement between two diagnostic methods.
  • Likelihood ratios help determine test usefulness (e.g., positive and negative likelihood ratios for ruling in or ruling out disease), but do not compare two tests directly.
     

Option C. Baltin and Altimore method: Incorrect,

 

  • No such statistical method exists in medical research or biostatistics.

     

Option D. Kimorov and Samletor technique: Incorrect,

 

  • This is not a recognized statistical method for diagnostic test comparison.


Educational Objective:

 

The Bland-Altman test is the preferred method for comparing a new diagnostic test with a gold-standard test, as it assesses the level of agreement and potential bias between the two tests.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty in pinching objects and a positive Froment’s sign following a deep laceration to the medial aspect of the hand. On examination, thumb adduction is impaired. Which of the following muscles is referred to as the "graveyard of the ulnar nerve" due to its vulnerability in ulnar nerve injuries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adductor pollicis

 

  • The adductor pollicis is innervated by the ulnar nerve and is considered the "graveyard of the ulnar nerve" because it is one of the last muscles to be supplied by the ulnar nerve in the hand. 
  • Ulnar nerve injury compromises its function, leading to impaired thumb adduction. This is clinically tested using Froment's sign or the "book test."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis longus: Innervated by the radial nerve, responsible for thumb abduction.
 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus: Also radial nerve innervated, functions in thumb extension.
 

Option D. Extensor pollicis brevis: Radial nerve innervation, aids thumb extension—not affected by ulnar nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The adductor pollicis, supplied by the ulnar nerve, plays a crucial role in thumb adduction and is notably affected in ulnar nerve palsy, earning it the term "graveyard of the ulnar nerve."

questions.text: A patient with a history of consuming tobacco presents with a lesion on his tongue. It is 3 x 2 cm in size. Biopsy confirms the lesion to be a squamous cell carcinoma. Imaging reveals that the tumor depth is 12 mm, without invasion into the floor of mouth or mandible. What is the T stage of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T3

 

  • Tumor of size 3 x 2 cm with DOI of 12 mm is T3.
  • Tumors >4 cm in size, or those with DOI >10 mm, are classified as T3. 
  • In this case, the tumor has a DOI of 12 mm, which places it in the T3 category, regardless of its size.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T1: Tumors that are ≤2 cm in greatest dimension and have a depth of invasion (DOI) ≤5 mm fall under this category. Since the tumor is 3 cm in size and has a DOI of 12 mm, this stage does not apply.

 

Option B. T2: Tumors >2 cm but ≤4 cm in size, or those with DOI >5 mm but ≤10 mm are classified as T2. Although the tumor is within the size range for T2 (3 cm), its depth of invasion exceeds the upper limit of 10 mm, so T2 does not apply.

 

Option D. T4a: Tumors with invasion into adjacent structures, such as the floor of the mouth, mandible, or skin, fall into this stage. Since the imaging confirms no invasion into surrounding structures, T4a does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and generalized edema. Physical examination reveals sparse, easily pluckable hair, skin changes with hyperpigmented patches that appear to be peeling, and a protuberant abdomen. Her weight is 8 kg. Which of the following laboratory findings would you most expect to find?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low serum albumin

 

The clinical scenario describes a classic case of kwashiorkor, a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by edema (due to hypoalbuminemia), skin changes ("flaky paint" dermatosis), hair changes (sparse, easily pluckable), protuberant abdomen, and growth failure. Hypoalbuminemia is a hallmark finding in kwashiorkor due to protein deficiency and is directly responsible for the generalized edema observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Elevated serum albumin: This is incorrect because kwashiorkor is characterized by hypoalbuminemia, not hyperalbuminemia. The protein deficiency in kwashiorkor leads to decreased albumin synthesis by the liver.

 

Option B. Normal serum potassium: This is incorrect because patients with kwashiorkor typically have electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia. The total body potassium depletion requires supplementation at 3-4 mEq/kg/day during treatment.

 

Option C. Elevated serum sodium: This is incorrect because hyponatremia rather than hypernatremia is more common in kwashiorkor. This occurs due to fluid shifts and dilutional effects from the edema associated with low oncotic pressure.

 

Educational Objective:
