Hypoalbuminemia (<2.5 g/dL) is a cardinal laboratory finding in kwashiorkor and directly causes the edema through decreased oncotic pressure. This protein-deficiency state differs from marasmus (calorie deficiency) which lacks edema.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with atrial fibrillation is brought to the emergency department after a fall. He is confused, and CT scan reveals a small intracranial hemorrhage. He has been taking dabigatran for stroke prevention. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic agent to reverse the anticoagulant effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Idarucizumab

 

  • Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI), used as an oral anticoagulant primarily for:
    • Stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation
    • Treatment and prevention of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE)
  • In cases of life-threatening bleeding or emergency surgery, Idarucizumab is the specific reversal agent for dabigatran. It is a monoclonal antibody fragment that binds dabigatran with high affinity, neutralizing its anticoagulant effect within minutes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine sulfate: Used to reverse heparin and low molecular weight heparin, not effective for dabigatran.

 

Option C. Vitamin K: Reverses warfarin by aiding synthesis of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors. Has no effect on dabigatran.

 

Option D. Andexanet alfa: Reversal agent for factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., rivaroxaban, apixaban), not for thrombin inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor used as an anticoagulant. In cases of major bleeding, its effects can be rapidly reversed by idarucizumab, a monoclonal antibody fragment that specifically binds and neutralizes dabigatran.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man with liver cirrhosis and peripheral edema is started on a diuretic. Two weeks later, he presents with laboratory findings of hyperkalemia and non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spironolactone

 

  • Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and an aldosterone antagonist. 
  • It is commonly used in cirrhotic patients with ascites and edema, as it counteracts aldosterone-driven sodium and water retention. 
  • However, by blocking aldosterone in the collecting duct, it reduces sodium reabsorption and decreases potassium and hydrogen ion secretion, leading to:
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Non-anion gap (normal anion gap) metabolic acidosis
    • These are predictable adverse effects of aldosterone antagonism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetazolamide:  A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor acting in the proximal tubule. It causes bicarbonate loss, leading to metabolic acidosis, but it does not cause hyperkalemia (may cause hypokalemia).

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: A thiazide diuretic acting on the distal convoluted tubule. It causes hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, not hyperkalemia or acidosis.

 

Option C. Triamterene: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic like spironolactone, but does not antagonize aldosterone directly. It can also cause hyperkalemia, but spironolactone is the preferred agent in cirrhotic edema due to its aldosterone-blocking effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing aldosterone antagonist, is commonly used to treat cirrhotic edema and can cause hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis by inhibiting sodium reabsorption and reducing potassium and hydrogen ion excretion in the distal nephron.

choices.text: Purely Health Education, as it provides preventive guidance
Primarily Health Propaganda, as it emotionally influences behaviour
Neither Health Education nor Health Propaganda, as it lacks clear scientific instruction
Both Health Education and Health Propaganda, as it combines emotional appeal with preventive measures

questions.text: During a cholera outbreak, a government-run TV network broadcasts a dramatic re-enactment of a child dying from dehydration, followed by a public service message advising people to boil water and use oral rehydration therapy. Which of the following best describes this intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both Health Education and Health Propaganda, as it combines emotional appeal with preventive measures

 

  • The dramatic re-enactment triggers an emotional response (propaganda), while the preventive message provides actionable knowledge (education).
  • By integrating both methods, the campaign maximizes behavioural impact.


Other Options:


Option A. Purely Health Education, as it provides preventive guidance: Incorrect, Dramatic portrayal introduces propaganda elements.


Option B. Primarily Health Propaganda, as it emotionally influences behaviour: Incorrect, it also provides scientifically sound preventive strategies.


Option C. Neither Health Education nor Health Propaganda, as it lacks clear scientific instruction: Incorrect, despite dramatization, it delivers a clear health message.


Educational Objective:

 

Public health campaigns often integrate both propaganda and education to enhance compliance while ensuring informed decision-making.

Health Education vs. Health Propaganda

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man from Chennai presents with a 9-month history of progressive difficulty in speaking and swallowing. His wife reports that his voice has become increasingly nasal and slurred, and he has frequent choking episodes while eating. On examination, deep tendon reflexes are brisk in all four limbs. Power is reduced symmetrically in the upper extremities without significant sensory loss. MRI brain and cervical spine are unremarkable. A tongue image is shown below.

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis

 

  • This patient presents with classical bulbar-onset ALS, characterized by progressive dysarthria, dysphagia, nasal speech, and evidence of combined upper and lower motor neuron dysfunction.
  • The spastic, small tongue without fasciculations suggests predominant upper motor neuron (UMN) involvement in the bulbar region.
  • Brisk limb reflexes (hyperreflexia) further support UMN pathology.
  • ALS uniquely combines UMN signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia) and LMN signs (atrophy, weakness, later fasciculations).
  • MRI exclusion of other structural lesions strengthens the diagnosis.
  • Myasthenia gravis typically causes fatigable weakness without hyperreflexia or spasticity.
  • Medullary strokes can mimic bulbar dysfunction but would present acutely, not over months.
  • CIDP involves demyelination with hyporeflexia, not hyperreflexia.

 

Distinguishing ALS from other causes of bulbar dysfunction:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myasthenia Gravis: Would cause fatigable weakness without UMN signs like spasticity or brisk reflexes.

 

Option C. Lateral Medullary Syndrome: Would include sensory deficits, vertigo, nystagmus, Horner's syndrome, and crossed findings (ipsilateral face + contralateral body), which are not present.

 

Option D. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (CIDP): Typically causes symmetric sensorimotor symptoms with hyporeflexia, not hyperreflexia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar-onset ALS should be suspected in patients with progressive dysarthria, dysphagia, spastic small tongue, hyperreflexia, and absence of sensory involvement, especially when imaging rules out alternative structural lesions.

questions.text:
A patient presents with recurrent epistaxis and AV malformations detected in lungs, GI tract, liver, CNS, nasopharynx as shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the condition are true?

 


 

  1. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  2. The disease is characterized by mucocutaneous telangiectasias and arteriovenous malformations in organs like the GI tract, lungs, and CNS.
  3. A deficiency in elastic tissue within blood vessel walls leads to recurrent epistaxis.
  4. Bevacizumab, a VEGF inhibitor, has shown potential in managing this condition.
  5. Curative surgical excision of AV malformations is the mainstay of treatment.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, and 4

 

This is Osler-Weber-Rendu disease/ hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), is a rare, autosomal dominant genetic disorder that causes abnormal blood vessel formation. 

 

Statement 2 – True: The disease presents with mucocutaneous telangiectasias and AV malformations involving multiple organs like the GI tract, lungs, liver, spleen, CNS, and nasopharynx.

 

Statement 3 – True: Recurrent epistaxis is a hallmark feature due to the deficiency of smooth muscle and elastic tissue in the vessel walls.

 

Statement 4 – True: Bevacizumab, a VEGF inhibitor, is an emerging therapy being tried in refractory cases.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1 – False: Osler-Weber-Rendu is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, not recessive.

 

Statement 5 – False: Surgical excision is not curative and not the mainstay. Management is largely supportive, including propranolol, tranexamic acid, and laser ablation in selected cases.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: BOAA-induced neuronal apoptosis leads to late-onset neurodegeneration
Cumulative axonal dysfunction occurs due to persistent glutamatergic excitotoxicity
Latent demyelination of descending motor pathways worsens with age-related neurodegeneration
BOAA remains stored in fatty tissues and is reactivated under metabolic stress

questions.text: A 55-year-old man from a rural region presents with bilateral leg weakness and difficulty maintaining balance. His history reveals a high intake of Lathyrus sativus during food shortages decades ago. He was previously asymptomatic but now experiences spasticity, hyperreflexia, and gait abnormalities. Which of the following best explains why his symptoms manifested later in life?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latent demyelination of descending motor pathways worsens with age-related neurodegeneration

 

Lathyrism may initially be asymptomatic but can worsen due to age-related neurodegeneration.

 

  • Progressive degeneration of corticospinal tracts causes late onset worsening of motor function despite cessation of toxin exposure.


Other Options:
 

Option A. BOAA-induced neuronal apoptosis leads to late-onset neurodegeneration: Incorrect, BOAA does not cause direct apoptosis but excitotoxic injury.
 

Option B. Cumulative axonal dysfunction occurs due to persistent glutamatergic excitotoxicity: Incorrect, Glutamatergic excitotoxicity occurs early, not decades later.
 

Option D. BOAA remains stored in fatty tissues and is reactivated under metabolic stress: Incorrect, BOAA is not stored in fatty tissue and does not get reactivated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lathyrism can remain latent for years, with symptoms worsening due to age-related degeneration of previously damaged corticospinal pathways.


Food Adulteration Diseases

choices.text: Retain catheter and start low-molecular-weight heparin
Retain catheter and start systemic thrombolytics
Remove catheter and start empiric antibiotics
Remove catheter and start heparin drip

questions.text: A 65-year-old man from Lucknow with recently diagnosed small cell lung carcinoma is undergoing chemotherapy via a right subclavian central venous port. He presents with dull ache and swelling of his right upper limb that has gradually worsened over 2 days. He denies fever, chills, or erythema. The catheter site is clean, with good flow of medications. A bedside ultrasound of the right axillary vein is shown. There is no evidence of limb ischemia or phlegmasia. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retain catheter and start low-molecular-weight heparin

 

  • This patient has a catheter-associated upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (UEDVT), confirmed by ultrasound showing a thrombus in the axillary vein at a venous valve.
  • In patients with cancer and central venous catheters, the risk of thrombosis is elevated due to malignancy-associated hypercoagulability, vascular trauma, and stasis.
  • If the catheter is functioning and not infected, it should be retained to preserve venous access for ongoing chemotherapy.
  • Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) is the first-line treatment in hospitalized cancer patients with thrombosis, preferred over vitamin K antagonists or even DOACs in this context.
  • Systemic thrombolysis is reserved for life- or limb-threatening thrombosis, not stable DVT.
  • There are no signs of infection at the catheter site, so antibiotics are not indicated.
  • Unfractionated heparin drips are used less often now for stable outpatient DVT, and catheter removal is not warranted here.

 

Management Strategy for Catheter-Associated UEDVT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retain catheter and start systemic thrombolytics: Not indicated unless severe symptoms or impending limb compromise.

 

Option C. Remove catheter and start empiric antibiotics: No signs of infection (no erythema, pus, or fever).

 

Option D. Remove catheter and start heparin drip: Catheter removal not needed; LMWH is safer and more effective long-term in malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In catheter-related upper extremity DVT among cancer patients, the catheter should be retained if it is functional and uninfected. Anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin is the preferred first-line therapy.

choices.text: Insertion of a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (LNG-IUCD)
Trial of progestin-only pills for 3 more months

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) for the past two months. Her menstrual cycles have been irregular for the last year, and she has not reached menopause. She is obese (BMI: 32), and a recent transvaginal ultrasound revealed an endometrial thickness of 16 mm. She has not responded to a prior 3-month course of progestin therapy. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

In a peri-menopausal woman with abnormal uterine bleeding, the primary concern is to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma. The presence of risk factors such as obesity, failed medical management, and persistent bleeding increases the likelihood of endometrial pathology.

 

Indications for endometrial sampling include:

 

  • Age >45 years with AUB
  • Perimenopausal state with AUB
  • Risk factors for unopposed estrogen exposure (e.g., obesity, PCOS, tamoxifen use)
  • Failed initial medical therapy
  • Endometrial thickness >5 mm in postmenopausal women or >12 mm in premenopausal women on TVUS

 

Sampling may be performed via hysteroscopic guided endometrial biopsy (pipelle or aspiration) or dilation and curettage if required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insertion of a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (LNG-IUCD): While the LNG-IUCD is a highly effective treatment for AUB, especially when related to endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, it should not be the first-line step in a patient with:

 

  • Persistent AUB
  • Significantly thickened endometrium
  • Obesity
  • Failed prior medical management

 

Before initiating this treatment, it is critical to rule out malignancy, which can only be done through endometrial sampling.

 

Option B. Trial of progestin-only pills for 3 more months: Given the failure of a previous 3-month course of progestin therapy, repeating a similar medical regimen without first ruling out endometrial pathology would be inappropriate. Continued unresponsiveness can delay diagnosis and treatment of serious underlying conditions, such as endometrial cancer.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: While hysterectomy may eventually be indicated for definitive treatment in cases of confirmed endometrial carcinoma or complex atypical hyperplasia, it is not appropriate as the immediate next step. It is an invasive surgical procedure and should only be considered after tissue diagnosis. Diagnostic evaluation with endometrial sampling is necessary before proceeding to such an extensive intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In perimenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding, especially those who are obese, have increased endometrial thickness, and have failed prior progestin therapy, endometrial sampling is essential to evaluate for endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): The silhouette sign helps localize lung pathology on chest X-rays by identifying loss of normal anatomical borders.
 

Reason (R): Obscuration of the left heart border on chest X-ray suggests pathology in the lingula, which is part of the left upper lobe and lies adjacent to the heart.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

The silhouette sign is a radiologic concept used to determine the location of lung pathology by observing which normal silhouette (e.g., heart, diaphragm, aorta) is obscured. If the left heart border is not visible, it indicates that a lesion is present in the lingula of the left upper lobe, as this segment is in direct contact with the heart border.

 

Therefore, both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason accurately explains the assertion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The silhouette sign localizes lung pathology on chest X-ray by identifying obscured anatomical borders; loss of the left heart border indicates lingular involvement.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Automated External Defibrillators (AEDs) are correct? 

 

  1. An AED delivers a shock only when it detects a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.
  2. AEDs can be safely used on a person who has a pacemaker, but electrode placement should be adjusted to avoid direct contact with the device.
  3. An AED should be used on a person experiencing cardiac arrest even if they have a pulse, as it can restart the heart.
  4. It is safe to use an AED on a wet surface or in a puddle, as water does not interfere with the effectiveness of defibrillation.
  5. If the first shock from an AED does not restore a normal rhythm, CPR should be resumed immediately before delivering another shock.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1. An AED delivers a shock only when it detects a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia: AEDs are designed to deliver a shock only when a shockable rhythm (ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia) is detected. It does not deliver shocks in cases of asystole or normal heart rhythms. In such case, continue giving chest compressions and ventilation.


Statement 2. AEDs can be safely used on a person who has a pacemaker, but electrode placement should be adjusted to avoid direct contact with the device: An AED can be used on a patient with a pacemaker, but the electrodes should be placed at least 1 inch away from the pacemaker to avoid interference.

 

Statement 5. If the first shock from an AED does not restore a normal rhythm, CPR should be resumed immediately before delivering another shock: If the first AED shock does not restore normal rhythm, CPR should be immediately resumed for 2 minutes before another shock is delivered. Continuous CPR maintains circulation and improves the effectiveness of subsequent shocks. If there is no pulse, and the rhythm is shockable, another shock can be given.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. An AED should be used on a person experiencing cardiac arrest even if they have a pulse, as it can restart the heart: An AED should never be used on a person with a pulse. Defibrillation is only indicated for cardiac arrest with a shockable rhythm. If a person has a pulse, other interventions should be performed.

 

Statement 4. It is safe to use an AED on a wet surface or in a puddle, as water does not interfere with the effectiveness of defibrillation: AEDs should not be used on a wet surface or in a puddle because water is a conductor of electricity and may reduce the effectiveness of the shock or put rescuers at risk. If possible, move the patient to a dry surface before applying the AED.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • AEDs should only be used for cardiac arrest with a shockable rhythm, and CPR should be immediately resumed if the first shock fails. 
  • AED placement should avoid pacemakers, and wet environments should be avoided.

questions.text: The following documents are exceptions to oral evidence in court except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Postmortem reports

 

In Indian law, oral evidence is generally preferred, especially in medico-legal cases. While there are defined exceptions to the rule of oral evidence, postmortem reports are not one of them. The doctor who performed the postmortem must testify in court to interpret findings and undergo cross-examination. This is because PM reports often involve subjective assessments like cause and time of death, which require clarification and professional judgment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dying declaration: Incorrect. Dying declarations are an established exception, especially when the declarant is unavailable due to death.

 

Option C. Reports of Fingerprint Bureau: These are prepared by government forensic experts in their official capacity and qualify as documentary evidence. As such, they are considered exceptions to oral evidence and are admissible in court under statutory provisions.

 

Option D. Chemical Examiner's reports: These are official reports produced by chemical examiners (forensic scientists) as part of their official duties. Just like the others, they are accepted in court as documentary evidence and are exempt from oral testimony requirements, unless questioned specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exceptions to oral evidences (i.e. Documentary evidences allowed): 

 

  1. Dying declaration: Accepted in court as legal evidence in event of victim’s death. 
  2. Expert opinions expressed in a treatise: Expert opinions printed in books are accepted as evidence without oral evidence of the author.
  3. Deposition of a medical witness taken in lower court: Accepted as evidence in a higher court when it has been recorded and attested by a magistrate in presence of the accused who had an opportunity to cross-examine the witness.
  4. Report of certain government scientific experts: Admitted as evidence without their oral examination, e.g. reports of Chemical Examiner or Director of Fingerprint Bureau/Haffkeine Institute/CFSL.
  5. Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding: Admitted in a subsequent judicial proceeding when the witness is dead or cannot be found or is incapable of giving evidence or cannot be called without unreasonable delay or expense to the court.
  6. Public records: Birth and death certificates, and certificates of marriage.
  7. Hospital records: Routine entries, such as date of admission, discharge, pulse, temperature, etc. are admissible without oral evidence.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hospitalized man presents with profuse watery diarrhea that began 5 days after completing a course of clindamycin for pneumonia. He is afebrile, but appears mildly dehydrated. On physical exam, there is mild lower abdominal tenderness without peritonitis. The clinician suspects Clostridium difficile–associated diarrhea (CDAD) and sends a stool sample for evaluation. Which of the following is considered the best initial diagnostic approach for the detection of Clostridium difficile in this patient's stool?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

 

  • Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) often occurs after antibiotic use, especially with clindamycin, cephalosporins, or fluoroquinolones.
  • The preferred diagnostic approach is a two-step algorithm that begins with:
  • Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) detection: a sensitive marker for C. difficile antigen (but not specific).
  • Toxin A/B assay (EIA): provides specificity, detecting toxins responsible for disease.
  • If results are discordant (e.g., GDH positive, toxin negative), NAAT (e.g., PCR) is used as a tie-breaker to confirm active toxigenic infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aerobic culture of stool: Incorrect because C. difficile is an anaerobic organism. Aerobic conditions would not support its growth, making this method ineffective.

 

Option C. Glutamate dehydrogenase assay: While highly sensitive, it does not differentiate between toxigenic and non-toxigenic strains; using it alone can result in false positives.

 

Option D. Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) only: Although highly sensitive, NAAT alone can detect colonization in asymptomatic individuals, leading to overdiagnosis. Therefore, it's not recommended as a standalone test in all clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most reliable initial diagnostic strategy for Clostridium difficile infection involves a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase screening and toxin detection, with NAAT used as a confirmatory test when needed.

choices.text: Administration of misoprostol for medical management
Initiation of antibiotic therapy and observation

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman at 11 weeks gestation presents to the outpatient obstetrics clinic with complaints of heavy vaginal bleeding and crampy lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She has no fever or chills. On speculum examination, her cervix is dilated and products of conception are visible at the cervical os. A transvaginal ultrasound shows a collapsed gestational sac with no fetal pole in the uterine cavity. Her vitals are stable. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate surgical evacuation

 

This case represents an inevitable abortion, which is defined by:

 

  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Cramping
  • Open cervical os
  • Visible products of conception

 

The presence of an open os with visible products confirms that the pregnancy is nonviable and will not continue. The most appropriate management in this scenario is surgical evacuation (e.g., dilation and curettage or suction evacuation). This is done to prevent complications such as hemorrhage, infection, and retained products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management: Appropriate only when the cervix is closed, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Misoprostol: Used to induce expulsion when the cervix is closed. It is ineffective and unnecessary if the os is already open.

 

Option D. Antibiotics and observation: Not indicated in the absence of infection. Surgical management takes priority here due to the open os and retained tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In inevitable abortion with an open cervix and visible products of conception, the preferred management is immediate surgical evacuation to prevent complications such as bleeding or infection. Misoprostol and expectant management are considered only when the os is closed.

questions.text: All are long-term and reversible contraceptive except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tubal sterilization

 

  • Tubal sterilization is a permanent method of contraception, typically done via laparoscopy or mini laparotomy, involving occlusion, cutting, or removal of the fallopian tubes. Although termed “long-term,” it is not reversible under standard practice and is not classified under long-acting reversible contraception (LARC). 
  • Even though reversal surgery (tuboplasty) exists, it is complex, expensive, and has limited success rates. 
  • Hence, it is not intended as a reversible method.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Implanon: A subdermal implant containing etonogestrel, effective for up to 3 years. It is reversible, and fertility resumes quickly after removal. It falls under the LARC category and is a preferred method for women seeking long-term but reversible contraception.


Option C. IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device): Copper-containing device inserted into the uterus, effective for 5–10 years depending on the type. It is reversible fertility returns immediately after removal. It is one of the most widely used LARC methods in India under national family planning programs.


Option D. LNG IUD (Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD): A hormonal IUD that releases levonorgestrel, provides contraception for 5–7 years. It is reversible, with rapid return of fertility after removal. Also used to treat heavy menstrual bleeding, endometrial hyperplasia, and dysmenorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To distinguish between permanent contraceptive methods and long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs), which are emphasized in reproductive health programs for effective family planning with the option of future fertility.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Simcoe’s cannula

 

The instrument in the image is a Simcoe’s cannula, which is used in ophthalmic surgery — most notably for aspiration and irrigation during cataract extraction. It has a dual-port system connected to a syringe or tubing, allowing simultaneous irrigation and aspiration of lens material during extracapsular cataract surgery (ECCE).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratome:  A surgical blade used to make incisions in the cornea, especially during cataract surgery (phacoemulsification). It does not resemble the instrument shown.

 

 

Option B. Scleral punch:  Used in glaucoma surgeries (e.g., trabeculectomy) to create a small hole in the sclera. It has a punch-like appearance, unlike the cannula shown.

 

 

Option D. Wire Vectis:  A loop-shaped instrument used to deliver the lens nucleus in Small Incision Cataract Surgery (SICS) or ECCE. It lacks the tubing and dual-port structure seen in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simcoe’s cannula is a dual-function ophthalmic instrument used for irrigation and aspiration during cataract surgery.

questions.text: A patient presents with vesiculobullous lesions over body. A Tzanck smear is performed. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be diagnosed using this technique?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

 

  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile skin and blister formation due to defect in structural protein keratin. It requires diagnosis via skin biopsy with genetic testing, not a cytological test like Tzanck smear. Hence, Tzanck smear is not helpful in diagnosing EB.
  • Direct Immunofluorescence will be negative
  • They are characterised under mechanobullous disorders. There will be little bit of friction and they will produce bullous lesions.
  • The genetic defect will lie in the keratin

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bullous impetigo: Can be diagnosed with a Tzanck smear, which demonstrates acantholytic cells.

 

Option C. Herpes zoster: Tzanck smear may show multinucleated giant cells and acantholytic cells—hallmark findings of viral blistering infections like HSV or VZV.

 

Option D. Pemphigus: An autoimmune blistering disorder, pemphigus shows multiple acantholytic cells (Tzanck cells) on smear, making the test useful for its initial diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tzanck smear is a cytological tool useful in diagnosing blistering skin disorders such as herpes zoster, pemphigus, and bullous impetigo by identifying characteristic cellular changes. It is not used in diagnosing genetic conditions like epidermolysis bullosa simplex, where genetic testing is required.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of facial asymmetry and ear abnormalities. On examination, the child has a preauricular skin tag, limbal dermoids in the eye, and underdevelopment of one side of the face. The external ear is malformed. Based on the clinical features and image shown, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goldenhar syndrome


Goldenhar syndrome, also known as oculo-auriculo-vertebral (OAV) spectrum, is a congenital condition involving abnormal development of the eye, ear, and spine. Classic features include:

 

  • Limbal dermoids (benign growths at the eye limbus)
  • Preauricular skin tags or appendages
  • Ear anomalies (microtia, anotia)
  • Hemifacial microsomia – underdevelopment of facial structures on one side

 

It is a result of abnormal development of the first and second branchial arches.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Treacher Collins syndrome: Involves mandibular and zygomatic bone hypoplasia, downward slanting eyes, but not limbal dermoids or skin tags.

 

Option B. Pierre Robin sequence: Characterized by micrognathia, glossoptosis, and cleft palate, without ear or eye involvement.


Option D. Crouzon syndrome: Craniosynostosis with proptosis and midface hypoplasia; no skin tags or limbal dermoids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goldenhar syndrome presents with limbal dermoids, preauricular skin tags, hemifacial microsomia, and ear anomalies due to abnormal development of the first and second branchial arches.

choices.text: Remove the patch and use condoms until her next menstrual period
Reapply the same patch using additional adhesive
Apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week
Apply a new patch without additional contraceptive protection

questions.text: A 23-year-old sexually active female presents with a concern regarding her transdermal contraceptive patch. She reports that the patch had been partially detached for more than 24 hours, and she is unsure about what to do next. She is otherwise healthy and not on any medications. To maintain contraceptive efficacy, what is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week

 

  • When a transdermal contraceptive patch becomes partially or completely detached for >24 hours, it compromises the consistent hormone delivery required to prevent ovulation.
  • The safest and most evidence-based recommendation is to:
    1. Apply a new patch immediately, and
    2. Use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for the next 7 days to ensure continuous protection.
  • This strategy maintains contraceptive reliability while reducing the risk of unintended pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove the patch and use condoms until her next menstrual period: Incorrect.

 

  • This approach unnecessarily discontinues hormonal contraception and increases the chance of ovulatory rebound, risking pregnancy.
  • There is no recommendation to abandon the patch entirely unless contraindicated.

 

Option B. Reapply the same patch using additional adhesive: Incorrect.

 

  • A patch that has been detached for more than 24 hours should not be reused, as drug delivery may no longer be reliable.
  • Additional adhesive does not restore contraceptive effectiveness.

 

Option D. Apply a new patch without additional contraceptive protection: Incorrect. While applying a new patch is appropriate, backup contraception is also essential because the delay has potentially allowed for hormonal drop, which could trigger ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a transdermal contraceptive patch has been off or partially detached for more than 24 hours, a new patch should be applied immediately, and a backup method (such as condoms) should be used for 7 days to maintain contraceptive effectiveness.

choices.text: Quarantine the entire ship and administer prophylactic antibiotics to all passengers.
Implement rigorous sanitation measures and isolate symptomatic passengers.
Vaccinate all passengers and crew against norovirus.
Conduct environmental testing to identify sources of contamination.

questions.text: A norovirus outbreak has occurred on a cruise ship, affecting multiple passengers. As the medical officer on board, you are tasked with implementing a public health strategy to manage the outbreak effectively. Considering the modes of transmission and the setting, which of the following would be the most appropriate initial step to control the spread of the virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Implement rigorous sanitation measures and isolate symptomatic passengers.

 

  • The most effective strategy given the characteristics of norovirus, which spreads rapidly through contaminated food/water or/& direct contact with infected individuals and contaminated surfaces. 
  • Implementing rigorous sanitation measures addresses the environmental control of the virus, significantly reducing the likelihood of surface-mediated transmission. 
  • Isolating symptomatic passengers minimizes person-to-person spread, effectively reducing the outbreak's impact. 
  • This dual approach is pivotal in managing norovirus outbreaks in enclosed environments like a cruise ship, where the proximity of passengers can facilitate widespread transmission.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarantine the entire ship and administer prophylactic antibiotics to all passengers: Incorrect, because antibiotics have no effect on viruses such as norovirus. Quarantine without targeted isolation and sanitation might not prevent the spread among the passengers, as communal areas may already be contaminated.


Option C. Vaccinate all passengers and crew against norovirus: Incorrect, as there is currently no effective vaccine available for norovirus. Even if available, vaccines generally do not confer immediate immunity and thus would not be effective as an immediate response to an ongoing outbreak.


Option D. Conduct environmental testing to identify sources of contamination: Incorrect, while useful for understanding the spread and potentially improving long-term management, this action does not provide a direct or immediate solution to controlling the outbreak.

 

Educational Objective:


Effective sanitation and isolation are key to controlling outbreaks of highly infectious diseases like norovirus in settings such as cruise ships.

choices.text: Activation of classical complement pathway by immune complexes
Graft infiltration by CD8+ cytotoxic T cells

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with end-stage renal disease undergoes a deceased donor kidney transplant. Minutes after vascular anastomosis and reperfusion, the transplanted kidney becomes pale and mottled, and no urine output is observed. Emergent evaluation reveals rapid vascular thrombosis within the graft. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alloreactive antibody-mediated response

 

This patient is experiencing hyperacute rejection, a rare but severe complication that occurs within minutes to hours after transplantation, typically during or immediately after graft reperfusion.

 

  • It is caused by preformed antibodies (most commonly anti-HLA or anti-ABO) present in the recipient.
  • These preformed antibodies bind to donor endothelial antigens, activating complement and leading to widespread thrombosis, ischemia, and graft failure.
  • The kidney becomes pale, mottled, and anuric, as described in the case.

 

This mechanism aligns with the phrase in the original: “Preformed antibodies” → vascular thrombosis → no urine output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activation of classical complement pathway by immune complexes: This mechanism is characteristic of Type III hypersensitivity reactions and is involved in immune complex–mediated glomerulonephritis or serum sickness, not hyperacute transplant rejection.

 

Option C. Immediate innate immune neutrophilic infiltration: While innate immunity contributes to general inflammation, neutrophils are not the initiating factor in hyperacute rejection. The primary event is preformed antibody binding, not neutrophil infiltration.

 

Option D. Graft infiltration by CD8+ cytotoxic T cells: This describes acute cellular rejection, which occurs days to weeks post-transplant. It is a T cell–mediated process, not immediate thrombosis from antibody-mediated damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperacute transplant rejection occurs within minutes due to preformed recipient antibodies against donor antigens, leading to rapid thrombosis, ischemia, and graft loss.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with a long-standing history of migraine headaches presents to the clinic for medication adjustment. She experiences moderate to severe migraines 2–3 times per month, often associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. She has a history of coronary artery disease and was advised to avoid vasoconstrictive medications. A new abortive therapy is prescribed that acts as a 5-HT1F receptor agonist without causing vasoconstriction. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lasmiditan

 

  • Lasmiditan is a selective serotonin 5-HT1F receptor agonist used for the acute treatment of migraine. 
  • Unlike triptans (which act on 5-HT 1B/1D receptors and cause vasoconstriction), lasmiditan does not cause vasoconstriction, making it a suitable choice for patients with cardiovascular disease, such as coronary artery disease.
  • Its primary mechanism involves inhibition of pain pathways in the trigeminal system, without the vascular effects seen with older agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sumatriptan:  A 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist and traditional triptan. While effective for abortive migraine treatment, it causes vasoconstriction and is contraindicated in patients with coronary artery disease.


Option B. Rimegepant: Rimegepant is a CGRP receptor antagonist (a gepant). It is also used for abortive migraine treatment and does not cause vasoconstriction, but it does not act on the 5-HT1F receptor. Therefore, it does not match the mechanism described in the question.


Option D. Eptinezumab: This is a CGRP monoclonal antibody used for migraine prevention, not abortive treatment. Also, it does not act on 5-HT receptors, and its indication is prophylactic, not abortive therapy.


Educational Objective:

 

  • Lasmiditan is a 5-HT1F receptor agonist used for the acute treatment of migraine. Unlike triptans and ergots, it does not cause vasoconstriction, making it safer for patients with cardiovascular disease.

choices.text: Observe and treat only if seizures recur

questions.text: A 72-year-old man from Jaipur with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents with sudden-onset right-sided weakness and altered sensorium. CT brain is taken and it is shown On day 2, he develops a generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting 90 seconds, followed by a postictal state. His airway is secure, vitals stable, and there is no ongoing seizure activity at present. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Load with IV phenytoin

 

Patients with acute intracerebral hemorrhage are at risk of early seizures (typically within 1–2 weeks of the hemorrhage), particularly in lobar bleeds with mass effect or cortical involvement. In this case, the patient has already had a generalized seizure, and immediate initiation of IV antiepileptic drug (AED) therapy is warranted to prevent recurrence and rising intracranial pressure (ICP), which could precipitate herniation.

 

Key Management Principles in Post-ICH Seizures:

 

 

Studies have shown that AED prophylaxis does not improve long-term outcomes and may even worsen prognosis if used indiscriminately. However, once a seizure occurs, especially in a setting of ICH with midline shift, treatment is necessary to minimize secondary brain injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start oral carbamazepine: Inappropriate due to delayed onset and unreliable absorption in acute ICH with altered consciousness.

 

Option C. Obtain an EEG: May be useful for detecting nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE) but should not delay the initiation of AEDs post-seizure.

 

Option D. Observe and treat only if seizures recur: Observation alone is inappropriate after a seizure in ICH, especially with mass effect, as further seizures risk worsening ICP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with acute ICH who experience an early seizure, prompt administration of IV antiseizure medication is essential to reduce the risk of recurrent seizures and secondary brain injury. EEG and long-term AED therapy may be considered based on seizure recurrence, but treatment must not be delayed after the initial event.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion-Reason Question:

 

Assertion (A): Engulfment of pathogens by phagocytes requires pseudopod extension.

 

Reason (R): Actin polymerization is associated with pseudopod extension during phagocytosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

 

  • Engulfment is a critical step in phagocytosis where phagocytes like neutrophils and macrophages extend membrane pseudopods to surround and internalize a pathogen or particle.
  • This process is powered by actin cytoskeleton remodeling, specifically actin polymerization, which drives the membrane outward to form the pseudopods.
  • Therefore, actin polymerization is not only associated with pseudopod extension, but is required for successful engulfment, making the reason directly explain the assertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phagocytic engulfment of pathogens involves actin polymerization, which facilitates pseudopod extension necessary to internalize the target.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man from Chennai with long-standing hypertension presents with sudden onset severe chest pain and he also complains of back pain between scapulae. BP is 210/105 mmHg, HR 94/min. Chest X ray and ECG are shown He is diaphoretic but alert, and physical examination reveals symmetrical peripheral pulses. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV labetalol bolus and infusion

 

  • The combination of tearing chest pain, hypertension, widened mediastinum, and inferior STEMI on ECG raises suspicion for aortic dissection involving the coronary arteries.
  • Inferior MI pattern may occur if dissection involves the right coronary artery ostium.
  • Administering antiplatelets in dissection can cause catastrophic bleeding into the aortic wall.
  • Priority management is to reduce shear stress by controlling heart rate (target HR <60 bpm) and blood pressure (SBP 100–120 mmHg) with IV beta-blockers.
  • Labetalol, having both alpha- and beta-blocking properties, is preferred over pure beta-blockers.
  • After stabilization, urgent imaging with CT angiography should confirm diagnosis prior to surgery.
  • Surgery is definitive for Stanford type A dissection but must follow hemodynamic stabilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection vs True STEMI

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with a lifelong history of easy bruising and mucosal bleeding. He reports frequent nosebleeds and prolonged bleeding after minor cuts. Platelet count is normal, but peripheral smear shows giant platelets. Platelet aggregation studies demonstrate defective response to ristocetin, which does not correct with addition of normal plasma. What is the most likely underlying defect responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gp Ib/IX complex deficiency

 

This patient has Bernard-Soulier disease, a rare autosomal recessive bleeding disorder caused by deficiency or dysfunction of the Gp Ib/IX complex, which is a critical platelet membrane receptor.

 

  • Gp Ib/IX is the receptor for von Willebrand factor (vWF) and is required for platelet adhesion to the damaged endothelium.
  • Deficiency results in impaired platelet adhesion, leading to mucocutaneous bleeding.
  • Peripheral smear characteristically shows large (giant) platelets and mild thrombocytopenia.

 

 

  • Platelet aggregation studies show an abnormal response to ristocetin, and unlike vWF deficiency, the defect does not correct when mixed with normal plasma (since the defect is in the platelet, not in plasma vWF).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gp Ia/IIa complex deficiency: Gp Ia/IIa is a collagen receptor and is not involved in ristocetin-induced aggregation. Deficiency in this integrin does not cause Bernard-Soulier phenotype or giant platelets.

 

Option B. von Willebrand factor deficiency: vWF deficiency (von Willebrand disease) also causes abnormal ristocetin-induced aggregation, but the defect corrects with normal plasma because vWF is a plasma protein, not a platelet membrane component.

 

Option D. Factor VIII deficiency: This describes Hemophilia A, which presents with deep tissue and joint bleeding, not mucosal bleeding or platelet function abnormalities. Factor VIII plays a role in the coagulation cascade, not platelet adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bernard-Soulier disease is caused by Gp Ib/IX complex deficiency, resulting in impaired platelet adhesion, mucosal bleeding, giant platelets, and a characteristic non-correctable defect in ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation.

choices.text: Autoclave and discard in general municipal waste
Dispose of in a yellow biohazard bag and send for immediate incineration
Store in a shielded lead-lined container until radiation levels decay, then discard as biohazard waste
Place in a red container for chemical disinfection and recycling

questions.text: A pathology laboratory technician in a tertiary hospital collects nasopharyngeal swabs for a patient undergoing radioiodine therapy for thyroid cancer. After collection, the technician asks about proper disposal. Which of the following is the most appropriate disposal method for these swabs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Store in a shielded lead-lined container until radiation levels decay, then discard as biohazard waste

 

  • Radioactive waste cannot be directly incinerated or autoclaved due to radiation hazards.
  • Swabs from radioiodine patients must be stored in radiation-shielded lead containers until the isotope decays before being treated as standard biohazard waste.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoclave and discard in general municipal waste: Incorrect, Radioactive waste cannot be mixed with general waste.
 

Option B. Dispose of in a yellow biohazard bag and send for immediate incineration: Incorrect, Incineration without prior radioactive decay can lead to environmental radiation contamination.
 

Option D. Place in a red container for chemical disinfection and recycling: Incorrect, Red containers are for recyclable plastics, not radioactive biomedical waste.


Educational Objective:

 

Swabs contaminated with radioactive material must be stored in lead-lined containers until decay before biohazard disposal.

choices.text: Sacubitril functions as an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor to reduce preload and afterload.
Sacubitril is co-administered with valsartan as part of heart failure management with reduced ejection fraction.
Sacubitril frequently leads to hypercalcemia as a dose-limiting side effect.
Sacubitril is routinely prescribed in combination with lisinopril for treatment-resistant hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Sacubitril is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sacubitril is co-administered with valsartan as part of heart failure management with reduced ejection fraction.

 

  • Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor used in combination with valsartan (an angiotensin receptor blocker) to form an angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI). This combination is indicated in chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
  • Neprilysin inhibition increases natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, and substance P, resulting in vasodilation, natriuresis, and reduced sympathetic tone.
  • Sacubitril is never combined with ACE inhibitors due to increased risk of angioedema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacubitril functions as an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor to reduce preload and afterload: Sacubitril is not an ACE inhibitor; it is a neprilysin inhibitor. Combining it with an ACE inhibitor increases the risk of angioedema.

 

Option C. Sacubitril frequently leads to hypercalcemia as a dose-limiting side effect: Hypercalcemia is not a recognized adverse effect. Possible adverse effects include hypotension, hyperkalemia, and renal dysfunction.

 

Option D. Sacubitril is routinely prescribed in combination with lisinopril for treatment-resistant hypertension: Sacubitril is contraindicated with ACE inhibitors like lisinopril due to angioedema risk and is not used for routine hypertension management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor used in combination with valsartan (as an ARNI) for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. 
  • It is not combined with ACE inhibitors due to the risk of angioedema.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of progressive fatigue, easy bruising over her limbs, and episodes of confusion over the last three days. She has no fever, joint pains, or bleeding from any orifices. Examination reveals scattered petechiae on her lower extremities and mild disorientation to time. No organomegaly is noted. Laboratory investigations reveal:

 

 

Peripheral smear shown below 

 

 

Which laboratory value is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ADAMTS13

 

  • The combination of anemia, severe thrombocytopenia, schistocytes on smear, renal impairment, and neurological symptoms points toward thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).
  • TTP is caused by a severe deficiency of ADAMTS13, a protease that normally cleaves large von Willebrand factor multimers; activity is typically <10%.
  • The uncontrolled accumulation of vWF multimers leads to widespread microvascular platelet-rich thrombi, causing tissue ischemia.
  • Normal PT/INR and fibrinogen levels help differentiate TTP from disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), where fibrinogen is decreased and coagulation parameters are deranged.
  • Plasma exchange is the first-line treatment and dramatically improves survival.
  • Compared to DIC, where coagulation abnormalities dominate, TTP is primarily a platelet-vWF mediated process.

 

HUS-TTP vs DIC:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C1 esterase: Decreased in hereditary angioedema presenting with episodic edema, not with microangiopathic hemolysis.

 

Option C. vWF multimers: Increased or normal in TTP due to deficient cleavage, not decreased.

 

Option D. Fibrinogen: Typically remains normal in TTP; decreased fibrinogen suggests DIC.

 

Educational Objective:


Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is characterized by severe ADAMTS13 deficiency leading to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and organ dysfunction; diagnosis must be suspected clinically and treated urgently with plasma exchange.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Nd:YAG laser posterior capsulotomy is/are true?

 

  1. Nd:YAG laser posterior capsulotomy is routinely performed in cases of posterior capsular opacification (PCO).
  2. The procedure creates an opening in the posterior capsule to improve visual axis clarity.
  3. This technique is rarely used in pediatric cataract patients due to the higher risk of inflammation and recurrence.
  4. Nd:YAG posterior capsulotomy is commonly used as a preventive measure during primary cataract surgery.
  5. Nd:YAG laser works via photodisruption, producing plasma and shock waves to create a capsular opening.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only statements 1, 2, and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1 - Correct: This is the primary indication for Nd:YAG capsulotomy. PCO is the most common delayed complication after cataract surgery. It results from residual lens epithelial cell proliferation on the posterior capsule, leading to decreased visual acuity. Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) is used to create an opening in the opacified capsule to restore vision.

 

Statement 2 - Correct: The goal of Nd:YAG capsulotomy is to restore a clear visual axis by creating a central opening in the posterior capsule. This helps remove the obstructive opacification caused by PCO and improves visual acuity.

 

Statement 5 – Correct: Nd:YAG laser creates capsular openings via photodisruption, generating plasma and shock waves that precisely cut tissue without mechanical contact.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3 – Incorrect, in pediatric patients, PCO is usually managed intraoperatively via surgical posterior capsulotomy with anterior vitrectomy, because children are less cooperative for laser treatment, and recurrence is high. So, Nd:YAG laser is not first-line.

 

Statement 4 – Incorrect, Nd: YAG capsulotomy is not used as a preventive step during primary cataract surgery. It is performed postoperatively, when PCO has already occurred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy treats posterior capsular opacification using photodisruption. It is not a preventive measure nor commonly used in children, who typically undergo surgical posterior capsulotomy and anterior vitrectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of gallstones undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the gallbladder is carefully dissected, and there is controlled entry into the biliary tract without spillage of bile or pus. The surgical field remains clean throughout the procedure, and the wound is primarily closed without signs of infection. On postoperative day 2, the patient remains afebrile with no signs of wound infection. Which of the following best classifies the surgical wound in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Class II 

 

  • This classification applies when controlled entry into the respiratory, alimentary, biliary, or genitourinary tract occurs without unusual contamination or major breaches in sterile technique. 
  • In this case, laparoscopic cholecystectomy involves entry into the biliary tract, but there was no gross contamination or bile spillage, making it a clean-contaminated wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I (Clean): Clean wounds do not involve entry into the respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary tract. Since this procedure involves the biliary tract, it is not a clean wound.

 

Option C. Class III (Contaminated): Wounds in this category involve major sterile technique breaks, open traumatic wounds, or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Since there was no bile spillage or infection in this case, this is incorrect.

 

Option D. Class IV (Dirty): These wounds involve existing infection, abscess, or perforated viscera. Since this was an elective surgery with no infection, it does not qualify as a dirty wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clean-contaminated surgical wounds (Class II) occur when there is controlled entry into hollow organs such as the gastrointestinal, biliary, respiratory, or genitourinary tract without significant contamination.
  • Understanding surgical wound classification helps in predicting postoperative infection risk and the need for prophylactic antibiotics.

choices.text: Cribriform subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ
Comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman undergoes screening mammography, which reveals suspicious linear and branching calcifications in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. A core needle biopsy is performed, and histopathologic examination demonstrates ductal epithelial proliferation with central necrosis and calcification. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ

 

The Comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is characterized by:

 

  • High-grade malignant cells
  • Central necrosis, which leads to dystrophic calcification
  • Often detected via screening mammogram due to microcalcifications
  • Represents an aggressive form of in situ breast carcinoma confined to ducts

 

The presence of both necrosis and calcification is a classic feature of Comedo DCIS, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS): LCIS typically does not show necrosis or calcification. It is usually an incidental microscopic finding and does not form masses or calcifications visible on mammography.

 

Option B. Colloid carcinoma: Also known as mucinous carcinoma, this is a rare invasive breast carcinoma subtype composed of extracellular mucin pools. It does not feature central necrosis or calcification.

 

Option C. Cribriform subtype of DCIS: While this DCIS subtype shows uniform cribriform (sieve-like) spaces, it typically lacks central necrosis and calcification. It is a low-grade form of DCIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ is characterized by central necrosis and calcification, making it detectable on mammography as suspicious microcalcifications.

choices.text: Increased choroidal visibility due to reduced pigmentation in the outer retina
Structural indentation of the sclera near the optic disc
Localized vitreoretinal traction in the peripheral retina
Dislocation of the lens due to defective zonular fibers

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents for a routine eye exam. She has a long-standing history of progressive high myopia since adolescence. On dilated fundus examination, the ophthalmologist notes a tigroid or tessellated appearance of the fundus, particularly in the posterior pole. Which of the following best explains this fundoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased choroidal visibility due to reduced pigmentation in the outer retina

 

The tigroid or tessellated fundus pattern seen in high myopia results from thinning of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and choroid, making the underlying choroidal vessels more visible. This creates a characteristic "tigroid" or "leopard-skin" appearance, most prominent in the posterior pole. It is a hallmark of long-standing axial myopia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Structural indentation of the sclera near the optic disc:  Describes posterior staphyloma, which is another finding in high myopia but not the cause of the tigroid pattern. It is a bulging of the weakened sclera, not thinning of the RPE.

 

Option C. Localized vitreoretinal traction in the peripheral retina:  Refers to lattice degeneration, which is a peripheral retinal condition associated with risk of retinal tears or detachment — not responsible for the posterior pole tigroid appearance.

 

Option D. Dislocation of the lens due to defective zonular fibers:  Seen in ectopia lentis, as in Marfan or homocystinuria, unrelated to the fundus pigmentation or tigroid pattern seen in myopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tigroid or tessellated appearance of the fundus in high myopia results from thinning of the retinal pigment epithelium and choroid, making choroidal vessels more visible. This is a characteristic finding in longstanding axial myopia.

choices.text: The median nerve of the right hand is injured.
There is weakness of thenar muscles on the right side.
The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak.
The flexor muscles of the thumb of the right hand are weak.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of progressive weakness in his right hand. The patient reports difficulty in fine movements of the hand. The doctor performed a test over the patient, as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true about the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

 

  • The test shown in the image is called the Froment's sign, also known as the book test. 
  • This test is used to assess the function of the ulnar nerve, specifically the function of the adductor pollicis muscle. 
  • In the normal hand, the patient should be able to hold a book (or paper) using adduction of the thumb. The ulnar nerve is responsible for this movement through the adductor pollicis muscle.
  • In this patient, the ulnar nerve is damaged, leading to weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle. 
  • Adductor pollicis is graveyard of the ulnar nerve.
  • As a result, the patient compensates by using the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) to flex the thumb while holding the paper, as seen in the image. 
  • This is why the thumb flexes rather than adducts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The median nerve of the right hand is injured: This is incorrect because the median nerve is not responsible for the adduction of the thumb. It innervates the flexor pollicis longus, which is compensating in this test.

 

Option B. There is weakness of the thenar muscles on the right side: This is incorrect because the thenar muscles (which are innervated by the median nerve) are not affected. The issue is with the adductor pollicis (innervated by the ulnar nerve).

 

Option D. The flexor muscles of the thumb of the right hand are weak: This is incorrect because the flexor muscles of the thumb (innervated by the median nerve) are functioning and are compensating for the weakened adductor pollicis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Froment’s sign is a test for ulnar nerve damage, specifically testing the adductor pollicis muscle. 
  • When the ulnar nerve is damaged, the patient compensates by using the flexor pollicis longus, resulting in flexion of the thumb instead of adduction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoing metabolic evaluation for a suspected lipid metabolism disorder is found to have impaired fatty acid synthesis. Further biochemical analysis reveals a deficiency in NADPH production. Which of the following enzymes is least likely to contribute to the NADPH pool required for fatty acid biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase

 

Fatty acid synthesis requires a continuous supply of NADPH, which acts as a reducing agent. Major sources of NADPH include:

 

  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (now rephrased as Hexose monophosphate shunt dehydrogenase in option a): catalyzes the first step in the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) and produces NADPH.
  • 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase: catalyzes a later step in PPP and also generates NADPH.
  • Malic enzyme: catalyzes the decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate in the cytoplasm and generates NADPH.

 

Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase, however, is involved in the interconversion of malate and oxaloacetate, and does not produce NADPH. It is part of the malate-aspartate shuttle, which transfers NADH, not NADPH, across mitochondrial membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main sources of NADPH for anabolic reactions like fatty acid synthesis are the pentose phosphate pathway and the malic enzyme reaction. Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase does not produce NADPH and is not involved in fatty acid biosynthesis.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skin rash 

 

  • Skin rash is not typically associated with PHPT. 
  • The classical symptoms are related to the effects of high calcium levels on bones, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and the central nervous system.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Ureteric calculi: Renal and ureteric calculi are a common manifestation of primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT). The condition can lead to hypercalcemia, which in turn can cause calcium to precipitate in kidneys leading to calcium oxalate stones.

 

Option B. Bone lesions: Patients with PHPT can experience bone pain and skeletal fragility. This is due to excess PTH stimulating bone resorption, which can lead to osteitis fibrosa cystica, a condition where bones become weak and deformed.

 

Option C. Mental confusion:  Elevated calcium levels associated with PHPT can result in neuropsychiatric manifestations, including mental confusion, fatigue, depression, and memory impairment, often referred to as "psychiatric moans"

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Skin rash is not a typical manifestation of symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, which is classically characterized by symptoms involving the bones, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and central nervous system, summarized by the phrase ‘painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, fatigue overtones and psychiatric moans’.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 17 weeks gestation undergoes a second-trimester quadruple screening test. The results show the following: 

 

  • β-hCG: ↑
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): ↓
  • Unconjugated estriol (uE3): ↓
  • Inhibin A: ↑

 

Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most consistent with this pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trisomy 21

 

The quadruple test includes:

 

  1. β-hCG
  2. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  3. Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  4. Inhibin A

 

The typical pattern of results seen in Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is:

 

  • ↑ β-hCG
  • ↓ AFP
  • ↓ uE3
  • ↑ Inhibin A

 

This pattern reflects the placental dysfunction associated with Down syndrome and is a classic profile detected in second-trimester screening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome):

 

  • β-hCG: Normal or ↓
  • AFP: ↑
  • uE3: ↓
  • Inhibin A: Not diagnostic
    → AFP is increased, but β-hCG is not elevated, making this unlikely.

 

Option B. Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome):

 

  • All three (β-hCG, AFP, uE3) ↓
  • Inhibin A: not useful
    → Doesn’t match the elevated β-hCG and Inhibin A.

 

Option D. Neural tube defect:

 

  • ↑ AFP, normal β-hCG, uE3, and Inhibin A
    → Isolated elevation of AFP only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Trisomy 21, the quadruple screen shows ↑ β-hCG and Inhibin A, and ↓ AFP and uE3. This distinct pattern helps in early risk stratification for Down syndrome in the second trimester.

questions.text: A 22-week pregnant woman from Hyderabad, known to be HIV-positive, presents with a 2-week history of worsening dry cough, low-grade fever, and progressive breathlessness. She denies hemoptysis, chest pain, or purulent sputum. Her last CD4 count, six weeks ago, was 180 cells/µL, and she reports irregular adherence to antiretroviral therapy. On examination, her temperature is 37.8°C, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. Chest auscultation is clear. Chest X-ray shows no focal infiltrates or consolidation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

 

  • This clinical picture is strongly suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals with CD4 <200 cells/μL.
  • PCP often presents with progressive dyspnea, dry cough, low-grade fever, and hypoxia, despite a normal or near-normal chest X-ray early in the disease course.
  • Chest radiographic findings may be normal in 5-30% of patients with a diagnosis of PCP. The literature reports a false-negative rate of 35- 40% when chest radiography is used for diagnosis of PCP.
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) remains the first-line treatment for PCP, including during pregnancy after the first trimester.
  • Adjunctive corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) should be added if PaO₂ <70 mmHg or if the alveolar-arterial (A–a) gradient exceeds 35 mmHg.
  • Oseltamivir treats influenza, and ceftriaxone plus azithromycin is reserved for typical bacterial community-acquired pneumonia, which presents differently.

 

PCP vs Bacterial Pneumonia vs Influenza:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhaled pentamidine: Used for prophylaxis, not effective for treating active PCP.

 

Option C. Oseltamivir: Appropriate for influenza, which presents with acute high-grade fever, myalgias, and systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone and azithromycin: Standard empiric therapy for bacterial pneumonia but ineffective against Pneumocystis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV-positive patients presenting with possible Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia one should treat with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, even during pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient undergoes the procedure shown in the image. What is the most likely underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic venous insufficiency

 

  • The images depict Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA), a minimally invasive procedure used for treating chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) and varicose veins. 
  • In this condition, venous valve dysfunction leads to reflux, causing venous stasis, edema, and venous hypertension. 
  • EVLT works by using laser energy to cause thermal ablation of the affected vein, leading to fibrosis and closure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): DVT presents with unilateral limb swelling, tenderness, and warmth, and is diagnosed with compression ultrasound. It is managed with anticoagulation, not EVLT.

 

Option C. Lymphedema: Lymphedema results from lymphatic obstruction, leading to painless, non-pitting edema. It does not improve with leg elevation and is not treated with EVLT. It is treated with limb reductive surgeries. 

 

Option D. Peripheral arterial disease (PAD): PAD is due to atherosclerosis causing claudication and ischemic symptoms. It is diagnosed with Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and treated with revascularization, not EVLT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • EVLT (Endovenous Laser Therapy) is a first-line minimally invasive treatment for chronic venous insufficiency and varicose veins, caused by venous valve incompetence. 
  • Patients present with leg pain, edema, and visible varicosities, which worsen with prolonged standing and improve with leg elevation.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Lingual artery is a branch of the external carotid artery (ECA), responsible for supplying the tongue.

 

B. Vertebral artery is a branch of the subclavian artery, providing blood supply to the brain and forming part of the Circle of Willis.

 

C. Anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery (ICA), forming part of the Circle of Willis and supplying the brain.

 

D. Iliolumbar artery is a branch of the internal iliac artery, supplying the pelvic region and lower back.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Immediate surgical excision of the cyst
Observation and repeat imaging after 6 months
Initiation of high-dose praziquantel therapy alone

questions.text: A 28-year-old shepherd from a rural region presents with dull right upper quadrant pain and intermittent fever for 2 months. He reports weight loss but no jaundice or vomiting. On abdominal examination, a vague mass is palpable in the right hypochondrium. An ultrasound is shown in the image. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PAIR procedure with prior albendazole treatment

 

  • Hydatid disease caused by Echinococcus granulosus presents with cysts in the liver or lungs. 
  • The presence of the classic "floating membrane" on ultrasound confirms the diagnosis. 
  • PAIR with albendazole is the preferred first-line treatment for symptomatic uncomplicated or uncalcified hydatid cysts. 
  • It is minimally invasive and avoids the risks of open surgery.
  • If the cyst is calcified and symptomatic, wait and watch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate surgical excision: It is generally reserved for complicated cysts (e.g., those that are large, ruptured, infected, or exerting pressure on nearby structures). Surgery carries a higher risk and is not the initial management in uncomplicated cases.

 

Option C. Observation and repeat imaging after 6 months: It is not appropriate given the symptoms and imaging confirmation. Delaying treatment may increase the risk of rupture or secondary infection.

 

Option D. Initiation of high-dose praziquantel therapy alone: Albendazole is the anti-parasitic drug of choice; praziquantel is not first-line for Echinococcus. Monotherapy with praziquantel is not effective in hydatid disease.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Posterior urethral injury involving the membranous urethra

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a bicycle accident during which he struck his perineum against the crossbar. He now has difficulty urinating, a perineal hematoma, and blood at the urethral meatus. A retrograde urethrogram (RUG) is performed, as shown in the image. Based on this finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bulbar urethral injury

 

The bulbar urethra, part of the anterior urethra, is the most common site of injury in straddle-type trauma (e.g., perineal impact from falling on a bicycle). 

 

The retrograde urethrogram image shows contrast extravasation localized to the bulbar region without reaching the membranous or prostatic urethra, confirming a partial tear or contusion in the bulbar urethra.

 

This injury typically presents with:

 

  • Blood at the meatus
  • Difficulty or inability to void
  • Perineal bruising or “butterfly” hematoma

 

In such cases, catheterization should be avoided until imaging confirms urethral integrity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Posterior urethral injury involving the membranous urethra: Usually due to pelvic fractures, not straddle injuries. Involves the membranous or prostatic urethra and often causes urinary retention with a high-riding prostate on exam.

 

Option B. Bladder neck rupture: Associated with pelvic trauma and may lead to extraperitoneal or intraperitoneal urinary leakage but would not show localized contrast extravasation at the bulbar urethra.

 

Option D. Penile urethral transection: Typically presents with complete disruption, often associated with penile trauma or instrumentation, and contrast would extravasate more distally, near the penile shaft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethral injury is the most common type of anterior urethral injury, typically caused by straddle trauma and confirmed via retrograde urethrogram showing localized contrast extravasation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy who has not received routine immunizations presents with conjunctival injection, runny nose, and bluish-white lesions on the buccal mucosa adjacent to the lower molars. The next day, he develops a maculopapular rash that begins on the face and neck and gradually spreads downward. Based on clinical findings, a viral exanthem is suspected. Which of the following best describes the genomic and structural characteristics of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enveloped single-stranded RNA

 

  • The clinical presentation is classic for measles (rubeola): Koplik spots, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash starting on the face.
  • Measles virus is a member of the Paramyxoviridae family.
  • It is an enveloped virus containing single-stranded, negative-sense RNA (ssRNA).
  • The Koplik spots are pathognomonic and usually precede the rash.
