  • Measles can be prevented with the MMR vaccine, which the child did not receive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naked double-stranded RNA: Describes reoviruses, such as rotavirus, which cause gastroenteritis, not a maculopapular rash with Koplik spots.

 

Option B. Enveloped double-stranded RNA: No known human pathogen fits this profile; double-stranded RNA viruses are not enveloped.

 

Option D. Naked single-stranded RNA: Includes viruses like enteroviruses, which may cause hand-foot-mouth disease or aseptic meningitis, but not measles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus is an enveloped, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus that presents with coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and a descending maculopapular rash, especially in unimmunized children.

 

Note: Mnemonic for Non-enveloped Virus:

 

P – Picorna virus

 

R – Reo virus

 

A – Hep. A virus

 

C – Calcivirus

 

HE – Hep. E virus

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man from Mumbai undergoing induction chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma becomes lethargic and oliguric within 24 hours of treatment initiation. He reports flank discomfort and nausea. On exam, his BP is 128/76 mmHg, HR 102/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. He is afebrile. Laboratory findings are as follows:

 

 

Urine microscopy image is shown below.

 

 

What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administer rasburicase

 

  • The patient presents with clinical tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) — a life-threatening oncologic emergency due to rapid lysis of tumor cells after chemotherapy, especially in high-burden malignancies like Burkitt lymphoma.
  • Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and acute kidney injury form the hallmark of TLS.
  • The rhomboids/rosettes seen in urine are classic for uric acid crystalluria – suggesting urate nephropathy due to intrarenal deposition and tubular injury. 
  • Rasburicase is the treatment of choice because it enzymatically converts uric acid to allantoin, a highly soluble and non-toxic metabolite.
  • Allopurinol is useful for prophylaxis but does not eliminate existing uric acid or dissolve crystals.
  • Sodium bicarbonate may exacerbate calcium phosphate precipitation.
  • Hemodialysis is reserved for severe, refractory TLS with uncontrolled electrolyte abnormalities or volume overload.

 

Biochemical and Clinical Features of Tumor Lysis Syndrome:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start allopurinol: Prevents TLS but ineffective in reducing existing uric acid or crystals.

 

Option C. Begin sodium bicarbonate infusion: Raises urine pH, increasing calcium phosphate precipitation.

 

Option D. Immediate hemodialysis: Indicated in life-threatening or refractory TLS, not initial management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with laboratory and clinical tumor lysis syndrome, rasburicase is the first-line therapy for rapidly reducing uric acid and preventing further renal injury. Allopurinol is prophylactic and not effective once TLS has developed.

questions.text: During retro-pancreatic dissection of the neck of the pancreas in Whipple’s procedure, which of the following structures is the least likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastroduodenal artery

 

  • The GDA is a branch of the common hepatic artery and supplies blood to the stomach and the duodenum. 
  • It courses anterior to the pancreas rather than posteriorly, making it less likely to be injured during retro-pancreatic dissection. 
  • Typically, it is ligated earlier in the surgery to prevent bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Portal vein: The portal vein runs posterior to the neck of the pancreas and is in close proximity during retro-pancreatic dissection. Therefore, it is highly prone to injury during this step of the Whipple’s procedure.

 

Option B. Superior mesenteric artery (SMA): The SMA lies posterior to the pancreas and to the left of the superior mesenteric vein. Although protected to some extent, the SMA is in the surgical field and could be at risk of injury during retro-pancreatic dissection if care is not taken.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric vein (SMV): The SMV is located posterior to the neck of the pancreas and runs alongside the portal vein. It is vulnerable during retro-pancreatic dissection and thus more likely to be injured compared to the GDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Gastroduodenal artery is the least likely to be injured because it lies anterior to the pancreas and is ligated during earlier phases of the procedure. 
  • The other structures—portal vein, SMA, and SMV—are located posterior to the pancreas and are within the surgical field during this dissection, increasing their risk of injury.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and eruptive skin lesions. Physical examination reveals multiple small yellowish papules over the extensor surfaces of the arms and buttocks. Laboratory testing shows markedly elevated triglyceride levels. Genetic testing reveals a defect in the apolipoprotein required to activate lipoprotein lipase (LPL), resulting in impaired clearance of chylomicrons. Which of the following apolipoproteins is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apo CII

 

  • Apolipoprotein CII (Apo CII) is essential for the activation of lipoprotein lipase (LPL), an enzyme responsible for hydrolyzing triglycerides present in chylomicrons and VLDL into free fatty acids and glycerol, allowing their uptake by peripheral tissues. 
  • In the absence of Apo CII, LPL cannot be activated, leading to accumulation of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins such as chylomicrons in the plasma.
  • This condition, often seen in familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia), presents with severe hypertriglyceridemia, acute pancreatitis, eruptive xanthomas, and sometimes lipemia retinalis.
  • The elevated triglycerides are a direct result of impaired chylomicron breakdown due to the lack of Apo CII.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo A: Apo A (especially Apo A-I) is the main apolipoprotein in HDL particles and plays a role in reverse cholesterol transport. It does not activate LPL and is not involved in chylomicron metabolism.

 

Option B. Apo B48: Apo B48 is essential for the assembly and secretion of chylomicrons in the intestine, but it does not activate LPL. While important for chylomicron formation, its role is structural, not enzymatic.

 

Option C. Apo B100: Apo B100 is found in VLDL, IDL, and LDL, and is necessary for LDL receptor binding and hepatic uptake of LDL particles. It is not involved in LPL activation or chylomicron metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apolipoprotein CII is required to activate lipoprotein lipase, enabling the hydrolysis of triglycerides from chylomicrons and VLDL into free fatty acids for tissue uptake.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation undergoes a routine obstetric ultrasound. Which of the following best describes this abnormal placental finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Velamentous cord insertion

 

Velamentous cord insertion occurs when the umbilical cord inserts into the fetal membranes (amnion and chorion) rather than directly into the placenta. The fetal vessels then travel within the membranes, unprotected by Wharton’s jelly, before reaching the placental disc. This exposes the vessels to risk of rupture, especially during labor or membrane rupture, and is associated with vasa previa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marginal cord insertion: Also known as battledore placenta, where the cord inserts at the edge of the placenta.

 

Option B. Battledore placenta: Another name for marginal insertion; the cord is attached at the periphery of the placenta.

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta: Involves a thickened, raised placental margin due to folding of the chorion; associated with placental insufficiency and abruption, not with cord insertion anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Velamentous cord insertion is a placental abnormality where fetal vessels traverse the membranes before inserting into the placenta, increasing the risk of vessel rupture, vasa previa, and fetal hemorrhage. It is diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound and requires careful monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following staining techniques is most appropriate to confirm the presence of Nocardia species?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Modified acid-fast stain

 

  • Nocardia species are aerobic, branching filamentous, weakly acid-fast bacteria.
  • They contain mycolic acid in their cell wall but in smaller amounts than Mycobacterium.
  • As a result, they do not retain stain with classic Ziehl-Neelsen stain, but they do stain positive with modified acid-fast techniques such as the Kinyoun method, which uses a weaker acid (1% sulfuric acid) during decolorization.
  • This helps differentiate Nocardia from similar-appearing organisms like Actinomyces (non–acid-fast).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albert stain: Used to detect metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not Nocardia.

 

Option C. Ziehl-Neelsen stain: Designed for strong acid-fast organisms like Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Nocardia often fails to retain stain with this method due to its partial acid-fastness.

 

Option D. Silver impregnation: Useful for fungi and certain spirochetes (e.g., Treponema), not typically used to confirm Nocardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are weakly acid-fast, and their presence is best confirmed using a modified acid-fast stain, such as the Kinyoun technique.

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulliparous woman desires long-term contraception and is interested in any additional health benefits the method may provide. Which of the following non-contraceptive benefits is associated with CuT 380A use?​
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced risk of endometrial cancer.​

 

  • The use of non-hormonal IUDs, such as CuT 380A, has been associated with a reduced risk of endometrial cancer. 
  • The exact mechanism is not fully understood but is thought to involve the local inflammatory response induced by the IUD, which may have protective effects against the development of endometrial malignancies. ​

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased risk of ovarian cancer: Incorrect, there is no significant evidence linking CuT 380A use to a decreased risk of ovarian cancer.​

 

Option B. Increased bone mineral density: Incorrect, CuT 380A does not impact bone mineral density; this benefit is more associated with hormonal contraceptives.​

 

Option C. Protection against pelvic inflammatory disease: Incorrect, While IUDs do not increase the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease after the initial insertion period, they do not provide protection against it.​

 

Educational Objective: 
 

CuT 380A use is associated with a reduced risk of endometrial cancer, likely due to the local inflammatory response it induces in the endometrium.

choices.text: Toluidine dye should be used to detect recent microinjuries on genitalia before taking the swab for sperm detection
History should not be taken from the victim if her age < 12 years
Radiological confirmation of age of victim should be done in every case of rape victim examination
Per speculum examination may not be needed in young victim if there is no history of penetration

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to examination of a female victim of sexual assault?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Per speculum examination may not be needed in young victim if there is no history of penetration

 

  • The correct answer is Per speculum examination may not be needed in young victim if there is no history of penetration. 
  • In cases of sexual assault involving young female victims, the examination approach must be child-sensitive, minimally invasive, and based strictly on the history provided. A per speculum examination is an invasive procedure typically used to inspect the vagina and cervix. 
  • However, if the victim is young and there is no history or signs of vaginal penetration, performing such an examination is not mandatory and may even be discouraged to prevent further trauma. 
  • The medico-legal examination should always prioritize comfort, dignity, and consent, especially in minors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toluidine dye should be used to detect recent microinjuries on genitalia before taking the swab for sperm detection:  Incorrect, while toluidine blue dye is used for identifying microtrauma in genital examination, applying it before collecting swabs can interfere with sperm detection and other forensic evidence collection. Forensic swabs for sperm, semen, or DNA must be taken prior to using any dyes or reagents to avoid contamination or loss of evidence.

 

Option B. History should not be taken from the victim if her age < 12 years: Incorrect, and misleading. The history is an essential part of any sexual assault examination. If the child is capable of providing a coherent account, history should be taken in a sensitive and age-appropriate manner. If needed, a guardian or trained counselor may assist, but the victim’s own version should not be ignored solely due to age.

 

Option C. Radiological confirmation of age of victim should be done in every case of rape victim examination: Not true, for every case. Radiological age estimation is usually performed only if there is a dispute or legal requirement regarding the age of the victim (e.g., in child sexual abuse cases where age affects the legal charge). It is not mandated in all rape victim examinations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Per speculum examination may not be needed in a young female victim of sexual assault if there is no history of penetration.
Invasive procedures must be guided by the history and clinical findings, especially in children.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old obese woman reports worsening heartburn after meals for the past 5 years. She undergoes upper endoscopy and biopsy of the distal esophagus, shown in the histology image below. Based on these findings, which of the following statements regarding this condition are true? 

 

  1. The biopsy reveals a transformation of normal squamous epithelium into columnar epithelium with intestinal features.
  2. Goblet cell hyperplasia is the hallmark of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.
  3. This metaplastic process is typically a response to chronic acid reflux and can predispose to adenocarcinoma.
  4. The lamina propria shows atrophy as a result of repeated mucosal injury.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only statements 1 and 3 are correct

 

Statement 1 – True: This describes Barrett esophagus, where non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus is replaced by non-ciliated, mucin-secreting columnar epithelium with goblet cells — a metaplastic adaptation to chronic acid exposure.

 

Statement 3 – True: Chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) leads to this metaplasia. Over time, this change may progress to dysplasia and eventually esophageal adenocarcinoma, especially in obese individuals with chronic reflux.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2 – False: Goblet cells are not a feature of squamous cell carcinoma. Instead, goblet cells are found in Barrett esophagus, and their presence confirms intestinal metaplasia, not carcinoma.

 

Statement 4 – False: The lamina propria is not atrophic in Barrett esophagus. The key histologic feature is replacement of squamous cells with columnar epithelium, not thinning of the lamina propria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett esophagus is characterized by columnar metaplasia with goblet cells in the distal esophagus, secondary to chronic GERD. This metaplasia increases the risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman reports widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and unrefreshing sleep for the past several months. Physical examination reveals tenderness in multiple soft tissue areas without joint swelling or redness. Laboratory tests, including inflammatory markers, are within normal limits. She is diagnosed with fibromyalgia and started on a medication that works by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Milnacipran

 

  • Milnacipran is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) specifically approved for the management of fibromyalgia.
  • It inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, leading to increased levels of these neurotransmitters in the CNS, which helps modulate pain perception and improves energy and mood in patients with fibromyalgia.
    • It does not treat depression in the U.S., although it is an SNRI.
    • Its role in fibromyalgia is FDA-approved and clinically effective in reducing pain and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pregabalin: While also FDA-approved for fibromyalgia, it works by binding to alpha-2-delta subunits of voltage-gated calcium channels, not by serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibition.

 

Option C. Fluoxetine: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). It may be helpful in some fibromyalgia patients but does not affect norepinephrine reuptake, which is believed to be important in pain modulation.

 

Option D. Amitriptyline: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) sometimes used off-label for fibromyalgia, but it blocks multiple receptors (muscarinic, alpha-adrenergic, H1) and has a broader side effect profile compared to milnacipran.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Milnacipran is an SNRI that treats fibromyalgia by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, helping to modulate pain and fatigue in patients with this condition.

 

Note - 3 main SNRI – Venlafaxine, Duloxetine and Milnacipran

choices.text: Fluoride toxicity from prolonged water consumption
Lead leaching from corroded pipes due to acidic water
Chronic arsenic poisoning from groundwater contamination
Methemoglobinemia due to excessive nitrate levels in well water

questions.text: A rural elementary school has reported a sharp decline in cognitive performance among children, along with fatigue, irritability, and attention difficulties over the past year. A public health team investigates possible environmental exposures and finds that the school’s drinking water has a pH of 6.2, total dissolved solids (TDS) of 480 mg/L, and fluoride levels of 1.8 ppm. Other parameters, including turbidity and bacterial counts, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these students’ symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lead leaching from corroded pipes due to acidic water
 

  • Water with a pH below 6.5 is corrosive and can leach heavy metals, particularly lead, from old plumbing systems.
  • Lead toxicity in children causes cognitive decline, behavioral issues, anemia, and neurological impairment, which matches the symptoms seen in the students.
  • Fluoride at 1.8 ppm is slightly above the recommended limit (<1 ppm) but is unlikely to cause neurotoxicity at this level.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluoride toxicity from prolonged water consumption: Incorrect, Fluoride toxicity typically causes dental fluorosis, not cognitive decline.

 

Option C. Chronic arsenic poisoning from groundwater contamination: Incorrect, Arsenic poisoning causes skin changes, peripheral neuropathy, and carcinogenic effects, not immediate cognitive impairment.

 

Option D. Methemoglobinemia due to excessive nitrate levels in well water: Incorrect, Methemoglobinemia presents with cyanosis and dyspnea rather than cognitive dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Water with low pH (<6.5) increases the risk of lead leaching from old pipes, contributing to chronic neurotoxicity and cognitive impairment in children.

 

Water Quality Guidelines:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute left flank pain radiating to the groin. The pain is colicky in nature and associated with mild nausea. On examination, there is tenderness over the left costovertebral angle (CVA). His urine dipstick shows microscopic hematuria. After controlling his colic, the following imaging is done. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plain CT KUB

 

  • In a patient presenting with acute flank pain suggestive of ureteric colic, the gold standard for evaluation is non-contrast CT KUB (Kidneys, Ureters, Bladder), which is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting urinary calculi.
    • Plain X-ray KUB, while useful for detecting radio-opaque stones, does not visualize uric acid stones or small stones and cannot assess obstruction.
    • CT KUB is preferred because it identifies even radiolucent stones and determines the exact location, size, and degree of obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL): ESWL is a treatment modality, not a diagnostic step. It is used only after confirming the stone's location and size, typically for stones <2 cm in the kidney or proximal ureter. Without confirming stone characteristics on CT, proceeding directly to ESWL is inappropriate.

 

Option B. Uretero-renoscopic removal (URS): URS is indicated if the stone is < 10 mm, causing obstruction, or if ESWL fails. Since the diagnosis is not yet confirmed, immediate intervention is not appropriate.

 

Option C. Wait and Watch: Observation is considered for small (<5 mm) non-obstructing stones that are likely to pass spontaneously. Before deciding on conservative management, imaging confirmation with CT KUB is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with suspected renal colic, non-contrast CT KUB is the gold standard for diagnosing urinary stones.
  • It identifies stone size, location, and degree of obstruction, guiding further management. X-ray KUB alone is inadequate, as it may miss radiolucent stones.
  • ESWL, URS, or conservative management should only be considered after confirming stone characteristics on imaging.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect pair: 

 

  1. Talocalcaneonavicular joint – Saddle joint
  2. Malleo-incudal joint – Ball and socket joint
  3. Atlanto-axial joint – Pivot joint
  4. Acromio-clavicular joint – Plane joint
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

1. Talocalcaneonavicular joint – Saddle joint: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket type of synovial joint, not a saddle joint. It contributes significantly to inversion and eversion movements of the foot.

 

2. Malleo-incudal joint – Ball and socket joint: The malleus and incus form the incudomalleolar joint, which is a saddle type of synovial joint, not a ball and socket joint. The joint allows limited movement necessary for sound conduction.

 

Correct Statements:

 

3. Atlanto-axial joint – Pivot joint: The median atlanto-axial joint is a pivot joint, allowing rotation of the head side to side (as in saying "no").

 

4. Acromio-clavicular joint – Plane joint: The acromioclavicular joint is a plane type synovial joint, allowing gliding movements between the clavicle and the acromion of the scapula.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 34-year-old carpenter presents after accidentally cutting his hand with a saw. On examination, he is unable to flex the distal phalanx of his index finger. Sensation is intact. There is no active bleeding, but a deep laceration is noted over the volar aspect of the proximal phalanx. What structure is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexor digitorum profundus tendon

 

  • Inserts on the distal phalanx
  • Responsible for flexion of the DIP joint
  • Injury → inability to flex DIP, especially isolated if only one tendon is cut

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS):

 

  • Inserts on the middle phalanx
  • Flexes the PIP joint, not the DIP
  • Injury to FDS would not prevent distal phalanx flexion.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum tendon:

 

  • Located on the dorsal side of the hand
  • Responsible for extension, not flexion
  • Injury wouldn’t cause loss of flexion — wrong surface and function.

 

Option D. Lumbrical muscle:

 

  • Intrinsic muscle originating from FDP tendons
  • Functions: MCP flexion and IP extension
  • Does not directly flex the DIP — injury here wouldn’t cause isolated DIP weakness.

 

Educational objective:

 

The tendon runs through Zone II, where both FDS and FDP lie together

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with multiple flaccid bullae on his trunk and oral mucosa. A skin biopsy followed by direct immunofluorescence is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • The image shows intercellular IgG deposition in a "chicken wire/fish net" pattern, which is pathognomonic of pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disease where autoantibodies are directed against desmoglein-3 > desmoglein-1, components of desmosomes in the epidermis.
  • The condition presents with flaccid bullae, oral mucosal involvement, and a positive Nikolsky sign.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: Subepidermal blisters with linear IgG deposition along the basement membrane, not intercellular staining.

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: IgA deposition in dermal papillae in granular pattern; intensely pruritic grouped vesicles, often on extensor surfaces.

 

Option D. Linear IgA disease: Shows linear IgA deposition at the basement membrane as annular lesions with characteristic crown of jewel/ string of jewel appearance, not fish net appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension undergoes echocardiographic evaluation. His left ventricular pressure-volume loop is as shown below. Based on this, what is the estimated ejection fraction (EF)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60%


Ejection fraction (EF) is the percentage of the end-diastolic volume that is ejected during systole. It is a key indicator of ventricular function.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ejection fraction is a critical measure of systolic function and is calculated as the ratio of stroke volume to end-diastolic volume. A normal EF typically ranges from 50% to 70%, with 60% considered a healthy midpoint. Values below this range may suggest varying degrees of heart failure. ​

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Laryngeal Mask Airways (LMAs) are correct?

 

  1. LMA placement requires neuromuscular blockade for successful insertion.
  2. LMAs provide a secure airway and can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.
  3. LMAs do not completely protect against aspiration, as they do not seal off the esophagus completely.
  4. LMAs are contraindicated in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation, such as pregnant women or those with bowel obstruction.
  5. LMAs should always be removed while the patient is deeply anesthetized to prevent airway complications.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, and 4 are correct

 

Statement 2. LMAs provide a secure airway and can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation: LMAs can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation. They are commonly used in short surgeries and difficult airway management.


Statement 3. LMAs do not completely protect against aspiration, as they do not seal off the esophagus completely: LMAs do not provide complete airway protection against aspiration since they do not fully seal off the esophagus, unlike endotracheal tubes.

 

Statement 4. LMAs are contraindicated in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation, such as pregnant women or those with bowel obstruction: LMAs are contraindicated in patients with a high risk of aspiration, such as those with gastroesophageal reflux, pregnancy, or bowel obstruction.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. LMA placement requires neuromuscular blockade for successful insertion: Neuromuscular blockade is not required for LMA insertion. Unlike endotracheal intubation, LMAs can be inserted without muscle relaxation and with just sedation or deep state of anesthesia with propofol or inhalational agents.

 

Statement 5. LMAs should always be removed while the patient is deeply anesthetized to prevent airway complications: LMAs should be removed when the patient is awake and protecting their airway. Removing an LMA while the patient is still deeply anesthetized increases the risk of airway obstruction, aspiration, or laryngospasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LMAs are useful airway devices that do not require muscle relaxation, allow for spontaneous and controlled ventilation, but do not fully protect against aspiration. They should be removed when the patient is awake to avoid complications.

choices.text: Conditional logistic regression to match cases and controls on exposure duration
Cross-sectional analysis at the point of case identification
Prospective cohort analysis excluding the nested case-control component
Multivariate regression adjusting for potential confounders like age, job type, and baseline stress levels

questions.text: In a nested case-control study investigating the association between long-term exposure to occupational stress and the development of chronic anxiety disorders, researchers use baseline data for exposure assessment. What analytical approach should be prioritized to enhance the interpretability of the results concerning the development of new cases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conditional logistic regression to match cases and controls on exposure duration

 

  • Conditional logistic regression is particularly effective in nested case-control studies for analyzing data where cases and controls are matched on several criteria, including the duration of exposure.
  • This approach allows for the adjustment of matched pairs, enhancing the accuracy of the analysis by directly comparing similar individuals, thus increasing the reliability of conclusions drawn about the impact of occupational stress on anxiety disorders.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Cross-sectional analysis at the point of case identification: Incorrect, as cross-sectional analysis does not effectively utilize the longitudinal data available in a nested case-control study.
 

Option C. Prospective cohort analysis excluding the nested case-control component: Incorrect, because excluding the nested case-control component overlooks the benefits of this efficient and targeted analysis method.


Option D. Multivariate regression adjusting for potential confounders like age, job type, and baseline stress levels: Incorrect, while multivariate regression is useful, conditional logistic regression specifically leverages the matched study design for more precise results.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In nested case-control studies assessing the relationship between chronic exposures (such as occupational stress) and health outcomes (like anxiety disorders), conditional logistic regression is crucial. 
  • This method effectively matches cases and controls on exposure duration and adjusts for potential confounders, providing a robust analytical approach that enhances the interpretability of the causal relationships investigated.

questions.text: A 47-year-old cattle farmer presents with complaints of intermittent fever, malaise, and joint pain persisting for several years. He reports occupational exposure to livestock and unpasteurized dairy products. Chronic brucellosis is suspected based on clinical history and confirmatory exposure risk. Which of the following serological tests is least useful in diagnosing chronic brucellosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Standard agglutination test

 

  • The Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) detects IgM antibodies, which are more prominent in acute brucellosis.
  • In chronic brucellosis, antibody levels often shift to non-agglutinating IgG, which SAT may not detect reliably.
  • Therefore, SAT has limited sensitivity in the chronic phase, making it less useful for long-standing disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2-Mercaptoethanol test: This test breaks down IgM antibodies and allows detection of IgG antibodies, making it useful in chronic brucellosis, where IgG predominates.

 

Option B. Complement fixation test: Detects non-agglutinating IgG antibodies, making it more appropriate in chronic brucellosis.

 

Option D. Coombs' test: The Coombs' anti-human globulin test detects incomplete IgG antibodies, which are common in chronic brucellosis and not easily picked up by SAT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic brucellosis, diagnostic tests should focus on detecting non-agglutinating IgG antibodies; hence, Standard Agglutination Test is less useful, while 2-Mercaptoethanol, complement fixation, and Coombs' test are more appropriate.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with continuous urinary leakage following a total abdominal hysterectomy performed 2 weeks ago. Physical examination reveals a moist vaginal vault. A methylene blue 3-swab test is performed, during which methylene blue dye is instilled into the bladder, and three sterile swabs are placed in the vaginal canal. After 30 minutes, the uppermost swab is found to be wet but not stained, while the other two swabs remain dry and unstained. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureterovaginal fistula

 

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, methylene blue dye is instilled into the bladder. Swabs are placed in the vaginal canal to localize the origin of urinary leakage:

 

  • If the upper swab is wet but not stained, this suggests clear urine leaking from the ureter, indicating a ureterovaginal fistula.
  • If the middle swab is stained blue, it suggests dye-stained urine from the bladder leaking into the vagina — a vesicovaginal fistula.
  • If the lower swab is stained, it indicates leakage from the urethra — a urethrovaginal fistula.

 

In this case, the upper swab is wet but not stained, indicating ureteral leakage and thus a ureterovaginal fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vesicovaginal fistula: Would show blue-stained fluid on the middle swab.

 

Option B. Urethrovaginal fistula: Would stain the lower swab.

 

Option D. Urethral diverticulum: Presents as post-void dribbling or a tender anterior vaginal wall mass, not identified by this test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The methylene blue 3-swab test helps localize urinary fistulas. A wet, unstained upper swab suggests a ureterovaginal fistula, while blue-stained middle or lower swabs suggest vesicovaginal or urethrovaginal fistulas, respectively.

choices.text: Manual removal of placenta following vaginal delivery
Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks for fetal anemia
Medical termination of pregnancy at 63 days gestation

questions.text: A 27-year-old Rh-negative pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is undergoing evaluation for Rh immunoprophylaxis. She has no prior alloimmunization and her indirect Coombs test is negative. Which of the following clinical situations does not require administration of anti-D immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks for fetal anemia

 

Anti-D immunoglobulin is administered to Rh-negative pregnant women to prevent alloimmunization in situations where feto-maternal hemorrhage (FMH) is likely. Common indications include:

 

  • Abortion, MTP, ectopic pregnancy
  • Amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling
  • External cephalic version
  • Placental abruption, abdominal trauma
  • Manual removal of placenta
  • Delivery of Rh-positive infant

 

However, in the case of intrauterine transfusion, especially beyond 28 weeks, there is no maternal exposure to fetal red cells due to the nature of the sterile intrauterine procedure. Thus, anti-D prophylaxis is not required post-intrauterine transfusion alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis performed at 16 weeks gestation: Invasive procedures involving the uterus can cause FMH, so anti-D should be given.

 

Option B. Manual removal of placenta following vaginal delivery: This increases the risk of significant FMH and necessitates anti-D administration.

 

Option D. Medical termination of pregnancy at 63 days gestation: Even early gestational interventions require anti-D prophylaxis due to FMH risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-D immunoglobulin is indicated for Rh-negative women in situations where feto-maternal hemorrhage can occur, except in procedures like intrauterine transfusion beyond 28 weeks, where fetal red cells are not introduced into maternal circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical conversions is not dependent on biotin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma-carboxylation of glutamate residues

 

Biotin (vitamin B7) functions as a coenzyme for carboxylation reactions, where CO₂ is added to a substrate. Key biotin-dependent enzymes include:

 

  1. Pyruvate carboxylase (Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate)
  2. Propionyl-CoA carboxylase (Propionyl-CoA → Methylmalonyl-CoA)
  3. Acetyl-CoA carboxylase (Acetyl-CoA → Malonyl-CoA)

 

These enzymes require biotin to function properly. In contrast, gamma-carboxylation of glutamate residues is a vitamin K-dependent reaction, not a biotin-dependent one. It plays a role in modifying clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biotin (vitamin B7) is a coenzyme required for carboxylation reactions such as in gluconeogenesis, fatty acid synthesis, and amino acid metabolism. Gamma-carboxylation of glutamate residues, however, is a vitamin K–dependent process, not involving biotin.

choices.text: Normal fetal response during active labor

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation is undergoing continuous electronic fetal monitoring during labor. The fetal heart rate tracing pattern is shown below. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with the pattern seen in this tracing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Umbilical cord compression

 

The tracing shows variable decelerations, characterized by abrupt decreases in fetal heart rate that vary in onset, duration, and intensity relative to uterine contractions. These are not uniform in appearance and typically have a rapid drop and recovery.

 

Variable decelerations are most commonly caused by umbilical cord compression like in oligohydramnios, which can lead to transient reductions in fetal blood flow and oxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal head compression: Causes early decelerations, which are uniform and mirror contractions.

 

Option B. Uteroplacental insufficiency: Causes late decelerations, which begin after the contraction starts and resolve after it ends.

 

Option D. Normal fetal response: Baseline variability and accelerations are considered reassuring, not variable decelerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Variable decelerations on fetal heart rate monitoring are most commonly due to umbilical cord compression and are identified by their abrupt onset, variable shape, and inconsistent relationship with contractions.

questions.text: A 67-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding for the past 2 months. MRI of the pelvis reveals a mass in the endometrial cavity invading more than 50% of the myometrium. The tumor extends to involve the upper vagina. However, there is no radiological evidence of lymph node involvement (pelvic or para-aortic). What is the most appropriate FIGO 2023 stage of her endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) III B

 

According to the Revised FIGO 2023 staging for endometrial cancer:

 

  • Stage 1: It is confined to uterus
    • 1A: <50 % of Myometrial invasion
    • 1B: >50 % of Myometrial invasion
  • Stage 2: Cervical invasion
  • Stage IlI indicates local or regional spread of the tumor beyond the uterus
  • Stage 4: Distant metastasis
  • Stage III B includes:
    • Direct extension or metastasis to the vagina, parametrium, or pelvic peritoneum, without lymph node involvement.

 

In this case:

 

  • The tumor extends to the upper vagina, which qualifies for Stage IIIB.
  • There is no involvement of pelvic or para-aortic lymph nodes, thus excluding Stage IIIC1 or IIIC2.
  • Myometrial invasion alone (even >50%) does not qualify for Stage III unless it extends to adjacent structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. III A: This stage refers to serosal or adnexal involvement, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option C. III C1: Refers to metastasis to pelvic lymph nodes, which this patient does not have.

 

Option D. III C2: Refers to para-aortic lymph node involvement, possibly with or without pelvic lymph node metastasis—also not present here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial carcinoma extending to the vagina but without nodal involvement is staged as FIGO Stage IIIB, reflecting direct extension to vaginal or parametrial structures without regional lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: A patient with stable angina is started on a newly prescribed medication. Shortly after initiation, he reports transient visual disturbances, describing luminous phenomena (e.g., bright halos or flashing lights). Which of the following medications was most likely started?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivabradine

 

  • Ivabradine is a selective inhibitor of the funny current (If) in the sinoatrial node, leading to heart rate reduction without affecting contractility or blood pressure. It is used for:
  • Stable angina in patients who cannot tolerate beta-blockers
  • Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)
  • A notable side effect of Ivabradine is visual disturbances, particularly photopsia/ phosphenes (brief moments of enhanced brightness in vision) or luminous phenomena, due to its effect on retinal ion channels (similar to those in the SA node).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aliskiren:  A direct renin inhibitor, used in hypertension. Not associated with visual side effects.

 

Option B. Valsartan:  An angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), also used for hypertension and heart failure. Visual disturbances are not typical.

 

Option D. Fasudil: A Rho-kinase inhibitor used experimentally in some vascular conditions (e.g., cerebral vasospasm), but not standard in angina management and not linked to visual disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ivabradine is an anti-anginal drug that reduces heart rate via inhibition of the funny current in the SA node and is associated with visual side effects, such as phosphenes or luminous visual phenomena.

choices.text: Conduct annual mass drug administration in the region.
Provide ongoing public education about filariasis transmission and prevention.
Initiate genetic modification programs for mosquito populations.

questions.text: A public health consultant is assessing strategies to sustain the elimination of lymphatic filariasis in a previously endemic area. Which intervention would be most effective in preventing the re-establishment of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Establish permanent vector control measures.

 

  • For diseases like lymphatic filariasis, where transmission depends on vector mosquitoes, establishing permanent vector control measures is crucial. 
  • These measures (e.g., use of insecticide-treated bed nets, environmental management to eliminate breeding sites) directly reduce the mosquito population, thereby decreasing the risk of disease resurgence. 
  • This approach addresses the root cause of transmission and provides a sustainable solution to maintain disease elimination.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Conduct annual mass drug administration in the region: Incorrect, because while mass drug administration is effective in reducing infection levels, it does not provide a long-term solution to prevent transmission.

 

Option C. Provide ongoing public education about filariasis transmission and prevention: Incorrect, as public education is important but must be complemented by direct interventions that reduce transmission risk.

 

Option D. Initiate genetic modification programs for mosquito populations: Incorrect, because genetic modification of mosquitoes, while promising, is still experimental and not widely implemented.

 

Educational Objective:


Permanent vector control measures are essential for maintaining disease elimination, particularly for vector-borne diseases, by directly limiting the potential for disease transmission.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding common causes of vaginal discharge are correct? 

 

  1. Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a positive whiff test and the presence of clue cells on wet mount.
  2. Trichomoniasis presents with thin, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and is associated with motile flagellates on wet mount.
  3. Vulvovaginal candidiasis typically presents with curdy white discharge and vaginal pH >5.
  4. Bacterial vaginosis is usually non-irritating and is treated with oral metronidazole.
  5. The first-line treatment for candidiasis includes fluconazole or intravaginal clotrimazole.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Statements 1, 2, 4 and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a positive whiff test and the presence of clue cells on wet mount: Correct. Bacterial vaginosis (BV) typically presents with a thin, grayish-white discharge and a characteristic fishy odor, especially after adding 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) to the sample (positive whiff test). Clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells coated with adherent bacteria, are seen on saline wet mount and are a hallmark of BV.

 

Statement 2: Trichomoniasis presents with thin, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and is associated with motile flagellates on wet mount: Correct. Trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, presents with a thin, frothy, greenish-yellow vaginal discharge, often with vaginal irritation, and may show a "strawberry cervix". Diagnosis is confirmed by observing motile flagellated protozoa on a saline wet mount.

 

Statement 4: Bacterial vaginosis is usually non-irritating and is treated with oral metronidazole: Correct. Bacterial vaginosis often lacks significant irritation or inflammation, unlike candidiasis or trichomoniasis. Oral metronidazole is the recommended first-line treatment.

 

Statement 5: The first-line treatment for candidiasis includes fluconazole or intravaginal clotrimazole: Correct. Vulvovaginal candidiasis, commonly caused by Candida albicans, presents with thick, curdy white ("cottage cheese-like") discharge and intense itching or irritation. First-line treatments include oral fluconazole or intravaginal antifungals such as clotrimazole.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3: Vulvovaginal candidiasis typically presents with curdy white discharge and vaginal pH >5: Incorrect. While it is true that vulvovaginal candidiasis presents with curdy white discharge, the vaginal pH typically remains normal (≤4.5). A pH >5 is more consistent with bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis, not candidiasis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-year-old child weighing 10 kg is brought to the clinic with signs of xerophthalmia and night blindness. The physician suspects vitamin A deficiency. What is the most appropriate therapeutic dose of vitamin A for treating this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 200,000 IU

 

The WHO-recommended treatment regimen for vitamin A deficiency in children is based on age:

 

  • <6 months: 50,000 IU
  • 6–12 months: 100,000 IU
  • >12 months (including 2-year-olds): 200,000 IU

 

This dose is usually given on day 1, day 2, and repeated on day 14 to ensure resolution and prevent recurrence. Since this child is 2 years old and weighs 10 kg, the correct therapeutic dose is 200,000 IU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children older than 12 months with vitamin A deficiency should be treated with 200,000 IU of vitamin A to reverse ocular symptoms and prevent long-term visual impairment.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man, recently diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), presents to the emergency department with worsening breathlessness and lethargy. He has no fever or chest pain. On examination, he is tachypneic with an SpO₂ of 90% on room air, RR 24/min, and bilateral coarse crackles on auscultation. Chest X-ray is done and it is shown. 

 

 

Laboratory values are:

 

 

What is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukapheresis

 

  • This patient has hyperleukocytosis (WBC >100,000/μL) with respiratory symptoms and bilateral infiltrates on imaging, suggesting leukostasis, a hematologic emergency.
  • Leukostasis is characterized by decreased tissue perfusion due to high blast burden, primarily affecting the lungs and CNS.
  • Symptoms include dyspnea, confusion, coma, or retinal hemorrhages, even if oxygen saturation appears deceptively normal (due to artifactual hypoxia).
  • Leukapheresis, in combination with hydroxyurea, is recommended as urgent cytoreductive therapy when intensive chemotherapy cannot be started immediately (as in this case).
  • Chemotherapy alone (e.g., cytarabine + anthracycline) is preferred when feasible, but leukapheresis is life-saving when there's symptomatic leukostasis and chemotherapy delay.
  • Supportive care includes aggressive hydration, TLS prophylaxis, and transfusion restriction, as excessive RBC transfusion may increase viscosity and worsen leukostasis.

 

Hyperleukocytosis and Leukostasis in AML – Clinical Approach:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids: Supportive only; does not reduce blast burden rapidly.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone 10 mg: Not indicated in AML; used in ALL for CNS involvement.

 

Option D. Packed RBC transfusion: May worsen viscosity unless the patient is severely anemic; used cautiously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AML patients with hyperleukocytosis and symptoms of leukostasis require urgent cytoreduction. When induction chemotherapy cannot be immediately administered, leukapheresis combined with hydroxyurea is the preferred temporizing strategy to prevent respiratory failure, CNS deterioration, and death.
